summary: Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend's England squad selection, stating he shouldn't be in the team. Townsend responded by scoring an equalizer for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit he was wrong. However, Merson reignited the row by mocking Townsend on Twitter after he was brought on in the 83rd minute during Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley, questioning whether he missed the coach.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to sign FC Tokyo's 22-year-old Japanese forward Yoshinori Muto for approximately £4 million. If the transfer is completed, Muto would join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan. Muto, who has 37 appearances and 16 goals for FC Tokyo since 2013, has earned 11 caps for Japan and recently graduated with an economics degree. He would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea. While Muto considers the offer an honor, he has not yet decided whether to join the club. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane stated that Chelsea's interest is unrelated to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber signed in February.

A large-scale Finnish study of over 12,000 two-year-olds found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. By age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with antibiotic-exposed children showing higher rates. Repeated antibiotic prescriptions before age two increased the likelihood of excess weight, particularly in boys who were also slightly taller. The researchers suggest antibiotics may cause weight gain by killing gut bacteria that normally digest food, freeing up more calories for the body and potentially increasing appetite. While the study did not prove causation, the findings suggest antibiotic use in infancy may contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic and highlight the need for judicious antibiotic use. Previous research has also linked early antibiotic exposure to eczema and digestive problems.

A Queen's Guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, an incident captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell. The guard lost his footing, knocked his bearskin, and dropped his rifle while taking up position in his sentry box in front of hundreds of shocked tourists. He quickly scrambled to his feet as his colleagues continued marching, appearing embarrassed as he realized how many people had witnessed the fall. The slip is thought to have been caused by metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a popular daily ceremony at Buckingham Palace, and the guards are fully operational soldiers, not purely ceremonial.

The original "Roots" miniseries, which aired in 1977 and drew over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E, Lifetime, and History networks for 2016. The remake will tell the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in Virginia, and will be simulcast across the three networks. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version. The remake is described as "original" and "contemporary," drawing more directly from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," and will consult with scholars in African and African-American history for authenticity. Executive producer Mark Wolper, son of the original producer, and Burton emphasize the importance of bringing this story to a new generation of viewers.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, has reported to police that palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in January 1978 when he was 27. On his first day of work, he was accosted in a bedroom by multiple male staff members who groped him and tried to remove his trousers before he escaped. He was subsequently threatened to remain silent and left the job that day. His complaint was initially ignored for months before finally being passed to Scotland Yard after he contacted the Palace during an inquiry into historical child sex abuse cases. A retired royal aide in his 80s was interviewed but denied involvement, claiming he was working at Balmoral at the time. The Palace has stated it will cooperate with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song from 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, filmed in a car, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In their parody, they rap about buying their first home, their journey to conceiving (which took two months), and Melissa's discovery of her positive pregnancy test. The clip concludes with them sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. It took five takes to film, and the couple created it so distant loved ones could learn about the baby. The video's viral success surprised them, and they are considering making another video after learning the baby's gender. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A gray jacket and skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction in Beverly Hills, California. The dress, which featured a black zigzag applique and was worn in several key scenes including encounters with Rhett Butler and an attack in shanty town, has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray over time. It was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions, all from the private collection of James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios hair and makeup department head who purchased the dress for $20 in the 1960s when it was about to be discarded. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, Clark Gable's suit trousers and jacket for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his mother dangled him over the railing. He fell 10-12 feet into the pit on Saturday around 3pm and was rescued by his parents before emergency responders arrived. The boy suffered minor bruises and bumps, with a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs. He was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition. Zoo officials received eyewitness accounts indicating the child was deliberately dangled over the railing. The cheetahs did not approach the child, possibly due to fear caused by the screaming. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family on Monday, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham was repositioned to point directly at a residential house's front door. The camera had been non-functional for over two years after approximately 300 fixed speed and traffic cameras using outdated technology were decommissioned across the West Midlands in March 2013. Speed enforcement is now conducted through mobile camera units, motorway fixed cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council acknowledged the misaligned camera and stated an engineer would visit the site for potential removal. The council confirmed the camera will not be included in their planned pilot program using new digital technology.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced his participation. Bolt stated he is fit, healthy, and ready to run, and expressed enthusiasm about Jamaica's relay tradition and the opportunity to make his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability and anticipated strong performances from the world's fastest man. The full Jamaican team list will be announced later.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended Barcelona's basketball El Clasico match against Real Madrid on Thursday night, which Barcelona won 85-80 in the Euro League. They were accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella. Prior to this, Neymar helped Brazil defeat Chile 1-0 at the Emirates Stadium on Sunday, enduring several brutal challenges during the match. Before the international break, Barcelona won their La Liga El Clasico to move four points clear at the top. Neymar and his Barcelona team-mates will return to La Liga on Sunday to face Celta Vigo as they compete for a treble of trophies. Real Madrid remain top of the Euro League division over Barcelona by points difference.

Italy is experiencing a surge in African and Middle Eastern migrants attempting to reach Europe. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received 20 distress calls on Monday alone. Save the Children reported that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people allegedly capsized 80 miles off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard could not confirm the incident. According to the International Organization for Migration, Italy received over 10,000 migrant arrivals in the first three months of 2015, with most coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean since the year's beginning, primarily due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and crews abandoning ships.

Alexis Sanchez joined Arsenal over Liverpool and other elite clubs after leaving Barcelona, signing for £32 million. The 26-year-old Chile forward has made an immediate impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger does not know Sanchez's exact reason for choosing Arsenal but is pleased with the decision. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool's interest in Sanchez may have been connected to their negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities including efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, noting his ability to revitalize the team. Ahead of Arsenal's Premier League match against Liverpool, Wenger downplays transfer speculation regarding Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for successfully rebuilding the team following Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The record, currently held by Australian Rohan Dennis at 52.491km set in February, has been a historic achievement in cycling for over a hundred years. Wiggins, 35, will ride at the Lee Valley VeloPark in front of an expected capacity crowd of 6,000, with the event broadcast live on Sky Sports. Tickets go on sale April 19, priced at £49, £39, and £29. After finishing his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, Wiggins will compete in the Tour de Yorkshire before preparing for this hour record attempt as part of his return to track cycling.

Serena Williams defeated Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in a Fed Cup play-off match on Sunday, improving her career record against Errani to 8-0. However, Williams struggled with the clay court conditions and described the match as an "eye-opener," noting she was not as prepared for the clay court season as expected. Despite her singles victory, the US team lost the Fed Cup tie 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske losing their doubles match 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. This defeat resulted in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams, the world No. 1, won her 19th Grand Slam singles title at the Australian Open and is pursuing a calendar Grand Slam, though the French Open remains her least successful major despite winning it in 2002 and 2013.

River Plate express interest in signing Manchester United loanee Radamel Falcao, acknowledging the deal would be complicated. The 29-year-old Colombian striker previously played for River Plate for eight years before departing for Porto in 2009. Vice president Matias Patanian stated the club dreams of Falcao's return and has open doors for him. Falcao has underperformed during his loan at Manchester United with only four Premier League goals this season, though he recently scored three goals in two games for Colombia to equal the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. During his time at River Plate from 2001 to 2009, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, an X Factor finalist and pop star, has been announced as the official face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The 19-year-old is featured in campaign images showcasing various hairstyles against a vibrant city background, wearing different outfits including a black blouse with leather jacket and a black lacy dress. The international campaign was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertisement featuring Henderson's single "Mirror Man." Henderson has expressed enthusiasm about the partnership, noting that she regularly uses the product.

On March 14, officer Pablo Torres fatally shot 26-year-old Aaron Siler in Kenosha, Wisconsin after Siler armed himself with a weapon during a confrontation. The Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Torres and his dog with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha," paid for by the association to thank the community for its support during recent incidents. Siler's family and friends found the billboard disrespectful, interpreting it as thanking Torres for killing Siler, and called for its removal. The police association stated no offense was intended. Torres is on leave pending investigation into the shooting. This incident followed another shooting by Torres 10 days earlier in which he shot 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with knives; that shooting was determined to be justified. The investigation into Siler's death continues.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur on Monday. Three militants were also killed by Iranian forces. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. According to reports, the militants crossed from Pakistan into Iran, and Iranian officials requested Pakistani authorities apprehend the surviving assailants. Jaish al Adal is described as an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group operating in Balochistan that targets Shiites and aims to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. The group has claimed responsibility for previous attacks on Iranian territory, including an October 2013 incident that killed 14 border guards. Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to control terrorists, while Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism and stated its security agencies are investigating and will apprehend any militants who entered Pakistani territory.

The Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed to parliament that Japan's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs, responding to a question from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Nakatani explained that when the ASDF detects unidentified flying objects, it scrambles fighter jets for visual observation, but has only found birds or conventional aircraft, not objects from outer space. Inoki, a WWE wrestler and founder of New Japan Pro Wrestling who entered Japan's Upper House in 2013, claims to have personally seen a UFO but acknowledged uncertainty about whether aliens exist. The discussion reflects Japan's ongoing political interest in extraterrestrial matters, with a previous Defense Minister in 2007 having discussed the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in eastern China. He had been standing on the toilet rim because he was concerned about cleanliness, causing the porcelain toilet to collapse and shatter. After calling his traveling companions for help, he was taken to a hospital where he received several dozen stitches. Initially, he admitted to friends he was squatting, but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities classified the incident as an accident, and police reminded the public that toilets are for sitting on, not standing on.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl over a four-year period and secretly filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The girl discovered the camera under the sink in March, leading to the investigation. She reported that Rebbie had been watching her undress for years and molesting her in her bedroom from ages 9 to 13. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera, 34 showing victims showering, which Rebbie had uploaded to his computer. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple juvenile victims and purchased the camera specifically to record the victim. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama created a series of images featuring daughters posing calmly while their fathers leap dramatically into the air beside them. The 37-year-old's project, from a book roughly titled "Daughter and Salary Man," aims to allow fathers to express their fun side and show "strong excitement and hope" through energetic poses, contrasting with their usual serious demeanor. Each photograph shows daughters in casual clothing while fathers wear sharp suits, photographed in front of various Japanese landmarks. The series has generated significant online interest for its unconventional approach to family portraits.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has opened the door for Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, last played for England during the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia last year. The 34-year-old has rejoined Surrey for the county championship season in an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up, with England aiming to regain the Ashes on home soil this summer. Pietersen was photographed at the KIA Oval ahead of Surrey's campaign, which begins against Glamorgan on April 19.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a relegation-threatened Romanian club, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria was initially fired on Wednesday following poor results but was reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. However, after the team lost 2-0 to FC Botosani on Saturday, leaving them 16th in the standings and six points from safety, Massone fired him again. Ze Maria, a 41-year-old former Inter Milan and Parma defender with 25 Brazil caps, was Ceahlaul's third coach this season, having replaced Florin Marin in January. He will be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao joined Manchester United on a season-long loan from Monaco but has underperformed, scoring only four goals. United would need to pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent, which they are unlikely to do. His former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets the move, noting that while Falcao was unhappy in France, he would have been better off staying at Monaco where he could have played in the Champions League. Falcao's struggles stem from a serious knee injury he suffered previously.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The suspect, described as very tall and wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the till drawer and approximately $1,500 in cash from the Union St dairy around 12:30pm. He demanded money from the dairy owner's daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, and fled the scene. No weapons were used. Police are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, which included kissing and allowing the student to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail and suspended from teaching. On March 24, a second 15-year-old student came forward claiming Granado had sex with him in her car on consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again on Monday and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district placed her on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being on school property.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a Puerto Vallarta marina in Mexico with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The dog, which belonged to a local bike shop owner, approached the water's edge out of curiosity and was attacked by the crocodile. New Zealander Tim Weston witnessed the incident while on holiday and observed the crocodile holding the dog in its mouth for hours as crowds gathered. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta as the resort is built among mangroves where these creatures have lived for centuries, and they are regularly spotted on the golf course and in a nearby sanctuary. American crocodiles in Mexico can reach lengths of 6 meters and are living closer to humans due to urbanization. Social media users reacted with horror to the video.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid Premier League relegation despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton. Hull are two points clear of the drop zone with six games remaining, including difficult fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce initially targeted 10 wins for survival but now believes eight or nine points may be sufficient. He attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players including Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton moved to fifth place with the victory, though manager Ronald Koeman had to address a disciplinary issue when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty designated for James Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers outside of test conditions and altering some answers himself. Following an investigation by the local education authority, the Department for Education annulled all SATs results for the entire school. Although Guffick claimed he asked pupils to make answers more legible rather than change them, a conduct panel ruled that no changes should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions. The panel found his conduct dishonest but not fraudulent. Despite acknowledging Guffick's remorse, the Education Secretary imposed a prohibition order banning him from teaching for at least two years, citing the serious impact on the school and the deliberate nature of his actions.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has had limited playing time at the club but enjoys a successful personal life. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year, and the couple have a son together. They have been dating since 2012. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, is active on Instagram with over 17,000 followers and regularly posts modeling photos. Lindegaard joined Manchester United in 2010 from Norwegian club Aalesunds but has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons, as he is now third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. He has been told he can leave the club.

The 13 glowing blue letters that hung above Yankee Stadium since 1976 failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, with an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. Current owner Reggie Jackson, a Yankee Hall of Famer who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters after the stadium's final game in 2008, hoped to pass the iconic signage to a new generation. Only a Sotheby's employee placed a bid of $260,000 to start bidding. Jackson, who bought the letters "on a lark," attended the auction and joked about underestimating their size. He had promised to visit any U.S. buyer's home to see the letters displayed. In contrast, a Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe after they were pictured inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to both players in his office on Thursday but decided not to discipline them, emphasizing that professional athletes must be mindful of their responsibilities and what they are seen doing. Sterling will lead Liverpool's attack at Wembley on Sunday against Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final, with Daniel Sturridge unavailable due to injury. Steven Gerrard is available after completing a three-match suspension, though Rodgers has not confirmed whether he will recall him. Rodgers expressed his focus on guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final of his tenure, noting that close losses in previous competitions are part of a winning journey.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's German playmaker, returned to London after the international break where Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He posted a picture relaxing with his dog at home and is preparing for Arsenal's upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium. Ozil missed Arsenal's previous game against Newcastle due to illness but has been performing well since returning from injury, recording four assists and three goals since January. He stated that he is adjusting well to English football, noting that the demanding schedule with frequent matches suits his playing style.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has confirmed that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique and expressed satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year contract, is six games away from winning La Liga. Despite summer replacement speculation, Bartomeu praised Enrique's work ethic and dedication, noting his contract runs until 2016. Barcelona recently defeated Valencia 2-0 with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, positioning the club to potentially win three trophies this season.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool worth approximately £100,000 per week, running until summer 2020. The 24-year-old midfielder, signed by Kenny Dalglish in 2011 for £16 million from Sunderland, is the third key player under manager Brendan Rodgers to extend his contract, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson has been one of the most improved players under Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and 7 goals this season. He is expected to be considered for the club captain role when Steven Gerrard departs to LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling regarding a contract extension are not expected to resume until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis has stated his intention to remain at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. The left back, who joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid on a three-year deal last July, has struggled to establish himself in the position at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is focused on maintaining concentration and winning every remaining match in the Premier League title run-in, with Luis noting they have nine difficult games ahead.

Nathan Hughes' three-match ban for accidentally striking George North in the head with his knee was overturned on appeal following public outcry. Hughes was initially sent off and suspended after the incident on March 27, when his knee collided with North's head as he scored a try for Northampton. North was knocked unconscious and suffered his third head injury in two months, requiring a month off to recover from concussion. The appeal panel determined the incident was accidental with no foul play involved. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon but is now free to play, though he is not in the squad for the upcoming match against London Welsh.

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers burning grass and spread by strong winds on April 14, destroyed dozens of villages. Smoke from these fires was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange wavelengths to penetrate, creating intense fiery sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the dramatic red sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her St. Louis driveway in March and recovered in April after a man named Mick Sexton recognized it and tipped off police. When returned, the car had been modified with red spray-painted rims, red side detailing, and orange steering wheel accents. Rather than being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her vehicle. She is having the car professionally cleaned due to cigarette and marijuana odors, and is creating a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who found her car.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club uses incentivized contracts for star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure to maintain financial fairplay compliance. With approximately £12 million total at stake for the squad, City must finish in the top four of the Premier League, as only the top three qualify automatically while fourth place must win a qualifying round. Currently in fourth place, City are just four points ahead of Liverpool after losing to Manchester United in the Manchester derby. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged the team's poor form, stating they have lost seven times since starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea, including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. City's remaining fixtures include matches against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, Queens Park Rangers, Swansea City, and Southampton.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick in the 59th minute. The match featured 13 English players, including 10 from Manchester, and was attended by close to 1,000 spectators with free admission. United manager Paul McGuinness deployed a three-at-the-back formation with wingbacks to provide experience closer to senior football. Marcus Rashford had two missed opportunities for City, while Cameron Borthwick-Jackson nearly added a second for United when his shot struck the crossbar. The victory leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has now lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series.

Joe Hart, England's goalkeeper, praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th international cap in a 1-1 draw between England and Italy. Hart, who reached his own milestone of 50 caps in the match, expressed admiration for the 37-year-old Buffon, stating he continues to learn from him. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed pride in his 50 caps and indicated his desire to continue adding to his international appearances while playing well for both club and country.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to offer food delivery in 67 cities for online and mobile orders. The service will include a nine percent service charge plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Postmates uses independent contractors who drive their own vehicles. This marks Chipotle's entry into the $70 billion food delivery market after previously declining similar offers. Other major food chains including Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also expanding into food delivery services.

The parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing, are urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty from the case against convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, Bill and Denise Richard describe the devastating toll on their family, including Martin's death, their daughter Jane's severe injuries, and multiple surgeries. They support life imprisonment without parole and waiver of appeal rights instead, arguing that years of death penalty appeals would prolong their family's suffering and pain. The Richards acknowledge the crimes' brutality but believe ending the case now would allow their family and the country to move forward. Tsarnaev was convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings, which killed three people and wounded over 200 on April 15, 2013. The sentencing phase began the day after the 2013 race's anniversary and was expected to last four weeks.

A custom-built Boeing 747 has been converted into a luxury home for a billionaire owner at an estimated cost of £400 million over three years. Instead of carrying up to 600 passengers, this aircraft is designed for a single owner with capacity for dozens of guests. The interior features multiple bedrooms including a master suite, an aeroloft with eight beds on the top deck, a dining room with adjoining kitchen, multiple lounges, a state room, a conference room, and office space. The design resembles a luxury hotel rather than a commercial aircraft, with all traditional seating removed and replaced with high-end furnishings and amenities.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station. The rocket stage landing on a floating drone ship was unsuccessful—it landed but tipped over. This was SpaceX's second attempt to land a rocket at sea; a January attempt resulted in the rocket hitting at an angle and exploding. SpaceX aims to reuse rockets like airplanes to reduce space access costs by up to a factor of a hundred. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station, including an espresso maker, and will return with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station and the second launch attempt for this mission, as Monday's launch was scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley is collaborating with NBC's Today show to launch a contest where one Elvis-obsessed couple will win an "ultimate wedding" at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on April 23. The winning couple will receive a free wedding reception, two-night hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show, with Priscilla serving as a witness. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis artifacts outside Memphis, Tennessee, and Priscilla has emphasized that the chapel is first-class and not a joke, with no impersonators allowed. Couples must submit a video or photos with an explanation of why they deserve the prize to enter the contest, with winners announced the following Monday.

Liverpool defeated Newcastle United 2-0 on Monday night, with Raheem Sterling scoring in the ninth minute and Joe Allen scoring his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes remaining. Vice-captain Jordan Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City, who sit four points ahead in the Premier League title race. Liverpool had suffered disappointing recent results against Manchester United and Arsenal but are now focused on winning matches and applying pressure to City. Newcastle appealed for a penalty when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez, but it was not awarded.

Roma ended their four-month home winless streak with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute following a swift counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves in the second half to secure the win. The victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in the Champions League places race. Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place. Security was heightened for the match due to previous incidents between the clubs, with 1,000 police officers present and residents of the Campania region barred from purchasing tickets, though no problems were reported.

Doncaster Rovers played Fleetwood Town in a League One match at the Keepmoat Stadium that ended in a 0-0 draw. The uninspired match tested fans' patience, leaving Doncaster's media team with the challenge of compiling highlights. They created a 27-second video with only 14 seconds of match action, showing just the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle. Doncaster has had a difficult season, sitting in mid-table mediocrity in League One, while Fleetwood's play-off hopes had largely disappeared.

Roland Giroux has developed a remarkable interactive relationship with his blood parrot cichlid fish through daily tactile engagement. After removing two bullying tank mates, he began hand-feeding the fish frozen blood worms, which led to increased sociability. The fish now enjoys being stroked and massaged for at least 15 minutes daily, becoming frustrated without this interaction. The fish demonstrates affection by swimming to Giroux's hand, resting between his fingers, and following his hand to the water's surface. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of midas and redhead cichlids first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character, has returned to the England cricket team after a difficult year, with only a minor back issue potentially preventing him from playing in Barbados. He previously broke his wrist punching a locker after dismissal and clashed with Marlon Samuels during the second Test, but responded positively after being counseled by England coach Peter Moores. While his natural aggression and exuberance are valued qualities that capture the imagination, Stokes requires careful management to ensure his aggression remains controlled and productive in generating runs and wickets rather than becoming problematic. England is committed to playing both Stokes and Chris Jordan regularly to help them reach their full potential in international cricket.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams have 11 points from five games in Group B, with Belgium ranked fourth in the world holding top spot on goal difference. Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel last weekend has boosted expectations for qualifying for the 2016 finals in France, marking their best chance to qualify for a major tournament since 1958. The match sold out due to overwhelming demand following the impressive performance in Israel. UEFA rules prevented moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, and the Wales squad prefers the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium venue.

England coach John Peacock has named a 20-player squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The defending champions, who won last year by beating Holland on penalties, qualified with a 100 per cent record. They are placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, opening their campaign against Italy on May 7 in Burgas, with subsequent matches against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The squad includes talented young players from Premier League clubs, with first-time callups including Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal) and Chris Willock (Arsenal), while Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have earned recalls after missing the Elite Round qualifiers.

Manchester City are pursuing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, regarded as one of the club's best youth talents. The Belgian prospect has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously rejected Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his education. City manager Manuel Pellegrini is leading efforts to sign him, with the club negotiating a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London on March 28. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death. Santillan worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, and had recently moved to London from Mexico.

Dawn, a bereaved mother who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show to confront her housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, after discovering that £207 she had saved toward a £500 gravestone for her baby Daniel James had gone missing. When Jamie and his girlfriend Carol initially denied taking the money, a lie detector test revealed that Jamie was lying. The test also showed that Jamie had sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to taking the cash and blaming his girlfriend. Upon learning the truth, Dawn became devastated and angry, expressing her distress at being betrayed by someone she trusted, particularly given that the money was meant to honor her deceased child.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group in northern Iraq, on Wednesday. Most of those freed were women, children, the ill, and elderly. Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, though the exact motivation was unclear. The Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital. This follows previous ISIS releases of Yazidis since the group attacked their towns last summer. ISIS's conquest of northern Iraq displaced hundreds of thousands of minorities, including Yazidis, with particular devastation in Sinjar where many were killed, enslaved, or raped. An international coalition responded with airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes. Approximately 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, representing less than 1% of the country's population.

Harry Kane, Tottenham's striker, has had a remarkable season and is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. He has broken into Tottenham's first team and Roy Hodgson's England side. A new animation produced by Copa90 features Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his England debut goal. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of the PFA awards ceremony on Sunday, where Kane competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should remain Liverpool manager despite a third consecutive season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher argues that Rodgers' future shouldn't be determined by one season, noting that new players haven't fully settled in yet. He suggests that with proper squad improvements and signings, Liverpool can win a trophy and return to the top four next season. Carragher also received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in eight schools in deprived areas.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport security after it was detected on X-ray machines. His father, Phil, criticized the security staff as "over-zealous" and "ludicrous" for taking the toy from such a young child. East Midlands Airport defended the decision, stating that government security regulations prohibit items that resemble prohibited items, and the prohibited list includes replica or model guns. The airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to post the toy back to the family's home in Doncaster, South Yorkshire. After returning from their Easter holiday in Lanzarote, James was bought a replacement toy gun.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He offered accommodation, a potential company car, phone, and laptop to the successful candidate. Rich's requirements included a non-drinking, non-smoking, fit and attractive woman who is reliable, honest, loyal, good at cooking, skilled with her hands, and excellent in bed. She must enjoy the outdoors but also be "a princess when need to be." Rich described himself as athletic, tattooed, 175cm tall, drug-free, independent, and financially successful with his own properties. He stated he is generous with money, would consider all reasonable offers, and that former partners need not apply.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is pushing for radical changes to increase home-grown players in Premier League squads from eight to 12, with the definition of 'home-grown' changed to mean training in England for three years before age 18 rather than before 21. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—have backed his proposals in a letter, warning that blocking them risks England falling further behind other nations and makes winning the World Cup harder. They cite that only 36.8 percent of Premier League starters in recent matches were eligible for England selection, indicating a shrinking pool of English talent at the top level. Despite opposition from the Premier League, the former managers argue that young English talent like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane need the opportunity to play at the highest level.

Demelza Poldark gives birth to a daughter in tomorrow's episode of Poldark, with Ross Poldark shown gazing lovingly at his new baby. The passage highlights an unrealistic pregnancy timeline, where Demelza progresses from announcing her pregnancy to being eight months pregnant to giving birth within minutes of screen time. This compressed timeline mirrors a previous pregnancy storyline involving Elizabeth, prompting fans to joke on Twitter that pregnancies in Poldark occur within ten minutes.

Leicester City, managed by Nigel Pearson, are bottom of the Premier League but just three points from safety after consecutive wins, including a 3-2 victory at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Pearson has urged his players to focus on their own performances rather than monitor relegation rivals, emphasizing that Leicester's future is in their own hands and they must concentrate on their run-in games to give themselves a realistic chance of survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest migration of any mammal ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific Ocean to Baja, Mexico. This surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale that swam 10,190 miles. During her journey, Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, which surprised lead researcher Bruce Mate and suggests she may be an eastern gray whale rather than a western gray whale as previously thought. This discovery could indicate that the population of western gray whales, believed to number only 150, may actually be even lower, and researchers may need to reconsider the genetic differentiation between western and eastern gray whale species.

Approximately 1,000 feet of seabed emerged overnight on Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Hokkaido Island, Japan's east coast, rising 30-50 feet above sea level and measuring roughly 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. Geologists attribute the emergence to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow that displaced an underwater area to the surface. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds accompanying the event, and authorities do not expect further expansion. The phenomenon is unrelated to a recent earthquake in Nepal and is distinct from seismic activity.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied reports that he will leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, stating he is happy at the club and loves the city and his teammates. Despite a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel expressed his readiness to play whenever called upon and his desire to sign a new contract. However, PSG's reported interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves suggests Van der Wiel's future at the club may not be entirely in his control.

Carlos Tevez has requested to leave Juventus this summer to return to Boca Juniors in Argentina, despite his contract running until 2016. Boca Juniors president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to completing the deal but stressed that Tevez must first terminate his Juventus contract. The 31-year-old, who has scored 17 goals this season and is Juventus's top scorer, previously played for Boca Juniors from 1996 to 2005, scoring 26 league goals in 76 appearances. Although Juventus are reluctant to lose him, they have accepted his desire to leave and begun identifying replacements. Tevez has stated his intention to finish his career at Boca Juniors, his first club. His international manager Tata Martino indicated that a move to Boca would not negatively impact Tevez's Argentina career.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena in a Champions League quarter-final match, with Bayern leading 5-0 at half-time. Goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski, securing Bayern's place in the semi-finals despite Porto's 3-1 first-leg advantage. During the match, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola tore his left trouser leg, exposing his underwear, which he joked about after the game.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon. Three vehicles collided, resulting in two patients being airlifted by rescue helicopter to Princess Alexandra Hospital—a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain. A 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also airlifted. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped and freed using hydraulic cutting gear. The highway was closed with diversions in place south of Fernvale for several hours.

Arsenal's second-placed team will host table-topping Chelsea on Sunday at 4pm in a crucial Premier League match. Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil recently purchased an Apple Watch from an Apple store and shared the purchase on Instagram. Jack Wilshere has returned to Arsenal after five months out with injury and appeared on the bench during their FA Cup semi-final win over Reading. Arsenal trail Chelsea by 10 points with six league games remaining. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has the potential to be the future of Arsenal's midfield but expressed concern about his injury record, questioning whether he can maintain fitness for a full season.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford on Sunday. Despite accusations of favoring United in the past, Clattenburg has only sent off two Premier League players this season, both from United (Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw). Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany was sent off by Clattenburg during an international match and is suspended. United currently sits one point above City following City's shock 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace, making the derby crucial in the battle for second place behind Chelsea. United are in strong form with five consecutive league wins, while City have struggled since the turn of the year and dropped to fourth place. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official.

Bob Katter, a federal MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of treating Billy Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string," suggesting the government assumed Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and concealing his criminal history. Gordon, who was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party, announced he would remain in parliament as an independent. Katter questioned why Gordon was expected to resign when federal MPs in similar situations were not, and compared Gordon's situation to other independents who became government puppets. The statement sparked social media criticism over Katter's terminology, which he later defended by referencing his own dark complexion and personal experiences with racism from both major parties.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, creates dancing videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. Despite experiencing bullying and staring due to her condition, she aims to demonstrate that she can do the same things as her peers, though sometimes differently. Her motivation is to counteract the misconception that people with cerebral palsy cannot accomplish anything and should be treated differently. Dayna has produced multiple dancing videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and has begun motivational speaking at local schools. She emphasizes that doctors warned she might never walk, yet she now dances, drives, and attends college like other 19-year-olds.

Manchester United misfit Javier Hernandez is being pursued by MLS side Orlando City, who view him as a significant commercial draw for their Latin-American fanbase. The 26-year-old Mexican striker has struggled during a loan spell at Real Madrid and is available for around £8 million. Beyond Orlando, eight European clubs are interested, including Premier League sides Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, as well as Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Hernandez has one year remaining on his Manchester United contract. Additionally, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira after he rejected their initial offer, with Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord also expressing interest in the midfielder.

A gang of at least three people set a white Dodge Charger on fire at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday after an argument with the driver. The suspects poured gasoline on the car and ignited it while two passengers were inside. According to the driver's grandmother, the suspects attempted to carjack the vehicle and pulled a gun before pouring gasoline and lighting the fire. No one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, with surveillance video being used in the investigation. The suspects remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a southern Iowa chiropractor from Lamoni, surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting to his misdeeds and bartering sex for services with patients, and pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. The agreement requires him to prove the circumstances surrounding the license revocation no longer exist before he can resume practicing. Despite these violations, Manuel received perfect five-star patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com based on three patient survey responses.

A Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland on Tuesday. The U.S. crew deemed the Russian pilot's actions "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers performed in close proximity at high speed. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off, but U.S. officials denied this claim. The Pentagon and State Department plan to file a formal complaint through diplomatic channels. This incident follows a similar encounter a year prior when a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, which U.S. officials called "one of the most dangerous close passes in decades."

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot in March, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The thief broke the rear right passenger-side window of the agent's car at the Marriott Springhill Suites and used a rope tied to the rifle case's handle along with another vehicle to forcefully extract the secured rifle case. In addition to the sniper rifle, the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. Some items were recovered at a nearby Residence Inn, but the sniper rifle has not been found. The rifle's serial number was entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified before Obama's visit. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and police are uncertain whether the agent's car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times in Freebody's home in Canberra. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa was suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the incident, which compromised his mental state and understanding of his actions. Evidence of Costa's confused mental state includes fluctuating mood during emergency calls made during the incident and a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet. The prosecutor suggested Costa feigned memory loss, but Professor Mullen maintained that Costa likely suffered from dementia in the weeks, months, and possibly years leading up to the event. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended his team's penalty decision after Ross Barkley missed a 10th-minute penalty kick against Burnley at Goodison Park. Despite Leighton Baines' superior penalty record of 15 goals from 16 Premier League attempts, Barkley chose to take the spot kick awarded for a foul on Aaron Lennon. Goalkeeper Tom Heaton saved Barkley's well-struck effort. Martinez stated that players could request penalty duties based on how they felt in the moment, and praised Barkley for showing responsibility. The miss did not affect the result, as Kevin Mirallas scored the game's only goal in the 29th minute, securing Everton's 1-0 victory. This incident recalled a previous penalty controversy in January when Mirallas took a penalty from Baines against West Brom and missed.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam in Puerto Rico on Thursday at 11:30 a.m., appearing to have died in a murder-suicide. The ship, which departed Tampa, Florida on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, was docked in San Juan when the discovery was made. Cleaning staff found the deceased after knocking on the cabin door. Authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating, with the cruise line cooperating fully.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has made a successful start as coach of Curacao, leading the Caribbean team to advance to the second qualifying round of CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao defeated Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate, winning 2-1 in the first leg and drawing 2-2 in the second leg, with Charlton Vicento scoring the decisive goal in the 87th minute. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, an experienced midfielder with a decorated career including trophies at Inter Milan, Real Madrid, and River Plate, has joined Leicester City on a one-year deal. With Leicester currently seven points from safety at the bottom of the Premier League table with eight games remaining, Cambiasso views keeping the club up as equivalent to winning a trophy. Despite not winning since January, he remains confident the team can avoid relegation, stating they still have chances to win matches with a quarter of the season left. Cambiasso has settled well at the club and is happy in the East Midlands.

A 23-year-old woman named Gemma has two children under five whom she handed to her mother Debbie at four months old. Gemma's mother is threatening to ban her from seeing the children due to Gemma's drinking, drug use (MKat), partying, and suspected stealing. Debbie, who has raised both grandchildren since infancy after social services threatened intervention, claims Gemma is unemployed, unfit as a mother, and has stolen from the family including an iPad belonging to one of the children. Gemma admits to past theft but denies stealing the iPad. Debbie states Gemma has been problematic since age 13 and abandoned her parental responsibilities four months after each child's birth. The children call Debbie "mum" rather than "grandma," and Debbie says Gemma does not prioritize her children over her lifestyle.

Chelsea forward Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead against Manchester United at Stamford Bridge. The goal came after Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao near the halfway line, sending Falcao to the ground. Cesc Fabregas collected the loose ball, released it to Oscar, whose back-heel sent it to Hazard to score. Sky Sports pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp agreed during half-time analysis that Terry's challenge on Falcao was a foul that should have stopped play. Souness noted Terry used his elbow on Falcao's head, Henry said he would have wanted a foul in that position as a striker, and Redknapp acknowledged it was a foul despite Falcao potentially being stronger to stay on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 northeast of Dallas on Thursday morning. All passengers, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out and the bus stopped; it burst into flames once everyone had exited. The fire destroyed most of the bus's back lounge except for Scott's Bible. The band's other two members were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space lasers that convert sunlight into energy to power homes. Satellites covered in mirrors would harvest sunlight, convert it to laser light, and beam the energy back to Earth via semi-conductors to boost solar panels. Initial Scottish trials were successful, with plans to move to Portugal. This technology could make solar power viable in Scotland and restore power to disaster areas. Unlike science fiction depictions, these lasers would be far less powerful. The passage also describes a separate Tokyo research proposal to use lasers on the International Space Station to clear space debris by pushing it into Earth's atmosphere. Dr Quarterman acknowledged potential concerns about satellite control.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile, has escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, where he was detained under a hospital order following his conviction for sexual offences. He went missing on Tuesday at 6.15pm after last being seen leaving the hospital in Winchfield. Munden was convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and of ten unrelated offences involving indecent images of children. He is described as approximately 5ft 8ins tall with a heavy build and dark hair, and may have shaved off his beard. Police have launched a manhunt and are urging the public to report any sightings, as Munden suffers from learning difficulties and is considered a matter of urgency to locate.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts after Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling sued her. Shelly Sterling claimed that Donald Sterling used couple's money to purchase Stiviano luxury vehicles including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, and a Range Rover, as well as help her obtain a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano countered that there was nothing improper about receiving gifts from Sterling. The court's decision sets a precedent allowing injured spouses to recover damages from gift recipients. Donald Sterling's downfall began after an audio recording surfaced in which he made racist remarks to Stiviano, criticizing her for posting social media photos with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson. Following this incident, NBA Commissioner Adam Silver banned Sterling from the league, fined him $2.5 million, and terminated his ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer strategy and called for the club to sign four top players: a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker. Henry argues that Arsenal cannot win the Premier League title with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker, despite Giroud scoring 14 league goals this season. Henry points to Chelsea as an example of a team that strengthened in these areas by signing Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa, and is now positioned to win the league. He emphasizes that Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger must make these signings to create competitive strength within the squad necessary for winning the title.

Maurice Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman and Bega Cheese boss, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. One of his victims testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of abuse on her life. She stated she did not understand the abuse was wrong when it occurred as a child and kept it secret until learning of his arrest. Since coming forward, she has experienced depression, self-harm, attempted suicide, and hospitalization. She expressed fear about future relationships, concerns about Van Ryn's eventual release into the community, and worry that the abuse will permanently affect her ability to relate to men.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that has sidelined him since March 2014. After more than a year out, he is progressing well and feeling "better and better." Gnabry recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21 team against Reading, marking his second full match in a week. He impressed for Arsenal's first team before his injury and is now looking forward to returning to competitive action.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70 feet down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales. After a night out drinking in Cardiff, Phillips and two friends got out of a taxi without paying the fare, claiming they needed to use an ATM. When the taxi driver gave chase, Phillips ran into the darkness and leapt over a fence, falling down the cliff. His body was discovered the next morning on the rocky beach by a dog walker. The coroner ruled it an accidental death, noting that Phillips likely became disorientated and could not have seen the danger posed by the cliff in the darkness. Phillips was a university graduate who worked as an accountant for Pretty Green, a clothing label owned by Oasis star Liam Gallagher.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delays have received minimal compensation despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit during the crisis. Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April last year and January this year, totaling £203,066 with an average payout of £92.68. Meanwhile, passport office managers received bonuses up to £3,500. Ministers refused to provide blanket refunds to families who paid extra for rushed processing or missed trips entirely. Home Affairs Committee chairman Keith Vaz expressed astonishment at the low compensation rate given the scale of the fiasco and the agency's substantial profits.

A 1930s semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, has remained virtually unchanged for over 80 years and is being sold as a collector's item. The three-bedroom property retains original features including stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, a mint green and black bathroom with original tiles and fixtures, wood-panelled hallway, original kitchen cupboards, brick fireplace, and vintage food tins on display. The house is double-glazed but otherwise preserves its period aesthetic. With a guide price of £200,000-£250,000, auctioneers believe the potential renovation costs may deter developers, though it could appeal to antique enthusiasts. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith with the 49ers. He became the starter midway through the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. Kaepernick led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and distributed by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey that connects the New Jersey Turnpike at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, specifically NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. Blur's debut album Leisure was released in 1991 to mixed reviews, and their self-titled album in 2001 achieved worldwide success, drawing from alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop influences. Albarn's debut solo album Everyday Robots was released on 28 April 2014, co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, along with samples of Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, known locally as Hamar. As the capital, it hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails, an American industrial rock band, from their 1992 debut EP titled Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter born on August 14, 1964, who has received a BAFTA nomination.

The passage describes two adaptations of "Shooter": a 2007 film starring Mark Wahlberg as Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit, and a TV series starring Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman in exile who is drawn back into action after discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House is an American television medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for seven deaths, including actress Sharon Tate, as well as additional first-degree murder convictions for two other victims. The murders were carried out by members of his group at his instruction. Following his charges, commercial recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released.

Sean Justin Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. He began his acting career in television on Little House on the Prairie in 1974, followed by his film debut in Taps (1981). Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, Penn appeared in notable crime dramas including At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). He gained prominence with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two additional Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and his second in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (1908-2001) was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring from playing, he maintained a prominent role in cricket for thirty years as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid is an executive who has held several prominent positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He began his drumming career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he performs with Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015, spanning 34 episodes across two seasons. CBS cancelled the show on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards was an American Democratic politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She first gained national attention as Texas state treasurer when she delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and wit. She was defeated in her 1994 re-election bid by George W. Bush. She lived from September 1, 1933 to September 13, 2006.
Drake Bell released an independent EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer and author born July 6, 1927 and died October 3, 2004, wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar (1783-1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent sovereign states free from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean known for mysterious disappearances of aircraft and ships.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith with the 49ers. He became the starter mid-2012 season after Smith's concussion and led the team to Super Bowl XLVII, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. During his first full season as starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a sponsored, nonpersonal marketing communication that promotes products, services, or ideas through mass media. It differs from personal selling because the message is not directed at specific individuals. Advertising is delivered via traditional media like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and outdoor advertising, as well as modern media including search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts written by Noël Coward. An American Pre-Code film adaptation was released in 1931, directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957 to October 19, 1963. He lived from February 10, 1894 to December 29, 1986.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira in 384 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at seventeen or eighteen years old and stayed until age thirty-seven around 347 BC. After Plato's death, he left Athens and began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor and entrepreneur born on February 16, 1982. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and currently serves as CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons after being drafted first overall in 1979. He won a championship and NBA Finals MVP in his rookie season, followed by four more championships during the 1980s. After retiring due to player protests, he returned in 1996 at age 36 to play 32 games before retiring permanently. Johnson later became recognized as one of America's most influential black businessmen and served as a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black (lead vocalist and guitarist) and Kyle Gass (lead guitarist and vocalist). The band released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). They gained popularity in 1997 through their eponymous television series and by supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I (1566-1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death, ruling both kingdoms in personal union while they remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciaries, and laws. He advocated for a single parliament uniting England and Scotland, achieving most of his aims in Scotland but facing significant difficulties in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and repeated conflicts with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017 (Series 18) is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality television show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born on October 4, 1967, best known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since its start in 2000. He previously worked for Channel 4 until July 2011, when he moved to Channel 5 to continue narrating the revived Big Brother. His distinctive Geordie-accented voice-over work has made him one of Britain's most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is Germany's tenth largest state by area (18,413 km²) and sixth most populous with 4 million people.
