Located in the middle of a formerly German-speaking region of Europe, Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium. The region is also known as a quality wine area in Germany and, together with Saale-Unstrut, represents one of Europe's northernmost wine regions and the only two of Germany's 13 wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood. "In the End" is a song by American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown launched her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back," a collaboration with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in lead roles. Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Raveena Tandon replaced Divya Bharti in the female lead role following Bharti's death. The film is notable for its chartbuster songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor born on December 16, 1961. He is known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and making his directorial debut with Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill is the 1985 James Bond film that serves as the fourteenth installment in the spy film series and the seventh and final film starring Roger Moore in the role of MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, covering most of western New Guinea. It was previously named Irian Jaya, and before that West Irian or Irian Barat, when it encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died from natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggested his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez launched her music career in 1999 with her debut album "On the 6" and the number-one single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she made history by becoming the first woman to have a number-one album and film simultaneously with "J.Lo" and "The Wedding Planner." Her third album "This Is Me... Then" (2002) was influenced by her high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck. After marrying Marc Anthony, she appeared in successful films like "Shall We Dance?" She gave birth to twins in 2008 and returned to prominence in 2011 as a judge on "American Idol" and with her commercially successful single "On the Floor," one of the best-selling singles of all time.

Working animals are domesticated animals trained by humans to perform tasks. They serve various purposes including assistance roles like guide dogs, providing tractive force such as draft horses or logging elephants, and performing jobs like milking or herding. While wild animals can occasionally be tamed and trained for work, they typically lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament of truly domesticated working animals and are often trained for novelty or entertainment rather than practical purposes.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Top Latin Albums is a Billboard magazine record chart recognized as the most important music chart for Spanish language, full-length albums in the American music market. Regional Mexican Albums is a genre-specific record chart published weekly by Billboard magazine in the United States.

Vedam is a 2010 Telugu language Indian drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. The film stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring an ensemble cast including Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn. The film is stylized as MIIB.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character from Miguel de Cervantes' 1605 novel Don Quixote. He serves as Don Quixote's squire and is known for his commentary throughout the novel, called "sanchismos," which blend humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
Henrik Ibsen's play "Hedda Gabler" had its world premiere on January 31, 1891, at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company headquartered in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director born on May 14, 1961.

Juventus is a professional Italian football club based in Turin, founded in 1897 by young Torinese students including first president Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico. It is the second oldest active football club in Italy after Genoa's football section (1893). The club has traditionally worn black and white striped home kits since 1903 and currently plays at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis appeared in supporting and minor roles in films and television during the late 1990s and early 2000s. Her film appearances included Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), and she also appeared in the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson is an American entrepreneur and webcam model born on April 9, 1974. She is a former pornographic film actress known as "The Queen of Porn" and has been called the world's most famous adult entertainment performer. She began acting in erotic videos in 1993, following her work as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are an NBA team that competes in the Western Conference's Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view. It was produced by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW). The event continued a tradition established by JCP from the 1960s-1980s of holding major wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas, primarily at Greensboro Coliseum. Specific editions included the third annual event in 1985, the fifth annual in 1987, and the fifteenth annual pay-per-view event in 1997.

Jack Ryan Falahee is an American actor born on February 20, 1989. He is best known for his role as Connor Walsh on the ABC legal drama "How to Get Away with Murder" and for playing Benjamin Stringfellow on the PBS historical drama "Mercy Street."

Do n't Say No is the debut extended play by South Korean singer Seohyun (Seo Ju-hyun, born June 28, 1991). Seohyun debuted as a member of Girls' Generation in August 2007, which became one of South Korea's best-selling and most popular girl groups worldwide. Beyond her group activities, she has established herself as an actress in stage musicals including Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia. She released her solo debut mini album, Do n't Say No, on January 17, 2017, becoming the third Girls' Generation member to debut as a solo artist.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer designed primarily by Steve Wozniak, with Steve Jobs overseeing the plastic case development and Rod Holt developing the switching power supply. It was one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products, introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Steve Wozniak, born August 11, 1950, is an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur who co-founded Apple Inc.

A&E, formerly known as Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel and the flagship property of A&E Networks. A&E Networks is a joint venture between the Hearst Corporation and Disney's ABC Television Group, with each maintaining 50% ownership.

L.A. Reid is an executive who has held several prominent positions in the music industry. He served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group. Additionally, he founded and served as CEO of Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.

Veeram is a Tamil film title used for two different productions: a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 Indian epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

"Home for the Holidays" refers to two films: a 1972 made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972; and a 1995 film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam is an American actor, comedian, and writer born on April 1, 1982.
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster featuring eight men and eight women competing to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer born on July 15, 1973.
Island Records is a British-American record label operating as a division of Universal Music Group.
Sikkim is a northeastern state located in India.
Christa McAuliffe was a social studies teacher who took a position at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ronald Bilius "Ron" Weasley is a fictional character created by J.K. Rowling for her Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder and produced by his brother Jack Binder. Columbia Pictures distributed the film, which was released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick is an American football quarterback born on November 3, 1987, who is currently a free agent.

Sheryl Lee appeared in the 2016 film Café Society and reprised her role as Laura Palmer in the 2017 Showtime revival of Twin Peaks. Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in Wicked on Broadway in 2016.
Matteo Renzi is an Italian politician born on January 11, 1975, who served as Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 to December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado is a film featuring an ensemble cast including Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

"Same Old Love" is a song by Selena Gomez from her second studio album, Revival (2015). The album debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, and "Same Old Love" was one of the first three singles released, all of which topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a rock music genre that emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s, primarily in the United Kingdom and the United States. Beginning in the late 1970s, the new wave of British heavy metal introduced bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon that continued in this musical tradition.
Ashton Kutcher appeared in several romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman is a men's clothing retailer that is part of the Arcadia Group, alongside Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins. The chain operates high-street stores throughout the United Kingdom and has a widespread presence on most UK High Streets, as well as outlets in six cities and towns in Ireland.

Wales underwent significant transformation during the Industrial Revolution through the development of mining and metallurgical industries, which shifted the country from an agricultural economy to an industrial one. The exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield drove rapid population growth throughout Wales.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy Awards, performed worldwide tours, and produced albums that topped charts in several countries.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website based in San Bruno, California, and ranks as the second most popular site globally according to Alexa Internet's web traffic analysis.
Sidse Babett Knudsen is a Danish actress born on November 22, 1968, who works in theatre, television, and film.

Conrad Dunn began his screen career in Stripes (1981), playing the role of Francis "Psycho" Soyer. The film featured several actors, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, in their first significant film roles.
Raees is a film starring Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label established in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix, produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide was the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, primarily Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and Turkey. The Ottoman government also targeted other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups, including Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, in what some historians consider part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born on October 4, 1967.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19, 1946, is an American politician who served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, at the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director born on October 20, 1956. He is known for directing films such as Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours, and Steve Jobs. The Beach, released in 2000, is an adventure drama film he directed based on Alex Garland's 1996 novel of the same name, with the screenplay adapted by John Hodge.
A viral image of a dress generated over 10 million tweets in its first week, with users debating its colors using hashtags #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand MC and bar was a British Army officer born on 22 January 1917 and died on 11 June 2006. He held the military decoration of MC and bar.
Advertising is a sponsored, nonpersonal marketing communication in audio or visual form used to promote or sell products, services, or ideas.

The Others (2001) won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director, making it the first English-language film to win Best Film at Spain's national film awards despite containing no Spanish dialogue. The film received six Saturn Award nominations, including Best Director and Best Writing for Amenábar and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann, and won three awards: Best Horror Film, Best Actress for Nicole Kidman, and Best Supporting Actress for Fionnula Flanagan.

Ralph Fults was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist who lived from January 23, 1911 to March 16, 1993. He was associated with notable criminals including Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang.

The 14th Dalai Lama, born Lhamo Thondup on July 6, 1935, in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet, is the current Dalai Lama with the religious name Tenzin Gyatso. He was selected as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and formally recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama in 1939. During the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India, where he currently lives as a refugee.

Miracle at St. Anna is a World War II film set in German-occupied Italy that follows four Buffalo Soldiers from the 92nd Infantry Division who take refuge in a small Tuscan village and bond with its residents. The narrative is structured as a flashback, with a survivor recounting these experiences in a frame story set in 1980s New York.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who was born on November 27, 1957. She served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

"Home for the Holidays" is a 1995 film featuring an ensemble cast including Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before relocating to Texas and subsequently to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg was born in Lawton, Oklahoma and raised in Anaheim, California. As a child, he developed a fascination with the ocean and an interest in art.

A mendicant way of life is practiced by various religious orders across multiple faiths, including Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, Sufi dervishes, and monastic orders of Jainism and Buddhism. A monk is a person who practices religious asceticism through monastic living, either solitary or communal. Monks dedicate their lives to serving others or choose to withdraw from mainstream society to live in prayer and contemplation.
The Mod Squad is an American crime drama series that aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American science fantasy western action horror film directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona is a state in the southwestern United States, ranking sixth largest and 14th most populous among the 50 states. It became the 48th state and last contiguous state admitted to the Union on February 14, 1912. Approximately one-quarter of Arizona consists of Indian reservations home to 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation—the largest tribe in both the state and the United States with over 300,000 citizens. Arizona is notably known for its significant Native American population.
Smriti Mandhana is an Indian cricketer born on July 18, 1996, who plays for the Indian women's cricket team.

Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson is a French-British actress, model, and activist born on April 15, 1990, in Paris. She was raised in Oxfordshire and attended the Dragon School, where she trained as an actress at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett began her film career in the mid-1980s following her graduation from Yale University with a bachelor of arts degree and completion of a master of fine arts degree from drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is NASA's highest award, presented by the President of the United States on behalf of Congress based on recommendations from the NASA Administrator. Recipients must perform extraordinary feats of accomplishment during NASA-authorized space flights. Frank Frederick Borman II, born March 14, 1928, a retired Air Force Colonel, is mentioned as a recipient of this honor.
The Saw franchise generated over $873 million in worldwide box office revenue across all its films.
Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for playing Joe Wicks in BBC's EastEnders and DS Sam Casey in ITV's Law & Order: UK.
Colombiana is a 2011 French action film that was co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was a main cast member of the Netflix original series Marco Polo, which was cancelled on December 12, 2016.

Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Boyhood is a film shot over 11 years (2002-2013) that follows Mason Evans Jr. from age six to eighteen as he grows up in Texas with his divorced parents, played by Arquette and Hawke.
Hush is a 2016 film produced by Trevor Macy through Intrepid Pictures and Jason Blum through Blumhouse Productions.
The Penibaetic System is the southernmost mountain range system within the Baetic System, located in southern Iberian Peninsula. It is one of three systems that comprise the Baetic System.

Bonobos is an apparel company offering a comprehensive range of men's clothing including suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories. Topman, part of the Arcadia Group (which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins), operates a chain of men's clothing stores throughout the United Kingdom and Ireland, with a presence on most UK High Streets and outlets in six Irish cities and towns.
"Roar" is a song by Katy Perry from her fourth studio album, Prism, released in 2013. It was released as the lead single on August 10, 2013.
The Saturn Corporation, registered as Saturn LLC, is a trademark established on January 7, 1985, as a General Motors subsidiary.

The Armenian Genocide was the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, primarily Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and Turkey. The mass killings began in 1915 under Ottoman rule. Turkey, the successor state to the Ottoman Empire, denies that the term "genocide" accurately describes these events.

Muslims believe the Quran was verbally revealed by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel over approximately 23 years, beginning on December 22, 609 CE when Muhammad was 40 years old, and ending in 632 CE, the year of Muhammad's death.

The human brain, along with the spinal cord, comprises the central nervous system and consists of three main parts: the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum. The cerebrum is the largest component and contains the cerebral cortex, beneath which lie several important structures including the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic structures (amygdala and hippocampus), claustrum, basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy drama film set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network that broadcasts a diverse range of programming including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to shows, hunting and fishing content, and children's shows.

Sir Donald Bradman (1908-2001), known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. Despite becoming reclusive in his later years, his opinions remained highly valued and his status as a national icon persisted over 50 years after his retirement from Test cricket. In 2001, Australian Prime Minister John Howard referred to him as the "greatest living Australian."

Margaret Hilda Thatcher was a British stateswoman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. She was the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century and the first woman to hold the office. In 1975, she defeated Heath in the Conservative Party leadership election to become Leader of the Opposition, making her the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom.

Randy Mario Poffo, known professionally as "Macho Man" Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator born November 15, 1952, and died May 20, 2011. He was best known for his work in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) and World Championship Wrestling (WCW).
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor with a career spanning over five decades.
EA Black Box was a video game developer founded in 1998 in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada by former Radical Entertainment employees. The company was later acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

Baiae was an ancient mineral springs and coastal resort on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples in Italy. Herculaneum was an ancient Roman town located in the shadow of Mount Vesuvius that was destroyed by volcanic pyroclastic flows in 79 AD, with its ruins now located in Ercolano, Campania, Italy. The area near Naples contains numerous culturally and historically significant sites, including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum. Famous ruins exist worldwide, spanning ancient sites in China, the Indus valley, Judea, Zimbabwe, the Mediterranean basin, and the Americas.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama set in 1980 West Texas that stars Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin. The film follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran through the desert landscape. Tommy Lee Jones plays Sheriff Ed Tom Bell in the film, which is one of his many notable roles across various films and television series.

Palo Alto is a charter city in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, located in the San Francisco Bay Area. Its name comes from Spanish words meaning "tall tree" (palo meaning "stick" or "tree," and alto meaning "tall").

Albert Lawrence Brooks is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian born on July 22, 1947. Finding Dory is a film directed by Andrew Stanton with co-direction by Angus MacLane, with a screenplay written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code is a method of transmitting text as on-off tones, lights, or clicks that skilled listeners can understand without special equipment. The code was designed so that character length varies inversely with frequency of occurrence in English, increasing communication speed. Morse code is less sensitive to poor signal conditions than voice communication and remains comprehensible without a decoding device. It is commonly used by amateur radio repeaters and can be sent through improvised methods in emergencies, making it a simple and versatile telecommunication method.
Alexandra Anna Daddario is an American actress born on March 16, 1986.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12 at 21:47 UTC with a magnitude of 6.5. The Hindu Kush is an 800 km mountain range stretching along the Afghan-Pakistan border from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan, featuring numerous high snow-capped peaks. The highest point in the range is Tirich Mir at 7,708 meters, located in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan.
Ripon College in Wisconsin had approximately 840 students as of 2015, with the majority residing on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand encompassing sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and media worldwide controlled or partially owned by Rupert Murdoch's family. Rupert Murdoch served as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate, which split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013. Murdoch and his family own both successor companies through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is a US-based women's apparel company that specializes in tomboyish-style clothing.
Bessie Smith was an American blues singer who lived from April 15, 1894 to September 26, 1937.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies to enable computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It combines knowledge and research from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.

Aleister Crowley (1875-1947) was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer. Born Edward Alexander Crowley, he pursued multiple creative and esoteric disciplines throughout his life.
Poldark is a British-American drama television series that premiered on BBC One on March 8, 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge is a film released on 20 October 1995, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol. It was shot in India, London, and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director born on May 14, 1961. Tim Roth is a Canadian guitarist and backing vocalist, born December 6, 1975, and the only remaining founding member of the melodic death metal and progressive metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986 and had three children together.

Sean Penn is an acclaimed actor who has won two Academy Awards for Best Actor in Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008). His career began with his 1981 film debut in Taps, followed by notable roles in 1980s films like Fast Times at Ridgemont High. He gained critical recognition for crime dramas including At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way. Penn achieved prominence as a leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Oscar nomination and the Berlin Film Festival's Best Actor Award. He received two additional Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001). His directorial effort, Into the Wild (2007), was critically acclaimed and received two Academy Award nominations.

Earth's history began with volcanic outgassing creating a primordial, oxygen-free atmosphere and ocean that would be toxic to modern life. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed and liquid water accumulated on the surface. Plate tectonics continues to shape Earth's oceans, continents, and living species. Human activity now dominates the biosphere and significantly affects Earth's systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gas levels, and soil, air, and water quality. Water covers 71% of Earth's surface.
Nuuk is the capital and largest city of Greenland and is part of the municipality of Sermersooq.

Both sides suspended plans to coordinate air strikes against jihadist groups in Geneva, though they agreed to continue counter-terrorism discussions to prevent unnecessary clashes.

Policy Exchange's report proposes selling high-value social homes when they become vacant to raise £4.5bn annually, which could fund 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes and create the largest social house building programme since the 1970s. The think tank argues this would reduce the social housing waiting list by approximately 500,000 people. However, Labour opposes the plan, arguing it would displace low-wage families from expensive neighbourhoods and break up mixed communities. Critics warn the policy could create segregated communities and push out lower-income families from affluent areas. The government supports councils exploring this option as part of efforts to address the housing crisis, while Labour advocates instead for using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea during a measles epidemic that has reached 942 cases. Laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, but the examination could not establish whether it was the main cause of death, and an inquest will be opened on Tuesday for further investigation. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and developed a rash a few days after discharge. He visited an out-of-hours GP on 17 April with a widespread rash and was found dead the following morning. His family is unclear how he contracted measles, as no close family members had it, and his three-year-old daughter has been vaccinated.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical sexual offence against a boy under 16. The alleged attack occurred in 2001 and was reported to Cumbria Police. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin's Gateshead, unbeaten in nine National League matches, faced Adam Lockwood's Guiseley, unbeaten in five. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored from a James Hurst throw-in. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute when Wesley York scored after Derek Asamoah's slip. The match ended 1-1.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at its football club to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale that has been delayed by a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed work will begin following approval from Bristol City Council in November. The club must wait six weeks for a judicial review period after signing the section 106 agreement, with redevelopment work scheduled to start in May if no judicial review is filed by March.

Cuadrilla has suspended shale gas drilling operations in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake, the second tremor in two months. The company will analyze data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume. The April 1st tremor shared similar characteristics to the latest quake. Fracking involves injecting pressurized water into rocks to release shale gas, a process that can cause earthquakes. The BGS confirmed that both earthquakes occurred approximately 2km from the Preese Hall drilling site and shared similar mechanisms. While the process remains controversial due to environmental concerns in the US, the UK Commons energy select committee has called for government support, arguing that risks can be managed through regulation and industry practice.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud at Liverpool Crown Court. The conviction relates to April 2015 when he played bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner, giving the impression he was collecting money for the charity. He was acquitted of two other fraud counts. Carpenter claimed he was busking and that the banner was a tribute to victims, not an attempt to deceive. The Hillsborough Justice Campaign chairman confirmed he gave permission for the banner but stated Carpenter was not authorized to collect funds using it. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 in a Championship match. Grant Ward opened the scoring with a scuffed shot, Luke Varney added a second goal after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance, and Tom Lawrence completed the scoring with a calm finish. Despite having opportunities to score more, Ipswich's defense held firm while Rangers offered little in attack. The victory moved Ipswich up to 14th place, above Rangers who dropped to 15th. Manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance, while QPR boss Ian Holloway acknowledged the defensive lapses, particularly the second goal, and called for his team to be mentally tougher.

Wells, a 23-year-old player, performed well in the T20 Blast last season with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club's direction, praising the coaches for creating an elite performance environment that motivates the players.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for their second consecutive win. Coach Churcher praised the front row and front five players—Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams—for their defensive effort, with over 70 tackles made during the game. In their next eight matches, the Reds will face seven teams ranked below them and league leaders Old Elthamians. While acknowledging the win was emotionally strong and dogged, Churcher noted the performance wasn't complete and emphasized the need to build on this momentum to avoid wasting the progress made.

A 28-year-old Bangladeshi man named Nazrul was arrested at a Kolkata railway station for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent in Ranaghat town on March 14. The incident sparked outrage and protests across India. Police identified eight suspects in the attack, with six now arrested and two still untraced. The five previously arrested suspects identified Nazrul as the rapist. Police apprehended him based on a tip that he had fled to Bangladesh after being identified in CCTV footage and was returning to Kolkata by train. During the attack, money was stolen from the convent school, the building was ransacked, and the nun was raped inside the convent. Milon Sarkar, arrested in May, was described as the gang leader, though his specific role remains unclear.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains the main reasons consumers change their purchasing habits. Key factors include the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports, all of which influenced the types of products available and popular among UK consumers. The video also examines how ownership and rankings of major UK brands are evolving over time.

Two women were defrauded by scammers posing as BT technical support. A 71-year-old from Sandyhills was tricked on 15 September, followed by a woman in Stranraer seven days later. The scammer in the Stranraer case gained remote access to the victim's computer and stole money. Police warn that these fraudsters easily obtain computer access and steal substantial sums. PC Siobhan Pellett advises people to be cautious of cold calls requesting remote computer access and emphasizes never to provide banking details or account numbers over the phone, as legitimate banks and businesses never request such information.

Duffy, 37, has joined third-placed Championship side Featherstone Rovers on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. The Scotland assistant coach will lead the team in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy as a fantastic coach, noting his remarkable work at Swinton under difficult circumstances. Duffy, a former player for Leigh, Widnes and Salford with a 16-year playing career, has been replaced at Swinton by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. A rider with head injuries who had been lying unconscious on wet sand was treated for hypothermia and flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system using satellites. This decision aims to improve upon the current ground-based radar system, which leaves approximately 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The new system will enable satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, allowing real-time tracking of planes worldwide. This development was prompted by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014, which exposed weaknesses in global air navigation systems. The International Civil Aviation Organisation has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines that will require aircraft to transmit their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez disappeared at age five in August 2002 when his father, Bobby Hernandez, took him to pre-school and fled. Now 18, Julian was discovered living with his father in Cleveland after encountering problems applying for college. The FBI received a tip on October 30 and confirmed his identity with help from Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Bobby Hernandez, 53, has been arrested and is being held at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on a $250,000 bail. He is also charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery.

A fire occurred on 2 March at a waste facility on Duncan Street operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (run by Asset and Land Group), reducing train services and causing travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended the company from accepting waste following the blaze. Although the fire service found the site "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the GMFRS had raised concerns to the EA in February about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment. Following joint visits by fire safety officers and EA staff, the EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, after which the company cannot operate from that site, though it must still remove all waste. The company has until 7 August to appeal. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills linked to the Ukraine crisis. The first bill would allow Russian territories to accept parts of neighboring states if their leaders request it or hold a referendum, bypassing the current requirement for a treaty. The second bill would expedite Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians by eliminating fees, residence requirements, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship, with applications accepted until August 1 and citizenship granted within two months instead of one year. The bills reference the situation in Crimea, where separatist sentiment is strong and many residents already hold Russian passports. The proposals follow Russia's 2008 war with Georgia, after which breakaway territories came under Moscow's control.

McLaren, a legendary F1 team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently in decline. The slump began in 2013 with chassis design problems, and now involves issues with the Honda power unit despite improvements to the car itself. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998. McLaren has experienced multiple scandals, including a 2007 disqualification from the championship and a 2009 "lie-gate" incident. The team's history shows cycles of triumph and decline since its establishment by Bruce McLaren. Ron Dennis, who built the team to dominance in the 1980s-90s, returned to control after the disastrous 2013 season. Despite current struggles, Dennis believes McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win future championships. The team features two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, who returned in 2015 hoping to secure a third title. Currently, McLaren can only realistically aim for fourth grid position and decent points, relying on belief that progress will lead to future success.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January and died in hospital. He had just left Phoenix Gym when he was shot while getting into his car. Three Liverpool men aged 29, 29, and 32 have been arrested and remain in custody. Police believe the shooters waited outside the gym for about an hour. Detectives are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and are appealing for CCTV witnesses near the meat market to come forward.

The passage describes five ways to enjoy Christmas online while maintaining spiritual engagement:

1. **Everyday Church Online** - Virtual Sunday services with a global congregation from 61 countries, featuring a chat room and streamed sermons. Their Christmas theme focuses on Star Wars with sermons titled "The Hope Awakens."

2. **Guardians of Ancora** - A free fantasy game for ages 8-11 where players rediscover Bible stories to restore light to a fictional world. Christmas content includes Bible-themed quests about Jesus's birth.

3. **Nativity Videos** - "The Digital Story of Nativity" (nearly 6 million views) tells the nativity through social media updates and tweets. The Churches Advertising Network's "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" (250,000 views) depicts a modern couple transforming into Mary and Joseph.

4. **Manga Messiah** - Next Manga distributes Bible stories in Japanese manga format across multiple languages and platforms. The nativity version is available in 33 languages, with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees.

5. **Social Media Engagement** - Christian groups use Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to share spiritual messages and connect with communities, with church leaders suggesting these platforms effectively communicate Gospel messages and encourage spiritual reflection.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to develop 250 hectares of common land for a circuit. Backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, are offering 320 hectares of replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting expert testimony regarding potential damage to habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales expressed difficulty concluding the replacement land is of equal value but is not opposing the development. Developers' ecology report claims a "net gain" in biodiversity through habitat enhancement plans nearby, which the Gwent wildlife trust disputes. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation following the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers making the final decision.

On 1 April, Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, stating detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings. On 3 April, Chechen Muslim clerics met and adopted a resolution condemning the report as insulting to their faith, with their spiritual leader Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev stating "there will be retribution." Novaya Gazeta characterized this as a call for reprisals against journalists and urged Russian authorities to prevent incitement against them. Authoritarian leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya. The paper's chief editor Dmitry Muratov defended the journalists' work in an open letter, pledging to continue investigating human rights abuses. The LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution and threatens to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute those responsible.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, work together to house single homeless men over 35 by claiming housing benefit. While operating legally, the arrangement has drawn criticism for prioritizing profit over tenant welfare. Investing Solutions receives significantly more in housing benefit than it pays to landlords—for example, claiming £2,114 monthly while paying landlords £1,150, generating substantial profits. The company is one of the UK's largest housing benefit recipients, with Wandsworth Council alone paying over £2.1m in the past two years. A former tenant reported unsuitable living conditions including lack of heating, rats, and damp. Both organizations are based in the same south London building and were founded by Samir Patel. Fresh Start Housing stated it has housed 788 homeless people since its founding, though it declined to specify how many were housed through Investing Solutions.

London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 points in a warm-up match coached by Joe Prunty. Great Britain led for most of the first three quarters but lost to the Netherlands in the final 10 minutes. The Dutch were led by Worthy De Jong with 18 points and scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to secure a 71-60 lead before winning despite GB's late comeback. Coach Prunty emphasized the importance of consistent effort in their upcoming Eurobasket qualifying campaign, which begins with a game in Hungary. He praised Gordon's performance, particularly his three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter.

A former five-weight world champion submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission on Wednesday to use 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves required for 154lb fights. The NAC will debate the matter publicly on 16 August before deciding. Lighter gloves offer less cushioning but theoretically deliver more punishing punches. The undefeated fighter coming out of retirement had previously posted on Instagram about wearing 8oz gloves but had not initially submitted the required waiver document. NAC rules allow 8oz gloves for bouts between 135lbs and 147lbs if waivers are signed and justified. The NAC executive director emphasized that fighter health and safety is the priority when deviating from regulations. The 29-year-old UFC lightweight champion is making his boxing debut against a 40-year-old opponent in what could be the richest fight in history. The NAC director studied extensive information before approving the fight, citing the fighter's younger age, height, reach advantage, and a granite-like chin, along with observations that the opponent hasn't knocked anyone out in 10 years. A Hall of Fame boxing referee was hired to oversee the bout.

The Sunday Post's London office, located on historic Fleet Street, is closing on Friday, marking the departure of its last two journalists—Darryl Smith and Gavin Sherriff, who worked there for 25 and 32 years respectively. Fleet Street was once the center of British journalism, home to major national newspapers and the birthplace of the first British daily newspaper in 1702. At its peak, the street was famous for its bars filled with journalists and represented a pinnacle of the profession. However, the decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping, followed by most other national newspapers relocating by 1988 due to new computerized printing technology. The buildings were subsequently converted to other uses, such as Sainsbury's supermarket replacing Mirror Group Newspapers. The closure of the Sunday Post's office represents the end of an era for Fleet Street journalism.

J.K. Rowling received both supportive and abusive comments on Twitter, which she addressed by stating there are more decent people than not in the world. She previously faced criticism for donating £1m to Scotland's No campaign in the independence referendum and the same amount to Labour in 2008. Rowling blocked abusive Twitter users she believed were SNP supporters, stating she would not silence such behavior to protect any political party's image. However, she also noted having positive interactions with SNP supporters who shared her political views. She responded humorously to a suggestion that her books be burned. The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in a recent election and became the UK's third largest party.

The University of Edinburgh's Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime tracked 4,300 young people since 1998 and found that poverty significantly increases crime risk. Children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action for the same crimes as better-off children, and five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Poverty was identified as an exacerbating factor for offending even when other risk factors were controlled for. Boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as affluent girls to be involved in violent crime. A history of police contact was the strongest predictor of youth unemployment or underemployment by age 18. A separate study by the AQMeN Research Centre found that despite Scotland's crime rates being at a 41-year low, crime remains concentrated in deprived communities, with half of high-crime communities in the top 20% of areas with chronic health problems and a third in the top 20% of areas with highest unemployment. Prof McAra noted that contact with the juvenile justice system inadvertently reproduces conditions in which violence flourishes.

Mr Haugh, 25, was stabbed in the Marian estate in Kilkee in the early hours of Sunday and died at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Robbie Walsh, 25, was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody. According to detective evidence, Walsh was one of three people who entered the estate looking for Mr Haugh shortly after 01:00. A fight ensued involving weapons, during which Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Two other men arrested were released without charge with files prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. Knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene.

Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA, tweeted in May 2014 accusing Tom Elliott (now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone) of harassing and shooting people during his 10 years of UDR service between 1982 and 1992. The High Court ruled the tweet was untrue and without foundation. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and was ordered to post a public apology on Twitter by the end of Friday. Mr Justice Stevens reserved judgment on compensation amounts. Flanagan's insurance firm refused to cover compensation and costs, which he is challenging in a separate court action. Elliott stated he was vindicated and expressed disappointment that the matter took 19 months to resolve.

Hawick Knitwear, a company dating back to 1874 with over 230 employees, has increased weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 units to meet rising demand. The company, purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November, launched a new Hawick Knitwear-branded range in January that exceeded sales expectations. Growth has come from both the new brand and the established private label business. The firm operates across multiple European markets including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as international markets in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady of 20 years, suffered serious head injuries when struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside a school in Kempston in December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, though he accepts striking her. The prosecution states Wright's vehicle failed to stop at a red light while traffic in the other direction had stopped, and he hit Blackburn as she was escorting a woman and child across the road. Wright expressed remorse in court, acknowledging the impact on his victim and her family. Blackburn is now in residential care, and the trial is ongoing.

This passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose" involving 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, searching for the German U-boat U33. The exercise is a response to increased Russian submarine patrols in European waters. Russia operates approximately 60 submarines, including advanced nuclear-powered and diesel-electric vessels, and has recently launched what it claims is the world's quietest submarine. The exercise highlights a significant gap in British defenses: the UK lacks maritime patrol aircraft, a capability previously provided by the Nimrod, forcing Britain to rely on NATO allies for surveillance of Russian submarines near its waters. The exercise employs various detection methods including sonar, sensors, helicopters, and for the first time, underwater unmanned drones. Experts warn that Russia's advanced submarine technology and skilled crews make them highly challenging adversaries capable of remaining undetected for months, and that Britain's lack of maritime patrol aircraft represents a key vulnerability that must be addressed.

Since July 2016, violence in South Sudan has spread from Juba to southern Equatoria, causing 340,000 people to flee to Uganda—more refugees than from any other country that year. An average of 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees daily, with accounts describing killing, rape, and ethnic targeting of civilians. The conflict, which began as a dispute between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former Vice-President Riek Machar, has expanded to target Equatorians since rebel troops fled the capital. Refugees report systematic violence including murder and sexual assault. Uganda has responded generously, allocating land and shelter to families within 36 hours, but with nearly a million refugees now in the country, resources like water supply are becoming strained. About half the refugees are children, with schools operating in settlements like Bidi Bidi, which has grown from a village to one of the world's largest refugee settlements covering 250 square kilometers. UN officials suggest the violence could constitute genocide and ethnic cleansing.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. A former Norwich and Peterborough footballer, he turned professional boxer in 2013 after leaving football in 2011. He holds a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a former three-time world champion.

Bridgwater Community Hospital will receive £330m in coalition funding for new NHS facilities. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray and mobile scanner facilities. The project costs £33m total, with the remaining balance funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The current 1813-built hospital is outdated and poorly maintained. Three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced in the past five years, with additional work underway on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital. The new facility is planned for Bowers Lane subject to planning permission, with completion targeted for autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, Sheffield. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest near a black Mercedes car and was pronounced dead at Northern General hospital. The victim was a family member who was present during a family celebration when the attack occurred. This shooting marks a departure from recent incidents in Sheffield, which have primarily occurred in the north of the city. Recent shootings in the area include a 25-year-old man injured in Shiregreen, an elderly couple's home targeted in Southey Green (believed to be mistaken identity), and incidents in High Green in January.

The passage describes three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukraine-Russia conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conduct DDoS attacks against rebel websites, hack CCTV systems to monitor troop movements, disrupt separatist funding through electronic payment systems, and have hijacked network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, targets Ukrainian government websites and claims to have hacked devices belonging to US officials, leaked defense ministry data, and disrupted vote-counting systems. Anonymous International publishes leaked Kremlin documents and focuses primarily on Russian domestic affairs, though some material covers Ukraine. All three groups present themselves as independent activists, though their activities suggest varying degrees of alignment with their respective governments' interests.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as three veteran MSPs—Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie—delivered farewell speeches ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, reiterated his belief that Scotland is "diverse" rather than "divided" and emphasized the need for greater parliamentary responsibility for Scotland's governance. He welcomed the Scotland Bill's transfer of powers but argued it fell short of pledges made during the referendum campaign. McNeil, an MSP since the parliament's establishment in 1999, warned that Holyrood must maintain accountability and scrutiny, cautioning that the parliament has lessons to learn from Westminster's committee system. Goldie also stepped down, joking about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering evidence from pensioners, their families, and friends about their experiences in residential care to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will examine factors including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care home environments. While Rochira has observed positive impacts of high-quality care, she has also received increasing correspondence about unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales. Her team will also consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but expressed disappointment that no provider experts were included on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, increased pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to June 2016, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. The company manufactures and supplies animal feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors, and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland selling farming and rural products. International sales grew in Europe and new markets. The company acknowledged challenging times in agriculture over the previous 12-18 months but expressed confidence in the industry's robustness and the group's ability to handle potential Brexit impacts.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was also taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and are seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker). He is described as white, approximately 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair, and was believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt. Police have warned the public not to approach him and are urging anyone with information to contact police or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols have been deployed in the area.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, warned of economic risks, stating that the global economy is weakening and the world is at a "delicate juncture." This assessment follows weaker-than-expected trade data from China, where exports fell 25% year-over-year. The IMF plans to downgrade its global growth forecast from 3.4% when it releases updated predictions in April. These developments have significant implications for businesses and industries relying on China's economic growth.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address problems with a new chain ferry at Cowes. Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July and ordered an independent audit review. Since launching on 14 May, the ferry has experienced multiple issues including breakdowns, running aground, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues, and vehicle damage. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concern about business losses from six months of disrupted trade and questioned whether local businesses would receive compensation similar to damaged car owners. Transport councillor Ian Ward characterized the problems as typical teething issues for a prototype, noting that electrical problems have been fixed and ramp extensions are being manufactured to prevent vehicle scraping. He attributed groundings to seamanship issues that have since been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man who was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening during the police investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, faced criticism from the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) for job advertisements specifying physical attributes such as "brown long hair with b-c cup" for a personal assistant role and requesting a "sexy female driver" for a Porsche. The EHRC called the ads "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women," and women's equality campaigners compared them to 1970s practices. Employment lawyer James Lynas stated the adverts were "clearly unlawful," noting that phrases like "beautiful and attractive" could be interpreted as age discrimination and that rejected male applicants could sue for sex discrimination with unlimited compensation. Under the 2010 Equality Act, employers cannot discriminate based on age, sexual orientation, marital status, disability, race, religion, or other protected characteristics, and must justify any clothing size specifications as essential to the job. The agency's founder Nathalie Jansen defended the practice, citing client preferences and explaining specific examples such as a client wanting a "Jackie O" look. The EHRC called for the agency to modernize its practices and "consign this type of sexism to the history books."

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, allegedly shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and injured another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday following a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. Gun crime at schools and colleges in India is rare, though the country has strict firearms control laws. The motive for the shooting is unclear.

Between June 2016 and May 2017, advocacy group Glaad analyzed television shows and found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. Transgender character representation increased from seven to 16. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington from Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith from Wentworth. The study also recorded a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president noted progress was being made, though emphasized that numbers alone tell only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to face opposition. His decision follows controversy over a £10.25m loan to Northampton Town FC from the borough council when he was leader, intended for stadium rebuilding and land development. The missing funds are under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities, and the football stand remains half-built. A majority of his local party's executive council indicated they would vote to deselect him. Mackintosh has denied wrongdoing but stated it is time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was indicted for murder after firing a rifle into a car of teenagers leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Police responded to reports of underage drinking when Oliver fired into the vehicle as it drove away. Although police initially claimed the car reversed aggressively toward the officer, footage showed it was driving forward. Oliver was also charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for injuring four other teenagers in the car, including two of the victim's brothers. He was fired for policy violations and faces 5 to 99 years in prison if convicted. He would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. Oliver is currently free on bail, and no trial date has been set.

Melania Trump has decided not to immediately move to the White House, planning to stay in New York until her son Barron finishes school, citing concerns about mid-year school changes. This decision has drawn criticism on social media, as only two other First Ladies in U.S. history have not resided in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. However, historians note that children staying back to finish school is not unusual, and precedent exists for this arrangement. While the official role of First Lady is ceremonial, involving hosting functions and supporting causes, Melania has indicated Barron will be her priority, suggesting she may not take on the full-time role of recent predecessors like Michelle Obama. Her only stated policy interest is tackling cyber-bullying. Past First Families have successfully balanced White House life with maintaining family privacy and normal routines, with some children completing their education before or after moving to the residence.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service to investigate the initial police response to a call made by the man before his death at a sheltered housing complex. Police Scotland stated it is fully cooperating with the investigation and awaiting the commissioner's findings, which will be submitted to the COPFS.

A yellow weather warning has been issued for wind in seven Welsh counties (Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys), with gusts potentially reaching 75mph (120kmph), particularly west of the mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction is expected to increase impact, causing likely disruption to travel on roads and at sea. Overnight winds already brought down a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain closed through most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants scored first through player-coach Derrick Walser, but the Panthers equalized with Jeff Dimmen's goal. In the second period, Mike Forney's powerplay goal put the Giants ahead 2-1, though Andy Bohmback tied it again. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored to make it 4-2 before David Ling scored for Nottingham. The teams will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

World champion Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, made five pit stops, and now faces a 36-point deficit with 18 races remaining. An incident-packed first lap involving multiple collisions led to the safety car being deployed on lap four. Rosberg took the lead after Red Bull's Ricciardo suffered a puncture on lap three, and Rosberg maintained his advantage throughout the race. Ferrari's Vettel finished second and Raikkonen fifth, despite both colliding on the first lap. Hamilton struggled to recover due to car damage from a collision with Sauber's Nasr, ultimately unable to make up significant ground. No driver who has won the first three races of the season has failed to claim the World Championship, presenting a significant challenge for Hamilton's title hopes.

Thomas Hitzlsperger became the most prominent footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to advance discussion of a topic "simply ignored" in German football. His announcement received widespread support from former teammates, German football officials, and international figures, who praised his courage. Theo Zwanziger, former president of the German Football Association, called it a watershed moment in the fight against homophobia in football. The announcement is significant given Germany's ongoing struggles with homophobia in the sport, and comes after Germany captain Philipp Lahm controversially discouraged gay footballers from coming out in 2011. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck both expressed support, with hopes that Hitzlsperger's step would encourage other active players to come out and help break the taboo surrounding sexuality in football.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances this season for Brighton, helping them achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at the end of the campaign, he is seeking a new deal, expressing his desire to be part of the club's Premier League campaign. Brighton recently confirmed promotion with a win over Wigan and currently lead second-placed Newcastle by four points, aiming to secure the league title in their final two matches. Sidwell previously played on loan at Brighton in 2015-16 before signing a one-year contract in June 2016, and has prior Premier League experience with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first in the 12th minute when Jamille Matt turned in a chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized from a corner kick when Kurtis Guthrie scored from close range after a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool had opportunities to win the match, including a missed header from Tom Aldred in the 75th minute. The match ended with Colchester reduced to 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The 29-year-old Reid made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season before their relegation from League One. He has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid may debut for Colchester United in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round match against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington on Saturday.

PC Keith Palmer's murder outside Parliament in March prompted the UK Police Memorial Trust to appeal for £1.5m to build a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The memorial will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff who have died over the past 250 years. It will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to families of fallen officers as personal memorials. The government committed £1m towards the £4m total cost, with the memorial expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United defeated Sunderland 1-0 and extended their lead at the top of the table to 15 points with eight games remaining. The team has won 25 of their first 30 matches and earned 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games. They have eight matches left to surpass Chelsea's 2005 record of 95 points. Manager Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on upcoming matches rather than past achievements. The next league fixture is a derby against Manchester City. Ferguson announced changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea at Sunderland, with players like Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez becoming available for selection.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Mr Schmidt stated that Google complies with all legally required tax payments and that it is the government's responsibility to change tax laws if it wants companies to pay more. Margaret Hodge proposed establishing a new parliamentary committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, potentially allowing secret hearings to prevent companies from using confidentiality rules to hide tax affairs. Google routes most of its UK sales through Ireland and has faced criticism for minimizing UK tax payments. EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Mr Schmidt argued that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs rather than where products are consumed, and called for international tax reform with clearer rules set by politicians rather than companies.

NHS Improvement is pushing for faster progress in reducing agency staff spending, which reached £3.6bn last year. A cap introduced in October limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates has saved £600m so far, but the regulator aims to cut £1bn total by year-end. While progress is "promising," NHS trusts are currently 10% short of targets. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of trust performance and collect data on highest-earning agency staff, as some hospitals continue receiving quotes well above the caps—such as £130/hour for surgeons when the cap is £76. The regulator emphasizes the NHS cannot sustain current agency spending levels.

The Longford Town Centre, built during Ireland's economic boom, now symbolizes the country's financial crash. Local traders report a slow economic turnaround after difficult years. Matt O'Brien, who runs a men's clothing shop, has seen business increase recently and expanded into new areas like childrenswear and dress hire. However, opposition politician Robert Troy criticizes the government for lack of investment in the region, noting the Industrial Development Authority hasn't brought potential clients to Longford in four years. The government points to Center Parcs' planned 200 million euro tourism development in Ballymahon, expected to create 1,000 jobs when it opens in 2019, pending planning permission. Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon highlights the area's natural attractions and infrastructure. Despite signs of recovery, traders believe more support is needed, including free parking to attract customers to the town center.

This passage describes a cricket tournament featuring eight teams that compete twice against each other, with the top four teams advancing to play-offs. The competition concludes on 29 May. Leading performers include Warner (294 runs), Kohli (267 runs), and De Villiers (249 runs), while McClenaghan took the most wickets with 9. Four England players participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The passage provides a detailed fixture list from 25 April through 29 May, including group stage matches and play-off dates (Qualifier 1 on 24 May, Eliminator on 25 May, Qualifier 2 on 27 May, and Final on 29 May). All matches are scheduled for 15:30 BST unless otherwise stated.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported that plastic carrier bags increased by 200 million since 2013. These bags pose environmental problems as many cannot be recycled and end up in landfills and rivers. From October, England will implement a 5p charge per plastic bag to encourage reuse. Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, which already charge for carrier bags, have experienced reduced bag usage. Campaigners hope the English charge will decrease discarded bags and benefit the environment.

A severe windstorm affected Wales on Friday, causing significant disruptions. Part of a school roof was damaged near Caernarfon, and hundreds of homes lost power. The weather caused train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and ferry cancellations between Holyhead and Dublin. The National Trust closed two castles due to high winds. A yellow wind warning was in force until midnight Friday. As winds eased into the evening, some bridge restrictions were lifted. Due to continued blustery conditions forecast for the Christmas weekend, Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed from December 26 to December 27.

Michael B. Jordan is joining the Black Panther film, reuniting with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. He expressed excitement about putting a different spin on his role, though specific details weren't disclosed. The film will also star Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Black Panther is scheduled for release in February 2018.
