The passage describes a restoration project for a historic theatre at Alexandra Palace, founded in 1875. The theatre is intended to host theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music, alongside BBC studios that will also be refurbished. The entire east wing restoration project costs £26.6m, with funding from the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and a final £1m to be raised by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust by summer 2017. The theatre, which has remained unused for decades but retains its original decor and stage machinery, is hoped to reopen in 2018 as part of a broader initiative to transform Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination. The renovations will also include converting the glazed east court into a public exhibition space.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 England caps since his 2009 senior debut. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 appearances starting in 2004. He scored one international goal during England's 5-0 victory over Moldova in 2014 World Cup qualifiers. In his retirement statement, Milner expressed well-wishes to manager Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador caught fire after she burned rubbish in a wood stove. Her son David, who was awake on FaceTime with his father, spotted the flames and woke the family, allowing them to escape. The family lost their home, dog, and cats in the fire, which spread extremely rapidly. The fire alarm did not activate. The family fled with only their pajamas, but the community has provided donations of clothing, shoes, and other necessities. Mrs. Smith credits her son with saving her and her daughter's lives.

An energy drinks giant was reportedly considering a £200m offer for West Ham United. Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in the club in 2010 for £105m and now own over 85% of it. Following the club's move to London Stadium in August, there have been takeover links involving Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan previously indicated that while a minority shareholding might be sold to reduce debts, he and Gold plan to pass ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards ceremony in Los Angeles featured fan-voted awards and served as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the night's big winner, taking best movie, with star Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other major winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance in American Sniper, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep for best villain in Into the Woods. Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award and Robert Downey Jr. was honored with the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers co-stars. The ceremony also featured previews of upcoming summer films including Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron.

Cameron Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 international, was loaned from Aberdeen to United in July and has scored five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 with four goals in 89 appearances. St Mirren manager Jack Ross acquired Smith as an attacking option, describing him as a "really good player" and "good, mature boy." St Mirren, currently bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes daily over the next four months, now that weather conditions are suitable. Additional staff will also repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear gutters of debris.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. The workers, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were not wearing proper personal protective equipment because the equipment was initially assumed to be clear. The exposure level was less than 1% of the reportable threshold to the Health and Safety Executive, though EnQuest advised the HSE at the time. Following the incident, EnQuest implemented additional precautionary measures, and Wood Group conducted medical assessments of affected employees. Mr Innes has expressed concerns about duty of care and ongoing cancer fears, with blood tests continuing. The HSE confirmed the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR regulations and no investigation was conducted.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, southern India. After the dealer's manager admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, and following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the museum decided to return the sculpture. The ASI formally requested its return in May. While conclusive proof of theft is lacking, the museum's decision was influenced by the dealer's confession to trafficking looted Indian antiquities. The sculpture was one of 30 objects ACM purchased from the dealer, though the others are not thought to be stolen. The museum plans to pursue legal action for compensation regarding the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt across a wide area including Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Several aftershocks followed, and phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. An INGV official characterized it as a classic, medium-strong, and fairly shallow earthquake for the region. Italy remains earthquake-prone; a 2009 L'Aquila quake killed nearly 300 people, and six scientists and an official were later convicted of manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring information before that disaster. The previous May, two earthquakes in the same area had killed over 20 people.

Austin Grant from Sheffield successfully grew fruit in South Yorkshire's climate despite initial doubts about its suitability. The fruit remains attached to the plant and is not yet ripe enough to eat. The 62-year-old grandfather expressed his excitement about the results, saying he was "literally jumping for joy."

Rockstar delayed the PC release of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March to allow extra time for testing and polish. The company announced that online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC release. The PC version will feature enhanced graphics with support for 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor configurations. GTA V originally released on 17 September 2013 and became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days.

A 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting depicts a leper squint—holes in medieval church walls that allowed excluded people to view services. Simpson, who had been shortlisted previously, described the relatively small 7ft-high work as part of a series he has been developing. Judge Ansel Krut praised it as "quite extraordinary," noting its technical subtlety and minimal language that builds emotional resonance over time. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art materials, particularly quality paints and canvas. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest biennial art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked early Thursday morning. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, setting a fire that firefighters extinguished, while the Yeni Akit offices, located 20km away, were attacked almost simultaneously. Both attacks involved gunfire that shattered windows and left spent bullet casings at both scenes. No casualties were reported, police cordoned off the areas, and no group has claimed responsibility. Both newspapers support President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's AK Party.

A 24-year-old player has joined on a free transfer from the Stags, becoming Marcus Bignot's first signing for the Mariners, effective 1 January. He previously spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. He is a former Burton player.

Arsène Wenger commented on Gareth Southgate's interim England manager role, praising his experience and ability to demonstrate competency through his decisions. Wenger stated he focuses on his own job amid speculation about his potential involvement with the England position. Southgate has upcoming World Cup qualifier and friendly matches to prove himself for a permanent appointment. Wenger also announced that Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin would be offered a new contract despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, expressing confidence in Bellerin's long-term future at the club. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey is expected to miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation into the incident, with the company providing full cooperation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf said a new charter arrangement would resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats, the Hellier and Hildasay. The RMT union claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. Currently operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, the service will return to Serco Northlink directly from next month. Seatruck had argued the national minimum wage did not apply to its non-UK resident crew, while Serco Northlink said it had offered to bridge the pay gap but Seatruck declined. Under the new arrangements, all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink operates the Northern Isles route under a six-year £243m contract awarded in 2012, which is heavily subsidised by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on May 14, six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr Dickie and Mitchell's mother, with whom Dickie had been in a relationship. On May 7, Mitchell became intoxicated at the holiday park bar and confronted Dickie outside, where they were separated by members of the public. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault. Both Mitchell and his mother Samantha, 57, admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about the events. Mitchell later claimed he tried to separate the couple, describing it as a "tragic accident." A jury at Winchester Crown Court announced a verdict, and sentencing is scheduled for February 6.

Rod Temperton, a renowned British songwriter and producer, died in London at age 66 following a brief battle with cancer. He was best known for writing major hits for Michael Jackson, including "Thriller," "Rock With You," and "Off The Wall," as well as songs for his band Heatwave like "Boogie Nights." Temperton began his career in the 1970s with Heatwave before being discovered by producer Quincy Jones, leading to his prolific work on Jackson's albums. His songwriting also earned him a Grammy Award in 1990 and two Oscar nominations in 1986. Known as "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile, Temperton's songs have been recorded by numerous artists including Aretha Franklin and Donna Summer. His work helped make "Thriller" the best-selling album of all time in the US with 32 million copies sold.

Swansea University researchers Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, along with teams from Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities, discovered over 450 ancient geometrical earthworks called "geoglyphs" in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon, possibly 2,000 years old. These ditched enclosures were hidden by rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. Their function remains unclear, but they were likely used sporadically as ritual gathering places rather than villages or defensive structures. Analysis of soil samples, including phytoliths and charcoal, indicates the geoglyphs were built among tall vegetation and were not visible above the forest canopy, distinguishing them from other ritual sites like Maya pyramids. The research challenges the assumption that pre-16th century Amazonian forests were pristine, revealing instead that humans deliberately cultivated diverse plant species over 6,000 years, concentrating on economically valuable trees like palms in a form of "prehistoric supermarket." This ancient "agroforestry" practice may have left a lasting legacy in Acre's remaining forests today.

The Australian tennis player Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round. After winning the Japan Open on Sunday, Kyrgios attributed his quieter demeanor during the match to fatigue and tiredness from traveling to the Qi Zhong Stadium near Shanghai. He cited poor sleep and the difficult commute to the courts as contributing factors to his exhaustion.

The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine currently protects girls aged 12-13 against cervical cancer in Wales, with an 85% vaccination rate achieved since 2008. Scientists and charities are calling for the vaccination programme to be expanded to boys, citing increasing cases of head and neck cancers caused by HPV. Dr Mererid Evans notes that head and neck cancer cases are rising, particularly among younger, non-smoking men with an average age of 55. HPV accounts for 5% of the global cancer burden. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making decisions about expanding the programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil, died from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Diagnosed in August, he documented his cancer treatment on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," which attracted over 28,000 likes. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and was visited by players from various football clubs and the cast of Wicked. On January 23, doctors informed him that his cancer had spread and decided against further treatment. He briefly attended his prom on Saturday before feeling unwell and leaving after 10 minutes, where he received his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. His mother announced his death on Facebook. His family has encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with further fundraising planned through a special football match at Livingston FC.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a Group D match of the African Cup of Nations. Mohamed Salah assisted Abdallah El Said, who scored the winning goal in the 89th minute. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the match. Egypt will face Ghana on Wednesday with top spot in Group D still to be decided, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. Ghana also advanced to the quarter-finals with a 1-0 victory over Mali on the same day.

Lancashire County Council has selected land at the former Glenburn Sports College as the preferred site for a new railway station in Skelmersdale. The decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail of three potential locations. Under the plans developed in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, Skelmersdale could receive two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The site was chosen because it offers sufficient space for future expansion, good highway access, and strong connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale's original railway station closed to passengers in 1956, and the town remains one of the largest in the north west without its own station.
Police discovered cannabis plants in an elaborate grow house during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, late Sunday after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from Bad Muender later turned himself in to police. Both the victim and suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are appealing for witnesses.

Research from Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin analyzed 4,600 workers and found that women ask for pay rises as often as men, but are 25% less likely to receive them when they do ask. The study, based on 2013-14 Australian workplace relations data, refutes the "reticent female" theory that women avoid requesting salary increases due to reluctance to upset their boss or deviate from gender stereotypes. By comparing like-for-like workers (full-time with full-time, part-time with part-time) and accounting for factors such as employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications, researchers concluded the pay rise disparity reflects discrimination rather than differences in negotiating behavior. However, the study found that women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at equal rates, suggesting negotiating behavior may be changing among younger workers.

Oxford City Council has spent money on ground investigations to find a new burial site but has been unsuccessful. The two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley have space until 2018 and 2021 respectively. Council officials state that suitable land within Oxford has been exhausted, with all council-owned sites rejected due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or legal covenants. Once these cemeteries are full, only family plot reopenings, reserved plots, and ash interments will be available. Oxford's last burial space expansion occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (July 19-22) is introducing an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online content from signs and posters at the festival site. The app will feature videos and band interviews viewable on phones and tablets. Performers include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. According to festival director Caroline Maclennan, the augmented reality experience enhances the on-site experience while enabling global audiences to interact with the festival remotely, access information and interviews, purchase tickets, and experience the festival's atmosphere from anywhere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The BHA noted such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues across all sports disciplines. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and while he had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, he displayed no such symptoms on the day of his death. His trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime."

A 15-year-old girl met Davina Ayrton (then called David) at a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004. Ayrton, now 34, was convicted of raping the teenager while two others slept nearby. The victim, who had consumed minimal alcohol, clearly remembered the assault and shouted at Ayrton to stop, but her friends did not wake. Ayrton disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014. The defendant, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide in the previous summer, denied the charge. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody at a male prison in Winchester, citing substantial grounds to believe she posed a risk to herself and of failing to attend court. Sentencing is scheduled for 4 March, with protocols established for her detention.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian doubles partner lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilian pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss occurred after Djokovic was eliminated from singles competition by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. The world number one had previously suffered a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July to American Sam Querrey. Prior to the Olympics, the 12-time Grand Slam winner won his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in a chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms on Saturday. Participants must use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner Pete Bowsher from Moffat will return to defend his title and compete for the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, suffered a serious foot injury in September during a World Cup warm-up match with Italy. He is now recovering and close to returning to play, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations in February. Wales will begin their Six Nations campaign away to Ireland on 7 February. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other clubs to remain with Ospreys, the region where he made his debut in 2007 and where he has earned 16 caps for Wales.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near Sumas, Washington, attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. When ordered to halt, one man fired at agents and fled; the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested immediately. The fugitive, Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was arrested by Abbotsford Police in British Columbia the following morning. Four additional people were arrested in connection with the plot: Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, who were allegedly planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco for $11,000, and two others accused of planning the transport. All three defendants in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area near Sumas is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service counselled over 4,500 children experiencing online abuse in the past year, nearly double the 2,400 cases from 2011-12, with children as young as seven reporting torment and fear. Online trolls cause misery and humiliation for thousands of children, and cyber-bullying follows victims beyond school gates into their homes. Childline's president Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized that bullying worsens if left unaddressed and called for adults, parents, teachers, and schools to intervene and take the problem seriously, while encouraging children to seek help. The report was released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which works with parents, schools, and organizations to combat bullying.

Prime Minister Netanyahu's office requested the postponement of a Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee vote on 492 new settlement homes in Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, scheduled for Wednesday. The delay was intended to avoid escalating tensions with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This decision came after the US abstained on a UN Security Council resolution Friday calling for an end to settlement construction, which Netanyahu condemned. The resolution stated that settlements have no legal validity and constitute a violation of international law and an obstacle to a two-state solution. More than 500,000 Jews live in approximately 140 settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem built since 1967. Israel rejected the resolution, particularly objecting to the condemnation of East Jerusalem construction, which it considers part of its capital. Netanyahu responded by summoning US and Security Council ambassadors and recalling Israeli ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas stated the resolution supports an upcoming Middle East peace conference scheduled for January 15 in France.

The passage covers the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations. Prince William paid tribute to the Queen in a BBC interview, calling her a "guiding example" of good monarchy. A new stamp featuring four generations of the Royal Family—the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George—was released to mark the occasion. On her birthday, the Queen visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office to mark the postal service's 500th anniversary and attended a ceremony to open a new bandstand. Political leaders including Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their well-wishes. Prince William addressed recent criticism about his limited royal duties, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but is developing into his role at the right time. For her actual birthday on Thursday, the Queen and Prince Philip will unveil a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway, a 6.3km walking trail, and she will light a beacon triggering over 900 beacons worldwide. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle on Friday. The republican pressure group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage as excessive celebration rather than balanced reporting.

West Ham United defeated League Two side Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored the Premier League side's goals before half-time, with Sakho converting from Sam Byram's pass and Ayew following moments later into the same corner. West Ham made seven changes following recent top-flight losses, while Cheltenham remained unchanged from their previous league defeat. Cheltenham had chances through Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header but failed to test West Ham goalkeeper Adrian sufficiently. West Ham could have won by a greater margin, with Kyle Storer clearing Angelo Ogbonna's header off the line and Jonathan Flatt saving Sakho's attempt. The two teams had met once before four years earlier in the same competition, with West Ham winning 2-1 at Upton Park. Cheltenham's loss ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday when Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to see the motorcyclist as he turned his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and received a £1,000 fine and a two-year driving ban in the UK. The victim's family did not seek jail time for Werner, viewing the incident as a momentary lapse. Werner's defense stated he was remorseful and could offer no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from London, is a British jihadist who traveled to Syria in January and joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State. He posted online propaganda videos and images under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani, and was involved in the group's recruitment and fundraising efforts. Khawaja was photographed holding a severed head, allegedly of a Syrian army soldier. In June, he attempted to return to the UK, faking his death online and asking his cousin Tahir Bhatti to help smuggle him back. Police arrested both men at Dover. Khawaja faces up to life imprisonment and has admitted four offences, while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. A charge of soliciting to murder against Khawaja was placed on file. Authorities consider him one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from Syria.

Jackson, a 22-year-old forward, has joined Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season. He scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and attacking style, stating he will suit Barnsley's playing approach. Jackson declined a new contract offer from Wrexham to make the move.

Bottles of cleaning product "Vanish" have been washing up on beaches in Cornwall, including Poldhu Cove and nearby coves such as Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove and Marazion. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of these bottles near Land's End in May during stormy weather, though they note the evidence linking the washed-up bottles to this specific container is currently circumstantial. National Trust volunteers are clearing away the bottles as they pose a risk to wildlife and marine life. While most bottles remain sealed, some have leaked. Authorities including Cornwall Council, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, and Natural England are monitoring the beaches, and the public has been advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 14:00, resulting in several people sustaining minor injuries. The A9 was closed with diversions implemented via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that investigations into the incident were continuing.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers following their promotion to the Championship. He made 14 appearances last season, contributing to the team's second-place finish in League One. Dervite joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is the fourth player to sign a new contract following promotion, after David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour initially cooperated in the House of Lords to challenge the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but their alliance fractured when MPs rejected these amendments. The Lib Dems wanted to persist with the amendments while Labour deferred to the Commons' decision. Labour accused the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" and giving false hope to worried EU citizens, while the Lib Dems criticized Labour for supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite this conflict, the two opposition parties have a history of working together on various issues including higher education and housing, and indicated they may continue to cooperate on matters of agreement, though with "residual tensions."

Defence is a low priority in this election, ranking outside the top 10 voter concerns. While analysts agree the world is becoming more dangerous, the UK has significantly cut its armed forces and defence spending. The regular Army is being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000 personnel, and the UK has fallen from fourth to sixth place in global defence spending. The UK is likely to fall below Nato's 2% GDP spending threshold, requiring an additional £25bn over five years to maintain it. Major unresolved issues include whether to renew Trident (with costs of at least £20bn), how to crew two new aircraft carriers with insufficient personnel, and whether to equip them with the planned F-35 jets. The Conservative, Labour, and Liberal Democrat manifestos lack detailed defence policies. Military leaders warn of a "hollow force" with advanced equipment but insufficient personnel, making it increasingly difficult for Britain to maintain its traditional military influence.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for 22-year-old striker Neymar from Santos in the summer, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. Including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and a recent tax payment, Neymar's total cost to the club is £106.8m. Barcelona is under investigation for potential tax violations related to the transfer, with a Spanish judge ruling there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations. The club denies any wrongdoing and made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros, maintaining they originally met their fiscal obligations. Barcelona's president Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid accusations of misappropriating money and is also being investigated. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, a delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a motorway crash when a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman collided with the van he was traveling in. Mr. Luciw's family and the surviving driver, Andy Harrington, have called for mandatory regular driving tests for retired drivers, citing concerns about age-related slower reaction times. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must renew their licenses every three years through self-assessment forms without medical or driving tests. The DVLA stated it has no plans to restrict licensing based on age, citing evidence that older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK emphasized the importance of allowing older people to continue driving safely to maintain their independence.

Many women have suffered debilitating side effects from implants used to treat incontinence, leading to controversy over their safety. An independent review concluded that these procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended patients be offered a range of treatments with informed choice options. The review also recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events. However, two patients and a consultant quit the review group in protest, claiming the final report was watered-down and parts were removed. Independent expert Alison Britton will now examine the review process and lessons for the future. The health secretary confirmed recommendations would be implemented despite calls for an all-out ban, noting that the UK regulatory body holds the power to ban procedures, not the government. The review's chairwoman apologized for failing to unite panel members around the controversial report. Over 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh or tape implants, with over 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers due to complications.

Muir, 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old 5K indoor record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14:49.12. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether the race met UK Athletics criteria for record-breaking, noting it was a mixed 3K race where only Muir competed the full 5K distance and questioning whether drug testing was conducted. British Athletics confirmed the time is expected to be classified as official after ratification, with rules stipulating no drug test requirement if doping control wasn't present at the event. McColgan praised Muir's performance and potential, suggesting she could run faster times around 14:30 given her 3:55 1500m ability, and noted Muir has the capability to win world medals. McColgan compared the record-breaking circumstances to her own record 25 years ago, when she also ran alone and lapped other competitors. She expressed satisfaction that a fellow Scot broke her record.

Jung won the equestrian event aboard Sam, a late replacement horse after Fischertakinou contracted an infection in July. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall. Despite producing a faultless show-jumping performance in the final phase, Fox-Pitt's medal chances were ruined by a disappointing cross-country performance on Monday, where he incurred several time penalties and dropped from first place to 21st. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old Briton, defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in a match lasting two hours and 39 minutes to advance to the last 16 for the 11th time. Despite Fognini having five set points to force a fifth set, Murray won five consecutive games to secure victory. Murray will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. In a separate match, fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time, defeating Maria Sakkari of Greece 6-4 6-1. Murray described the match as tense and up-and-down, noting he managed to get through despite not playing his best tennis and concerns about fading light that could have required the roof to be closed.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014 following a sudden death. Police found the bar still serving alcohol at 04:49 BST, well outside licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours and fined £3,000. James Thomas faced one count of the same charge and was fined £1,000. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, describing it as one of the worst cases he had encountered and criticizing O'Neill's "appalling record" of not running the premises properly.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched the party's manifesto titled 'Real Partnership' with the statement "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." The party wants the election to focus on how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled. However, attention has shifted to Nesbitt's comments suggesting voters should transfer their votes to the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin if a nationalist party enters government. When asked about senior colleague Danny Kennedy's public distancing from these remarks, Nesbitt defended his position, stating he would not withdraw his words and expressed confidence in his stance. The manifesto includes commitments to tackle waiting lists, increase PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritize the York Street interchange, support the LGBT community, and ensure no group is disadvantaged by Brexit. Nesbitt framed the election as a referendum on "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption" regarding the previous decade of DUP and Sinn Féin governance.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will be brought before the Northern Ireland assembly to approve automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. Known as 'Turing's Law', the measure will align Northern Ireland with England and Wales and allow for both posthumous pardons and pardons for living gay and bisexual men convicted of such offences. The minister stated arrangements would be implemented as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men across all three jurisdictions, describing it as an opportunity for the criminal justice system to correct historical wrongs.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, breaking the Scottish record previously held by Yvonne Murray (4:22.60 from 1994). This time places Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She finished fifth at last year's World Championships and is aiming to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from June 24-26. Muir is balancing her athletic career with veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
I am unable to summarize this text.

Alexander Litvinenko, a 43-year-old former FSB officer who defected to the UK in 2000, was poisoned with polonium-210 in London in 2006 during a meeting with suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. He died nearly three weeks later. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that the Russian state was likely responsible for the murder, citing the suspects' lack of personal motive, the sophisticated nature of polonium as a weapon, and Litvinenko's defection and criticism of Putin as potential motives. The suspects deny wrongdoing and remain in Russia; extradition attempts have failed. Horwell noted that Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death, left a trail of polonium across London, and the long-term public health effects remain unknown.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as Australia's Test cricket captain following Michael Clarke's retirement after the Ashes defeat to England. Smith already captains the one-day and Twenty20 sides and has previous captaincy experience from three Tests against India. David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and leadership qualities, noting he has the right credentials for the role. Smith has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test on August 20.

Tim Farron, the new Liberal Democrat leader who beat Norman Lamb, stated he is "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and committed to defending equal marriage while extending marital rights for transgender people. When asked three times on Channel 4 News whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, he refused to give a direct answer, instead saying "we are all sinners." Regarding his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, Farron explained the Lib Dems had tabled an amendment due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties," and when defeated, he voted against the bill. He emphasized his support for equality and equal access under law for all people regardless of sexuality, and highlighted the need to address the "spousal veto" that prevents transgender people from having equal access to marriage.

Sanofi closed its pharmaceutical manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, eliminating 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare will now operate the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi employees. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries, expects the investment to positively impact the local economy and strengthen the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector.

The local authority announced three senior staff departures: Richard Ellis is leaving Friday at the end of his contract after serving as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn criticized the departures as evidence of the council's inability to retain senior staff and predicted further departures ahead. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their contributions.

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked Sardar Daud hospital in Afghanistan, detonating explosives at the gate and opening fire on staff and patients. Commandos killed all four attackers after several hours of fighting. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, which left over 50 people wounded. President Ashraf Ghani condemned the assault as an attack on human values and Afghanistan itself. This marks a significant shift in IS tactics—their first direct engagement with security forces in the capital using an approach similar to the Taliban's. The attack suggests IS now has expanded resources and military training, potentially indicating more assaults ahead. Since announcing its presence in Afghanistan in 2015, IS has primarily operated in the east near the Pakistan border and has carried out numerous attacks, including suicide bombings that killed dozens of people in previous years.

English rider Martin crashed at this year's TT on a Fireblade bike that experienced mechanical problems. He initially stated he was quitting road racing but clarified on Facebook that he has no plans to do more road racing on Hondas this year, though he hasn't given up on racing entirely. He did not compete at the North West 200 following his teammate John McGuinness's crash in practice, and will not race at the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a disaster, noting he spent much of the event testing the bike rather than racing competitively. After additional testing at Cadwell, he informed the team the bike wouldn't be competitive at Ulster, and the team withdrew him from the event. He expressed interest in racing classics and unconventional racing instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governorships in Nigeria's Saturday elections, marking the biggest defeat for the ruling Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. This follows the PDP's loss of the presidential election last month to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost control of key northern states including Katsina and Kaduna, and Adamawa, though it retained Rivers State and won eight governorships mostly in the south-east. The APC made historic gains across northern states and Lagos in the south-west, but failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which poses concerns for Buhari regarding potential militant disruption of oil production. The elections saw 66 violent incidents at polling stations, primarily in southern states, though overall they were more peaceful than previous years. The PDP's decline is attributed to 16 years in power, defections to the APC, widespread corruption allegations, and failure to address the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

Environmental lobby group Mighty accused agricultural commodities trader Olam of sourcing palm oil from suppliers engaged in slash-and-burn practices that contribute to regional haze, with allegations also directed at Olam's majority stakeholder, Singapore state-owned Temasek. Both companies reject the claims. Olam sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and accounts for less than 1% of the global market. The company's CEO stated it maintains a "zero tolerance for burning" policy and only recently disclosed its 14 suppliers after previous resistance. Temasek denied the allegations, stating it does not direct Olam's operations. The report also accused Olam of clearing rainforests in Gabon for palm oil plantations. The palm oil industry globally faces criticism for environmental destruction, deforestation, and labor practices, though executives argue policing third-party suppliers is industry-wide challenging and that enforcement is complicated by the economic benefits these firms provide to rural areas.
A restaurant began serving special platters for dogs after a new law permitted dogs to eat at outdoor restaurant areas.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury and has only appeared as a substitute in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent (groin injury) may return after missing Monday's match against Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is seeking a recall after scoring a late equalizer as a substitute in that same game.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted a ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The ban, imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 following protests over the film "Innocence of Muslims," is now being replaced with a content filtering system. Under the new arrangement, Pakistan's Telecommunication Authority can request Google to block offending material, and Google will restrict access for Pakistani users. YouTube stated that government removal requests won't be automatically granted and will be recorded in its Transparency Report. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the lifting of the ban, some activists have called for greater transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces pressure to withdraw from his position due to sharing Swiss-Italian nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Liberian Football Association boss Musa Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down by Thursday. Scala previously withdrew from the 2015 elections when Swiss incumbent Sepp Blatter was a candidate, citing conflict of interest based on shared nationality. However, Scala's spokesman argues that having the same nationality as a candidate does not constitute a conflict of interest under Fifa regulations, and that Scala's previous withdrawal was a voluntary precautionary measure. The presidential election, featuring five candidates including Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, will take place on 26 February in Zurich and will be decided by Fifa's 209 member votes.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an explosion at Harford Attachments on Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area. The company manufactures buckets for diggers. Forensic evidence suggests a flashover explosion occurred due to a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, creating a fire-ball effect. Forensic searches have been conducted, witness statements obtained, and the Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence through inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against Caf during the 2015 Nations Cup, but was reinstated after apologizing. Morocco was initially banned from 2017 qualifying but had the ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, with their fine reduced from $1m to $50,000. Tunisia's dispute stemmed from a controversial penalty awarded against them in their 2015 quarter-final against hosts Equatorial Guinea, which they lost 2-1 in extra-time. Tunisia denied accusing Caf or the referee of corruption, but contested the referee's selection and the unjustifiable penalty decision. Following a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Dakar, Tunisia and Caf resolved their differences. In the 2017 qualifying draw, Tunisia was drawn in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti, while Morocco was placed in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome.

A mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute of a Chelsea vs. Manchester City match at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. Manchester City forward Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct following a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz, marking his second dismissal for violent conduct that season. City midfielder Fernandinho received a three-match ban for clashing with Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas during the resulting scuffle. Chelsea's Fabregas faces no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath Castle is targeting patients suspected by their GPs of having cancer but showing no clear signs or symptoms. This follows a visit by doctors to Denmark to study their diagnostic systems, which have improved cancer survival rates. The problem in Wales is that patients without clear symptoms wait too long for diagnosis because they don't fit neatly into specific treatment pathways, resulting in delayed referrals and multiple tests over weeks. The fear is that too many patients begin treatment when their cancer is advanced or incurable. Under the pilot, 40 GPs can refer suspected patients to a diagnostic centre at Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant within seven days, with around six patients per week receiving various tests on the same day. Currently only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms receive diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. A similar clinic will be established at Neath Port Talbot Hospital. The trials were developed following experts' return from Aarhus, Denmark, which established diagnostic centres due to concerns about cancer survival rates. The pilot aims to reassure patients and accelerate diagnosis. If successful over six months, other health boards will offer the same service.

England defeated Pakistan by a large margin at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, while also taking four catches and claiming a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook scored 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan was bowled out for 198 and 234, batting for only 63 and 70 overs respectively. Root attributed his strong performance to correcting the poor strokes that led to England's defeat in the first Test at Lord's. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged the disappointment, citing poor shot selection and lack of confidence as key factors in the loss. The third Test is scheduled for August 3 at Edgbaston.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, having previously led the team on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches to assist McBryde for the summer tour. WRU chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions campaign will benefit Welsh rugby, as coaches and players gain experience from different environments and the challenging New Zealand tour will provide mental stimulation and inspiration.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1 in a dramatic comeback. Southampton took an early lead through Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty, but Hull's fortunes changed dramatically in the second half. Robert Snodgrass, introduced as a substitute after Will Keane's injury, scored in the 61st minute from Sam Clucas' cross, then provided an assist for Michael Dawson's header moments later. Despite Southampton's pressure and multiple attempts to equalize, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas produced a remarkable goalline clearance in added time to secure the victory. This win ended Hull's six-game losing streak, though they remain in the bottom three of the league.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa in Lincolnshire. The motorcyclist was a local resident, while the tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses and closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" before early June elections. The move was condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal, and by EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership prospects. The crisis stems from recordings released since February 2015 by Zaev, which allegedly show ministers plotting vote-rigging and murder cover-ups, along with accusations of wiretapping 20,000 people and widespread government corruption. The government denies these accusations and accuses Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country, which he rejects.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea is seeking to appoint a new permanent manager quickly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as their primary target. Curtis expresses concern about the Championship's strength, noting that relegation would be difficult to recover from despite examples like Norwich and Burnley. He believes Swansea has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, attributing this to frequent managerial changes and dilution of the "Swansea Way," though he considers the current squad capable of staying up. Curtis emphasizes the club's remarkable journey from near-bankruptcy and potential Football League relegation in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, and notes he reminds new signings of this history through the documentary "Jack to a King."

Dagenham and Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing to Leyton Orient 3-2. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona gave Dagenham hope after Orient took a 2-0 lead through Jay Simpson, but Armand Gnanduillet scored the winning goal. Dagenham, who reached the Football League for the first time in 2007, now return to the National League under manager John Still. The club struggled this season with League Two's worst goal difference and poor attacking form, with 40-year-old striker Cureton scoring only nine goals compared to 20 last season. Orient's victory keeps their play-off hopes alive, leaving them two points adrift of the play-off spots. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler acknowledged the difficulty of losing two managers this season but emphasized the need to win games to reach the play-offs.

A 36-year-old former Reds captain is returning to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. Manager Klopp praised the appointment, noting the ex-England skipper's ambition to become a manager in the future. The appointee made his Liverpool debut in 1998, left in 2015 to join LA Galaxy, and retired after a 19-year career in November. He previously declined a managerial opportunity at MK Dons, considering it too soon, and is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence required for Premier League management.

McManus scored first for Morton in the 15th minute, followed by Ross Forbes' deflected goal to double the lead. Alloa reduced the deficit through Kyle McAusland before half-time. McManus scored again and Denny Johnstone added a late goal to secure Morton's comfortable victory.

Ofsted has identified three illegal schools in Birmingham operating in squalid conditions, which have now closed. An investigation found 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. Running illegal schools can result in jail sentences up to 51 weeks. Places teaching more than 20 hours weekly must register as schools, though some "flexi schools" operate legally supporting home-educated children. Ofsted and ministers are concerned some exploit home education rights to run illegal schools. The government has funded six inspectors to investigate illegal schools and the Education Secretary is pursuing prosecutions. Ministers are consulting on plans for increased regulation of places teaching 6-8 hours weekly or more. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, stated the cases found are likely the "tip of the iceberg" and expressed concern about child abuse and radicalization risks. He emphasized enforcement will apply across all religious groups.

Lilliard Gin is a distillery based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, operating from a cowshed with one of the UK's smallest production stills. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes aims to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence" by using local botanicals from the Teviot valley to capture the area's unique flavour profile and terroir. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure who fought at the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545 to avenge her lover's death. The distillery represents the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders in nearly 200 years and complements the existing Scottish Borders Brewery on site, with both operations emphasizing local sourcing.

Gary Green, 51, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm near Leeds in August 2013, causing his death. Green was more than twice the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law because the incident occurred on private land, and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed that the family had been "changed forever" and emphasized that driving under the influence is unacceptable regardless of location. The Health and Safety Executive inspector described Green's behaviour as "reckless."

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguay striker who joined Barcelona for £75m, had his FIFA ban partially overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). While he must still serve eight remaining competitive matches of his nine-match ban and cannot play in organized matches, he is now permitted to train, play in friendlies, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities. His competitive Barcelona debut is expected on 26 October against Real Madrid. Cas ruled that FIFA's complete ban from all football-related activity was "excessive," though the overall sanctions were generally confirmed. Suarez was originally banned for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. This is his third biting incident, having previously bitten PSV Eindhoven's Otman Bakkal and Chelsea's Branislav Ivanovic.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene. The couple trained for a week on an athletics track before competing. The race involves a 380-metre course with obstacles including haystacks to hurdle, a steep slope to climb, and water pistols to dodge. Participants can be any combination of people and don't need to be married to compete. Richard and Anna will advance to compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond, a minister, addressed concerns about job losses at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) in Swansea following the government's decision to scrap paper car tax discs in October 2014. The tax disc will be replaced with an electronic system allowing people to pay vehicle tax through monthly direct debit. Hammond stated that while the changes may alter job roles and reduce refund-related work, any necessary reductions in staffing will be managed through redeployment to other areas rather than redundancies. The DVLA employs approximately 5,000 workers, and these assurances were welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who had sought clarification on the government's plans.

Hungary's right-wing Fidesz government under Prime Minister Viktor Orban is resisting EU pressure to withdraw three controversial laws: strict asylum controls, restrictions on NGOs, and a higher education law. The government argues these are domestic issues and should not be subject to EU interference. Hungary has secured Poland's commitment to veto any EU sanctions, including the stripping of voting rights, which requires unanimous approval. The asylum law involves housing seekers in secured shipping containers, the education law threatens the closure of the prestigious Central European University founded by George Soros, and the NGO legislation would stigmatize organizations as "foreign-backed." Thousands of Hungarians have protested these laws, and EU officials have warned that action will be taken if there are no positive developments.

The live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast will star Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Kevin Kline as Maurice. Additional cast members include Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and an unnamed actress as Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon will direct the film, which begins shooting at Shepperton Studios in May and is scheduled for US release on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist for the Sunday Times since 1993, died after being diagnosed with multiple cancers. Known for his distinctive writing style and wit, Gill had been undergoing chemotherapy and remained stoical about his illness. His final column, addressing his diagnosis, was published posthumously. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill overcame dyslexia to become a celebrated journalist and writer, beginning his career with art reviews in the 1980s. While his writing was widely praised for its brilliance and fearlessness, his articles frequently sparked controversy, including offensive comments about the Welsh, descriptions of various locations, and a censured review of Clare Balding. Gill was engaged to his long-term partner Nicola Formby at the time of his death and had four children across two relationships.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, lead singer of the Mongolian band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator while performing in a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika. According to reports, he was hit with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, spending about 10 days in a coma with serious head injuries. The swastika is a traditional Mongolian symbol of eternity that predates Nazi Germany, though the Russian embassy called press reports of the assault "distorted." A Russian diplomatic officer is suspected of the attack but was not arrested; police stated this was due to the injury not being classified as serious, not diplomatic immunity. The musician's representatives denied claims he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday at an airport's northern runway to oppose expansion plans. Multiple protesters were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted aerodrome security area. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police announced that airport security would be reviewed following the protest, which occurred at 03:30 BST.

Nick Selman scored 101 off 144 balls for Glamorgan in his second first-class century, helping his team reach a total that was built around his mature innings. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions in Cardiff, with Selman's century coming after being dropped on eight in the first over. Aneurin Donald contributed 36 off 30 balls, and Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten helped Glamorgan secure a bonus point. Gloucestershire batted in difficult evening conditions with the day ending evenly balanced. Glamorgan were led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem. Selman described the wicket as slow and noted his return to form after four consecutive ducks following his previous century against Northants at Swansea. Taylor expressed satisfaction with the bowling performance and the opportunity to play red-ball cricket.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after contacting the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee online. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court after threatening to make a false police report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he said he would shoot them. The threats were made twice late at night while he was intoxicated. Hughes has a previous firearm possession conviction from 2009. He was remanded in custody pending sentencing, which is scheduled for the following week. His legal team claimed he had no intention of carrying out the threats or harming himself.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire in a cricket match. Surrey scored 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes (90) contributing a 130-run partnership. Yorkshire's chase fell short at 236 all out. Stuart Meaker took three wickets in nine balls, dismissing Bairstow and Ballance among others. Tim Bresnan scored 68 for Yorkshire. Yorkshire had hoped to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 after losing to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals the previous weekend. Matthew Waite took 3-48 for Surrey. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees acknowledged they were not good enough when it mattered, while Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised his team's collective effort and the Davies-Foakes partnership.

A 56ft converted trawler located 6 miles west of South Stack radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting that its onboard pump could not manage the incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on the vessel and towing it to Holyhead.

Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, with final exams in May conflicting with the April event. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, achieving a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m. While prioritizing her degree completion, Muir is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and believes she has multiple future Olympic opportunities ahead.

Liverpool are struggling to mount another title challenge after overachieving last season. Key problems include the loss of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's goals, with replacement strikers Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini not providing adequate work-rate or goal-scoring threat. The team lacks the intensity and pressing of last season, resulting in only four first-half goals in their first 10 games compared to 59 the previous year. Defensively, despite significant spending on players like Dejan Lovren, Liverpool remain inconsistent, and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet lacks commanding presence. Set-piece effectiveness has also declined dramatically. Against Chelsea, Liverpool will need a solid defensive structure with attacking contributions from full-backs and creative midfielders, but Chelsea remain superior. Steven Gerrard faces a mental and physical battle at 34 to maintain his competitive level, though he remains one of Liverpool's most important players and shows no signs of quitting despite his slip that cost them the title last season.

A £45m educational facility is being built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, comprising primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after William McIlvanney, the renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was an English teacher who became a full-time writer in 1975, gaining recognition with his first novel Remedy Is None. Known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," he wrote the Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works including Docherty and The Big Man. He was also an influential poet, journalist, broadcaster, and political and sports columnist. McIlvanney died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near a swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated after a British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s was discovered on Monday. The evacuation affected three streets, with safety advice extended to residents within 500m of the device. An exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea (approximately half a mile). Residents were advised to stay indoors near walls and keep windows open. Small boat owners were prohibited from sailing, and ferry services experienced disruption. Authorities stressed the evacuation was precautionary with no immediate danger to the community. Due to the mine's deterioration, experts decided to move it to a safer location before safely disposing of it.

UK Sport has allocated £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, £2m less than Rio 2016. Several sports including archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby lost funding entirely. Badminton, despite winning a bronze medal at Rio 2016, had its funding completely removed, drawing criticism from Badminton England. Cycling's funding was cut by over £4m to £25.98m, while judo received a slight funding increase despite having the same medal target as badminton. Team GB has been set targets of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo, down from Rio's 67 and 147 respectively. Five new Olympic sports (baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing) and two new Paralympic sports (Para-taekwondo, Para-badminton) have been added, with £9m of funding still to be allocated pending further exploration of medal potential. UK Sport prioritized funding based on medal potential, with officials stating that under-investment across all sports would risk overall performance at the Games.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel with 90 rooms and two assisted-living apartment blocks containing 122 apartments across nine and seven-storey buildings. Councillors voted 7-3 in favour of the development, citing benefits to tourism and elderly housing, despite objections from English Heritage, which warned of "severe harm" to the conservation area. The applicant, The East Cliff Project LLP, received 246 letters of support but faced 49 objections from residents and the Ancient Monuments Society, who argued the Victorian hotels retained historic character despite alterations.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, a soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely, 24, outside a bar in Brecon while off-duty. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching and beating the unconscious Boyd before dragging his body away. Vallely, who had been drinking for seven hours and claimed to be the "hardest man in Brecon," will be sentenced on 8 December. His friend Aaeron Evans was acquitted of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Boyd's family described him as loving and loyal with a promising career ahead, and expressed that Vallely's actions have created an irreplaceable void in their lives.

Andrew Travers, chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement following a significant polling day error. Voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to examine the issue, which Travers attributed to electoral registration list problems. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over while permanent arrangements are made. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. The review will conclude by the end of May and will assess arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored first for Gateshead with a free-kick, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with an equally fine set-piece before half-time. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead in the second half with a header from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby noted the team was disappointing in the first half but improved their passing in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment that his team's second-half performance was not as strong as the first.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of people over 60 across 96 countries. Norway ranks first, while Afghanistan ranks last, followed by Mozambique in second-to-last place.

The OneWeb project aims to build a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband coverage with a focus on connecting schools. To achieve this scale, Airbus has revolutionized satellite manufacturing by adopting high-volume, low-cost assembly line methods similar to automotive production, targeting three units per shift at under $1 million each. The first assembly line opened in Toulouse, France, with two additional lines planned for Florida. The constellation will be deployed via over 20 Soyuz rockets launching clusters of 32-36 satellites into orbit 1,200km above Earth, with approximately 300 satellites operational by end of 2020/early 2021, over 600 by late 2021, and over 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb, registered in the UK's Channel Islands, has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is pursuing additional financing. The company has committed to de-orbiting satellites within two years and implementing debris mitigation measures to address concerns about space junk from mega-constellations. While other companies like SpaceX and Boeing are pursuing similar projects, not all will secure necessary funding, and Airbus believes OneWeb has first-mover advantage.

Mr Swinney, the Scottish government leader, stated that the UK government's spending review has created "unprecedented pressure" on Scottish public expenditure. While the UK government claims Scottish ministers will have £390m more to spend next year, the Scottish government argues that cuts since 2010 will result in a 12.5% lower discretionary budget in real terms by 2019-20. Mr Swinney emphasized that over £1bn in cuts remain until 2020 and committed to protecting schools, hospitals, and police services from austerity measures. He highlighted recent achievements including more police, lower crime, better schools, free university tuition, and record health budgets. The UK government responded that Scotland receives a stable £30bn block grant and suggested the Scottish government focus on new powers rather than grievances. Labour's Jackie Baillie called for a long-term budget with real anti-austerity measures and criticized the Scottish government's record.

People with severe disabilities face significant challenges accessing suitable toilet facilities when leaving their homes, often feeling isolated and unable to participate in everyday activities. Changing Places toilets are specialized facilities with enhanced features and extra space (12 square metres) designed to meet the needs of people who require two carers or hoists for assistance, unlike standard accessible toilets. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, though an estimated quarter of a million people need them. Campaigners, including parents like Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers, are pushing to make Changing Places guidelines compulsory in building regulations for newly built larger complexes such as shopping centres, cinemas, and sports stadiums, rather than remaining optional recommendations as they have been since 2009. Architect Vaila Morrison notes that making them compulsory would provide clarity, as designers tend to focus on mandatory requirements and can ignore recommendations. Some venues like Arsenal Football Club have successfully installed Changing Places toilets and reported positive responses. Financial and logistical barriers sometimes prevent existing buildings from installing these facilities, which is why campaigners are focusing on new construction.

Italian consumer organisations have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's counters that it shares risks and rewards with licensees. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union and European unions. Consumer groups claim McDonald's prevents franchisees from switching competitors through long-term contracts and charges above-market lease rates, resulting in higher consumer prices and reduced choice.
