When Ebola reached Sierra Leone, he and volunteers conducted three key activities: educating over 10,000 people about the disease in local languages, providing food and supplies to 11,000 people, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives. The country was declared virus-free after the outbreak killed nearly 4,000 people over 18 months. The man now focuses on investing in young people as agents of change.

About 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum faced auction to pay off a pottery firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign launched in September reached its target within a month. The Art Fund led the campaign and will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, where it will remain on display. The museum had inherited the pension bill after Waterford Wedgwood plc collapsed in 2009, went into administration in 2010, and faced a 2011 court ruling allowing the collection's sale to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. The successful fundraising prevented the collection from being "sold and scattered around the globe."

Dan Groves stated that details of a potential deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town and become a club director are still being finalized. Billericay currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points below the play-off positions. Wright, a 30-year-old former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here runner-up, has played non-league football for several clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who committed to investing £10,000 per week, and has signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, announced he would extend his tenure by one year beyond his original 2018 departure date, rather than serving until 2021 as some had speculated. While he recognized the professional challenges of leaving during Brexit negotiations, his decision was primarily driven by personal circumstances: in 2018, two of his four daughters will be completing their A-levels and GCSEs, and his family plans to return to Canada to access its education system. Carney emphasized that the role requires total attention and devotion, and that personal factors were the only considerations in his decision. He clarified that his choice should not be interpreted as reflecting any government policy or tension with the Prime Minister, and that by 2019, the Article 50 process should be complete for his successor to manage.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Jamille Matt turned in a chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized from a corner when Kurtis Guthrie prodded in from close range. Blackpool had chances to win, including a missed header from Tom Aldred in the 75th minute. The match ended with Colchester reduced to 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, teaches children in P6 and P7 how to cope with change and prepare for the stresses of the transfer test and transition to secondary school. The programme consists of interactive workshops that raise awareness of emotional wellbeing, encourage pupils to seek help when distressed, and help them identify sources of support, while also providing teachers with training in promoting emotional wellbeing. Following a pilot in five schools, the charity hopes to roll it out across Northern Ireland. The workshops teach practical coping strategies such as breathing exercises and relaxation techniques. According to the chief inspector of schools, strengthening resilience in young people is a key challenge for Northern Ireland's education system, as pupils face complex challenges in their social and emotional development.

The Fawley power station, commissioned in 1971 on Southampton Water, closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation. Developers Fawley Waterside purchased the 300-acre site in 2016 and plan a £1bn "merchant city" development centered around the existing 198-metre chimney, which would become the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The development will feature a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. An outline planning permission application is expected later this year, with construction potentially beginning in 2018.

At the Hong Kong track cycling championships, 23-year-old Latham won Great Britain's second medal with a bronze in the men's scratch race, chasing down gold medallist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver medallist Lucass Liss of Germany. This followed Elinor Barker's earlier silver medal in the women's scratch. However, GB's men's team pursuit was beaten to bronze by Italy, and the women's team pursuit finished fifth in the heats. Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final, while Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was knocked out in the first round of the women's sprint by China's Lin Junhong. Marchant expressed disappointment but noted her focus is on preparation for Tokyo.

Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell, is returning to EastEnders for a brief return to film scenes with Dame Barbara's final episodes. His character's mother, Peggy, has returned to the show after leaving in 2010 and has been told her cancer has returned. She will die from the disease in emotional scenes to be screened in spring. Kemp's return will reunite the Mitchell brothers (Grant and Phil, played by Steve McFadden) with their mother for the last time. Grant Mitchell was a memorable character who arrived in 1990 and was involved in significant family dramas, including an affair with his brother's wife and various relationship entanglements with the Mitchell family.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as Tottenham Hotspur lost to Liverpool at Anfield. Manager Pochettino criticized his team's poor start and lack of desire, stating it is difficult to fight for the Premier League with such a performance. Spurs have won just twice on the road since September 24 and won only once in their past 17 away meetings against top-six rivals. Pochettino warned that if Chelsea extend their lead to 12 points, it would be a significant problem. Former midfielder Danny Murphy noted Spurs' inconsistency, highlighting their strong defensive record but poor away form compared to their home performances, and suggested they should have maintained their back-three formation used against other top sides.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governorships in Nigeria's Saturday elections, marking the biggest defeat for the ruling Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. This follows the PDP's loss of the presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, but lost key northern states and control of Adamawa. However, the PDP retained Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC failed to win in any of the five oil-producing states, which poses concerns for Buhari regarding potential militant disruption of oil production. The elections saw 66 violent incidents at polling stations, primarily in southern states, though overall they were more peaceful than previous years. One result remains outstanding in Taraba, while Imo state's election was declared inconclusive. The PDP's decline is attributed to voter desire for change after 16 years in power, defections to the APC, corruption allegations, and failure to address the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (July 19-22) is introducing an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online content from signs and posters at the site. The app will provide videos and band interviews viewable on phones and tablets. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. According to director Caroline Maclennan, the augmented reality feature enhances the festival experience for on-site visitors while enabling global audiences to interact with the festival, access information and interviews, purchase tickets, and experience the festival's atmosphere remotely.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated by the Department for Education. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, have been warned they could lose funding unless concerns are addressed by 4 July. The concerns include failing to promote spiritual, moral, social and cultural development, less favourable treatment of non-Muslims, segregation of boys and girls, and inadequate vetting of external speakers, including one with known extremist views. Ofsted's investigation into 21 schools alleged to be targeted as part of a hardline Muslim takeover found a "culture of fear and intimidation" in Birmingham schools. A head teacher reported that parents undermined her authority during inspections. Saltley School, the only local authority school in special measures, will receive a temporary governing board. Some parents have criticized the Ofsted reports as biased and accused inspectors of pushing their own agendas.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a 38-year-old British-Iranian dual national, was sentenced to five years in prison in September on charges of plotting to topple the Iranian government, which she denies. Her appeal hearing took place in Tehran on Wednesday in secret proceedings. Her husband Richard Ratcliffe has criticized the UK government's lack of action and expressed concern about the unpredictable outcome, which could result in her sentence being quashed, reduced, or increased. Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe has spent time in solitary confinement since her arrest at Tehran Airport in April, during which she experienced suicidal thoughts and began a hunger strike, though her condition improved after being moved out of solitary confinement. Her two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran after her passport was confiscated and is being cared for by her grandparents. Mr Ratcliffe believes his wife is being used as a bargaining chip in a diplomatic dispute between Iran and the UK. Amnesty International UK has designated her a "prisoner of conscience" and called for her immediate release.

Vincent Barker (Vinnie) died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, is charged with gross negligence manslaughter, which she denies. The prosecution alleges that Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the eye test and refer him for further investigation. This failure allegedly prevented the detection of fluid buildup in his brain that increased skull pressure and caused his death. The prosecution contends Vinnie's death was preventable and that Rose's conduct fell below the standard expected of a competent optometrist, constituting criminal negligence.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he found online between September 2013 and September 2014, and filming the encounters. He was also convicted of sending sexually explicit material to the victim's sister and father on Christmas Day 2014 and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. The victim reported feeling "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson hitting 56, Gary Wilson contributing 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield adding 39 runs. Afghanistan won the first T20 match, scoring 171-4 with two overs remaining, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Paul Stirling was dismissed early for a duck, while Afghanistan's opening pair of Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27) put on a 51-run stand. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23. Porterfield acknowledged Ireland fell short of their target of 180 and felt their bowling execution was lacking. Ireland also lost paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem for the T20s, though he is expected to return for the five ODIs starting March 15. The teams will meet again in the second T20 on Friday at the same venue.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for 22-year-old striker Neymar from Santos, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. Including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and a tax payment, Neymar's total cost to the club reached £106.8m. Barcelona faced investigation into the transfer after allegations that the actual cost was greater than the initially stated 57m euros. A Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations. Barcelona denied any tax-related crime and made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros, maintaining they had met their original fiscal obligations. Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned following accusations of misappropriating money related to the transfer. Neymar scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona that season.

Two British tourists, David Miller (24) and Hannah Witheridge (23), were found dead on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun (both 21), are being held as suspects and are alleged to have confessed to the killings. They are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if convicted. Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to review the investigation alongside Thai police and have now completed their work to compile a report and update the families. The UK Foreign Office had expressed concerns about DNA verification and allegations of suspect mistreatment. Post-mortem examinations showed Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police report that DNA found on Witheridge matched samples from the suspects.

VR technology is increasingly being used by journalists, teachers, healthcare workers, and retailers to enhance understanding and engagement. The National Autistic Society created a VR film showing what it's like to live with autism, experienced through a shopping centre journey. Alzheimer's Research UK released a similar film demonstrating challenges faced by dementia patients. Retailers like Ikea and Westfield use VR to showcase products, with Ikea's kitchen app proving unexpectedly popular. In healthcare, surgeon Dr Shafi Ahmed livestreamed a virtual surgery to 5,000 people across 14 countries, and VR is being used to treat phobias and PTSD. Google Expeditions takes students on virtual trips worldwide. Educational developers are creating language-learning apps and exploring how VR headsets can monitor student engagement. However, cost and computing power requirements remain barriers to widespread school adoption.

The "black box" from a Russian Su-24 jet shot down on November 24 was opened in Moscow. The investigation head reported that flight information appeared to be missing from the device. The jet's downing has escalated tensions between Russia and Turkey, with the two countries disputing whether the aircraft was in Turkish or Syrian airspace when hit. Turkey claims the jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace, while Russia maintains it was shot down within Syrian territory. One pilot was killed and the navigator rescued, and a Russian marine died during the rescue operation. Russia has imposed sanctions on Turkey, including a ban on package holidays, and demanded an apology. An analysis of the black box data is expected next week.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with victory likely securing their place in next summer's finals in the Netherlands. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland at number 20 in the world, are also unbeaten with four wins from four. Forward Erin Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, expressed her determination to reach a major competition after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup. Evans noted that Scotland are in a strong position to qualify automatically as one of the best six group runners-up. She highlighted the value of having 12 squad members playing outside Scotland, including five in England, four in Sweden, and two in the United States, stating that playing in top leagues like Germany's Bundesliga improves the national team's competitiveness.

A Commission on Local Tax Reform reviewed local taxation systems worldwide and found no single solution to fix defects in Scotland's council tax system. Property taxes are used by most OECD countries and considered stable and difficult to avoid, but create confusion about whether they tax wealth or fund services, and are perceived as unfair because they're not linked to income. Local income taxes are seen as fairer but create fluctuating revenue for authorities and limit flexibility in setting rates. The commission, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, will conduct a public consultation before publishing its report in autumn. The Scottish government considers the current council tax system unfair and is seeking fairer alternatives through the commission's recommendations.

Apple has implemented two-step verification for its iCloud backup service in response to celebrity photo thefts caused by third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after logging in on a new device, preventing access to iCloud and iTunes/App Store purchases without it. However, the feature remains opt-in rather than default.

The software vendor acknowledged Apple's changes are secure and prevent his workaround. Apple also added email notifications when backups begin downloading. Security experts recommend making two-factor authentication the default across Apple, Microsoft, and Google rather than optional. Concerns remain about recovery keys being lost or stolen, potentially locking users out of their accounts. Apple's CEO stated the company plans to more aggressively encourage two-factor authentication adoption and stronger passwords.

UKIP won May's election with campaign spending of £2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 and came third. Labour came second with spending of £1,027,339. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 and lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, while the Green Party spent £534,249 and came fourth. The SNP spent £267,372. These six parties spent a combined total of £9,347,087 during the campaign period from 23 January to 22 May. Cost per vote varied significantly: UKIP at 68p, Conservatives at 79p, Labour at 26p, the Lib Dems at £1.45, and the Green Party at 43p. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has joined National League rivals after cancelling his Barrow contract by mutual consent. The ex-Aldershot and Exeter player, who has also played in Italy, may face his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams and has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, with his move subject to international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson as a leader with the stature and voice he sought, and described Keating as young, raw, but hungry to prove himself. The Gulls currently sit four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Tistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The BHA's acting chief veterinary officer noted such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds, ridden by Leighton Aspell and owned by Trevor Hemmings, had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Though he had experienced post-race ataxia symptoms in the past causing him to overheat and wobble, he showed no such symptoms on the day of his death. His trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime."

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as three veteran MSPs—Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie—delivered farewell speeches before stepping down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse rather than divided, welcomed the Scotland Bill's transfer of powers to Holyrood, but argued it fell short of referendum campaign pledges. He concluded with humor, joking about competing with the Cheltenham racecourse and wishing candidates good luck "with varying degrees of enthusiasm." McNeil warned that parliament must learn from Westminster regarding accountability and scrutiny, while Goldie joked about missing her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens playing the Beast and Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle's father. Luke Evans will play Gaston, and Josh Gad will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. An unnamed star will play Mrs Potts, the role originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Bill Condon will direct the film, which will begin shooting at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service will announce its charging decisions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives on 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans were killed in the disaster at an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest on 15 April 1989. Last year's inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. Evidence files relating to 23 suspects have been referred to the CPS: 15 relate to Operation Resolve investigation into the causes of the disaster, and 8 relate to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct by South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police. Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS, will inform relatives of the decisions at a private meeting in Warrington. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed that families seek accountability and remain determined to pursue justice.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls. A former inmate described the facility as "notorious" for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A nearby resident witnessed packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks. The former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband to prison windows, though the Ministry of Justice stated there was no evidence of drones at the Chelmsford site. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the problem and stated the Justice Secretary has asked them to examine how prisons can be better equipped to prevent contraband. Laws have been introduced allowing up to two years imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady of 20 years, suffered serious head injuries when struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside a school in Kempston in December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red traffic light, though he accepts hitting Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The prosecutor states traffic in the other direction had stopped, but Wright's vehicle did not. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse in court, acknowledging the impact on his victim and her family. The trial is ongoing.

Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. She will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast because her university exams in May conflict with the April event, as she is completing her final year of veterinary medicine studies. She expressed disappointment about missing the Games but prioritized completing her degree. Muir identified the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and indicated she believes she has multiple future Olympic opportunities ahead.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 while walking home from a Christmas party. A search began in Chapelizod, Dublin at a three-acre woodland site beside the R112 near the River Liffey, expected to take several weeks and involve excavations. Enhanced CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance shows Deely speaking with an unidentified man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where Deely worked and was retrieving an umbrella. The same man was later captured on CCTV following Deely on Haddington Road. A detective review team released the footage in April and appealed for the man to come forward, but he remains unidentified as of the search date.

Del Potro defeated Swiss player Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in his first Grand Slam match since 2014, following more than two years away due to wrist injuries. The 27-year-old Argentine, currently ranked 165th, will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next and is in the same draw half as Andy Murray.

In other matches, Nick Kyrgios came from two sets down to beat Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 in a rain-affected match. Kyrgios will play Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with Lopez having defeated Fabio Fognini 3-6 6-7 6-3 6-3 6-3. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also secured routine victories.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against Caf during the 2015 Nations Cup, but avoided disqualification by apologizing. The dispute stemmed from a contentious penalty awarded to hosts Equatorial Guinea in Tunisia's quarter-final match, which Tunisia felt was unjustifiable. Tunisia clarified it did not accuse Caf or the referee of corruption, but criticized the referee selection. Morocco was initially banned from 2017 qualifying after refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced their fine from $1m to $50,000. Both nations have now been cleared to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia drawn in Group A against Togo, Liberia and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F against Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome.

McLaren, a legendary F1 team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently in decline. The slump began in 2013 with chassis design problems, and now the Honda power unit is the main issue despite improvements to the car itself. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998. McLaren has a history of cycles between triumph and decline—from early success under founder Bruce McLaren, to dominance in 1984-85 and the Honda era, to recent struggles. Ron Dennis, who built the team into a powerhouse, returned to control after the disastrous 2013 season. Despite current poor grid positions, the team has two world champions including Fernando Alonso, who rejoined in 2015 hoping to win a third title. Dennis believes McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again, though currently the team relies mainly on belief rather than results.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014 following a sudden death. Police found several people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, and James Thomas faced one such charge. The judge found the premises had not been run properly and was operating well into the morning. O'Neill, described as having "an appalling record," was fined £3,000 and the bar was ordered closed for three months. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season by hitting eight three-pointers in the Golden State Warriors' 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry scored 45 points with nine assists, bringing his season total to 280 made three-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272. Klay Thompson contributed 26 points as the Warriors rallied from 13 points down. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol recording 16 points and 15 rebounds and the Bulls outscoring Miami 57-27 in the second half.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic met YouTube star Bas van Velzen at Melwood, believing he was a competition winner. Van Velzen, known for uploading free-kick videos and becoming a YouTube sensation, surprised the players by showcasing impressive dead-ball skills rather than being a regular fan. The Dutch free-kick specialist impressed the Liverpool quartet with his striking ability and later revealed one of Balotelli's infamous slogans as a final surprise.

BRCA1 gene carriers diagnosed with breast cancer can reduce their risk of death by over 60 percent through oophorectomy (ovarian removal), as demonstrated by a Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA mutations. The study found a 20-year survival rate of 77.4 percent for the entire group, with a 62 percent reduction in breast cancer death for BRCA1 carriers who underwent the procedure, and a 65 percent reduction in death from all causes. The protective effect was most significant when surgery occurred within two years of diagnosis. Women carrying mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes face a 50-80 percent lifetime risk of breast cancer and severe threat of ovarian tumors. The procedure was not effective for BRCA2 carriers. Researchers recommend oophorectomy become part of treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer.

Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak train No. 80 (the Carolinian) shortly before 10 am on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The train was traveling from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk-Southern property when the accident occurred. None of the 166 passengers aboard were injured, though one passenger who fell ill during the approximately two hours and 45-minute delay received treatment. The couple may have been living in a homeless camp according to a man who knew them. The train resumed its route after the delay.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years as an informant after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s. He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work but has not received it. Toro became one of the DEA's most valuable assets, helping carry out undercover stings worldwide and providing information that aided in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. After declining health forced him to retire, Toro is now facing deportation and living illegally in the U.S. The DEA refused to assist him with citizenship after he went public about his situation. Toro fears returning to Colombia would result in his death within hours due to his past work against major drug traffickers. His temporary visa expired on January 1, and he remains in limbo unable to secure a green card or passport, which prevents him from collecting social security benefits.

The US internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for allegedly using the new '.sucks' domain to extort celebrities and companies seeking to protect their reputations. Major brands including YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have had their names registered under this domain. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have reportedly paid to have their names removed. Vox Populi charges approximately $2,499 annually for '.sucks' domains to trademark holders and celebrities, with plans to offer them to the general public for $10 per year starting in September. An advisory panel of major companies and industry groups has called the scheme "predatory" and a "shakedown," prompting ICANN to request that US and Canadian regulators determine whether Vox Populi's actions are illegal. ICANN stated it could declare the company in breach of contract if illegal activity is found.

A baby boy's body was found floating in a pond in Norfolk in 1988. Twenty-seven years later, DNA analysis led police to identify his mother, who was arrested on suspicion of infanticide. She revealed that she had concealed her pregnancy and delivered the stillborn baby herself, then placed his body in the pond. A second post-mortem found no evidence of foul play. The infanticide charge was dropped, though the Crown Prosecution Service is considering charges related to failing to register the birth and preventing lawful burial. The baby was reburied and named Peter after the church where he was laid to rest, with a new headstone provided by a stillbirth support charity.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks after unlawfully imprisoning him in 2010. Young mistakenly believed Hicks planned to leave without paying and drove him back to the taxi rank against his wishes. When Hicks jumped from the moving vehicle traveling at over 20mph, he suffered severe brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires 24-hour care from his mother. A high court judge ruled Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and was liable for damages, though the exact compensation amount—expected to be around 50 percent of the family's request and "hundreds of thousands of pounds"—will be determined at a further hearing. The judge applied a 50 percent reduction in damages due to Hicks' decision to jump from the moving car, plus an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms produced tornado reports. A tornado was spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, and moved northeast away from the city. Additional tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. A tornado may have also touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, with reports of wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, and roof damage. Severe weather expert Chad Myers noted that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Baseball-sized hail was also reported in the region. Additional storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face off in a middleweight clash in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold is seeking his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot, planning to dominate Machida by cutting off his movement and forcing him to fight Rockhold's style rather than Machida's evasive approach. Rockhold believes he has significant advantages across all aspects of fighting—takedowns, kicks, and punches—while Machida has limited options on the feet and ground. Despite mutual respect between the fighters, Rockhold is confident in his superior speed and hip movement. Machida, coming off a recent victory, is also confident he can win by applying his technique and strategy, and believes the winner deserves a title shot. Both fighters have prepared extensively for the bout.

A light general aviation aircraft landed without deploying its landing gear at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane touched down on its belly and skidded along the runway, with its propellers striking the tarmac and bouncing. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off again. The 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, who had been flying for nearly 50 years and was accompanied by his dog, successfully flew the damaged aircraft 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where it landed safely. The incident was caused by human error—the pilot forgot to deploy the landing gear. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performances this season but pledged to support the midfielder until the end of the campaign. Toure, earning £220,000 per week with two years remaining on his contract, has faced criticism as Manchester City's Premier League title defense has faltered. Pellegrini dismissed suggestions that Toure needs rest and stated the player does not believe he has performed well. City face West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany due to injury, with the team having collected only 18 points from a possible 39. Goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the players share responsibility for underperformance but expressed confidence in Pellegrini's management. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has cautioned left-back Aaron Cresswell against joining Manchester City, citing examples of English players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who saw limited playing time after moving to the club.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive who lived in Britain for over 20 years under an assumed name, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence from 1999 was dropped. He was convicted in absentia for his role as a "man of honour" in the Cosa Nostra, taking bribes from builders in Palermo. After losing his extradition battle in February, it emerged that his sentence expired in October 2014 under Italian law, which extinguishes sentences once more than double the penalty period has passed. His European arrest warrant is being withdrawn, and the case will be discharged once paperwork is finalized at Westminster Magistrates' Court. Legal experts criticized the lengthy and costly proceedings, noting that Italian authorities should have communicated the sentence's expiration earlier. The CPS acknowledged making an administrative error by failing to serve appeal papers on time in March 2014, which contributed to the delay that allowed the sentence to expire.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The Paul Nicholls-trained horse is bracketed with Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race before his retirement as a professional jockey. McCoy previously announced his intention to quit riding after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. The race features a seven-runner line-up, including Mick Channon's Somersby.

Forty years after her daughter Marcia's murder in 1975, Virginia Trimble Ritter recently viewed crime scene photos of her child's body for the first time. Marcia was raped and strangled to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett, whose body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter's then-husband had advised against viewing the photos, and she declined for decades even after Barrett's conviction 33 years later. Last year, she requested to see the photos from the lead investigator and viewed them on his laptop, describing the disturbing details of her daughter's injuries. Marcia's body was discovered in a garage near her home, and the case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence matched him. He was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one, believes he will eventually win the Masters to complete the career Grand Slam, joining only five other players who have achieved this feat. At 25 years old, McIlroy views winning Augusta as a career-long goal and considers it unthinkable that he won't accomplish it. He has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, but feels the course suits his game and he could win multiple times there. McIlroy credits his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta—when he shot 80 with a four-shot lead—as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. He subsequently won his first major at the 2012 US Open and has since won three more majors. McIlroy plans to use the golf course as a sanctuary from the pressure and hype surrounding the tournament.

This passage summarizes trending stories from a busy week online. Key stories include: four rainbows appearing over the New York area after heavy rain, China cracking down on the practice of hiring exotic dancers at wakes, actor Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK interview about his private life, a viral lip-plumping challenge inspired by Kylie Jenner using the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge, 102-year-old Alice Barker traveling back in time with filmmakers, a controversial prom proposal involving bomb references that raised racism accusations, casting announcements for "Beauty and the Beast" and "Black Mass," a pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military father photobombing his son.

Over the past 12 months, 272 children with foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England after being brain damaged by prenatal alcohol exposure. However, experts warn the actual number affected is likely much higher—research by the World Health Organisation suggests at least one in 100 babies born in the UK (approximately 7,500 annually) could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems from maternal drinking. Foetal alcohol syndrome is a permanent condition that does not improve, and affected children may face disabilities including difficulty with motor skills, lack of danger awareness, and inability to live independently. Associated medical issues include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government currently advises pregnant women not to drink, or if they do, to consume no more than two units twice weekly. Experts advocate for stricter guidance recommending complete abstinence during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender nicknamed "boomerang boy," attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 at 8 pm while wielding an axe. Store owner Sab Dhillon tackled McKerry to the ground, and his wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. Police arrived and arrested McKerry minutes later. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in prison. McKerry earned his nickname in the 1990s due to his pattern of committing crimes and returning home; he had been arrested 80 times by age 15 and accumulated numerous convictions including shoplifting, burglary, and aggravated vehicle-taking.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35)—have been charged with gang rape following an alleged sexual assault on April 10 at a Canadian naval barracks in Halifax, Nova Scotia. They appeared in court in Dartmouth where they were granted bail of over £2,000 each with conditions requiring them to surrender their passports, remain in Nova Scotia, live at the Stadacona naval base, and continue working for the Royal Navy. The alleged victim, a woman in her early 20s from Halifax, was at an alcohol-fuelled party at the barracks after the sailors returned from a hockey tournament. The men are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, offences punishable by up to 14 years in prison. They must return to court on May 27 and are forbidden from contacting the victim and six witnesses.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son RJ is one of only 70 people worldwide with Netherton's syndrome, a rare genetic skin disease that causes red, scaly, inflamed skin resembling burns or scalding. Mrs. Jackson regularly applies creams and Vaseline to manage his symptoms and prevent skin drying. While shopping, she was surrounded by armed police after a stranger reported her for child abuse, mistaking his condition for injury. RJ and his mother face ongoing discrimination, including denial of entry to play centers and cruel taunts from adults and bullies who believe his skin is burned. Mrs. Jackson discovered RJ's diagnosis through a Facebook support group after doctors initially could not identify the condition. Though there is no cure, symptoms typically improve with age. Despite the challenges and public ignorance, Mrs. Jackson emphasizes that RJ is a happy, beautiful child who loves playing and has supportive siblings.

The Protein World "Are you beach body ready?" advertisement featuring a bikini-clad model on London Underground posters has sparked significant controversy. Feminists and body image campaigners, along with over 50,000 petition signers, objected to the campaign for promoting unhealthy body image and suggesting only women resembling the model are beach-ready. The Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints. Several posters were defaced by protesters. Transport for London confirmed removal of the posters after their three-week paid advertising period ended. Protein World defended the campaign as fitness-focused and claimed the image was unphotoshopped, while engaging in defensive social media responses. TV presenter Susanna Reid called the advert "anxiety inducing" during an interview with the company's head of global marketing. The company reported receiving threats and a bomb threat to police. Despite the backlash, Protein World stated they would not change their advertising methods. A protest rally was organized for May 2 in Hyde Park.

Rail firms are implementing fare increases of up to 87 percent shortly after the general election, contradicting pledges by major party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western urgently review its decision to nearly double fares on the London to Cotswolds route through his constituency, where off-peak returns from Charlbury to London will rise from £33.30 to £62.40 from May 17. Train companies can increase "unregulated" fares three times yearly, which comprise around half their revenue. Other significant hikes include a 24.5 percent increase on Virgin's Stafford to Liverpool route and a 22 percent rise on Manchester to Stoke services. Virgin claims its overall west coast fare increase is only 1.65 percent and that most increases affect fares already 20 percent cheaper than competitors. Research shows hundreds of "anytime" and "off-peak" returns rose 40 percent in January, with increases concentrated on day-purchase tickets and rural routes.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being struck in the face with a brick thrown by vandals at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred on April 18 when Young and his newlywed wife Elaine, 54, were inside their home. After thugs began pelting stones at their front window, Young opened the door to confront them and was hit directly in the left eye by a brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. The couple, who married three weeks prior and met 14 months ago, now plan to move away as they no longer feel safe. Police launched an investigation but found no apparent motive, suggesting the attackers may have been "messing around."

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension through the end of the 2016 season following his successful return from injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that resulted in his father's death in April 2014. After undergoing ankle surgery, he made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season. Derbyshire's elite performance director praised Poynton's character and dedication during his recovery and expressed confidence in his continued form.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. During his treatment, which included 80 days of chemotherapy, kidney tumor removal surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley decorated his protective radiotherapy mask like a ninja turtle to feel braver. His story gained international attention, and Nickelodeon sent him ninja turtle gifts. After battling the disease for a year, doctors declared him cancer-free. He will undergo regular check-ups to monitor his health and has become the face of Cancer Research UK's kids and teens campaign.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, is being pursued by both the Republic of Ireland and England for international representation. Tim Sherwood, Villa's manager, believes Grealish should prioritize his club career and securing a permanent place in Villa's first team before making an international decision. Sherwood praised Grealish's performance in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, noting his confidence and dribbling ability. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season, and he is currently undecided between the two countries. Grealish's father Kevin supports Sherwood's view that his son should focus on club football first, with international opportunities to follow.

Private jet travel is a luxury industry worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US in 2013 and 705,000 in Europe. Landing fees at airports vary dramatically, with the most expensive being Haneda Airport in Tokyo at £4,559, followed by Narita International Airport at £3,728 and Kansai International Airport at £3,594. Other notably expensive airports include Toronto Pearson (£3,461), Darwin International (£3,059), Bristol Airport (£2,929), Dublin Airport (£2,729), and La Guardia in New York (£2,630). Peak travel times occur during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with costs reaching $38,000-$54,000 for round-trip flights. Popular private jet routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas (£2,890) and Milan to Rome (approximately $5,880 one way).

Katie Gallegos from Oregon took her two dogs, Cooper (a Labrador) and Daisy (a small female pup), to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy ate slowly and delicately, Cooper consumed his entire cone in one bite, as he always eats very quickly. The video of this incident has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers found it cute and hilarious, while others criticized Gallegos for feeding dogs ice cream. Gallegos defended the practice, stating Cooper is healthy and athletic, and that her previous dog ate ice cream weekly and lived to 19 years old. Daisy receives only occasional small portions due to her size. The dogs have also visited Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," which Gallegos clarifies contains only whipped cream, no coffee.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year deal. He joined the club as assistant manager last summer and took over as interim manager in February when Allan Johnston departed. Since taking over, Locke has won six of seven games. He will address the media at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son for wearing essential oils (manufactured by doTERRA) that she applies to help keep him calm and focused. Teachers claimed the oils smelled and distracted other students. The mother received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem for staff and students. She refused to stop using them, arguing natural products should be acceptable. The Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend the child, characterizing it as a health issue. The family uses oils with scents including lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A fire destroyed a 90-condo beachside apartment complex called the Sandpiper in Westhampton on Wednesday at 3 pm. The fire was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings and caused the structure to collapse. Twelve fire crews responded but were unable to enter the summer homes to combat the flames, instead using cranes to approach the fire. The cause is under investigation, with authorities examining claims that it started near a parked car. Smoke was visible from three miles away. The complex, which operates as holiday homes from May to November, resulted in residents losing their belongings, including building manager Rob Taber who lived and worked there.

The Queen, at 88 years old, was spotted riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, through Windsor Great Park. She rode without a helmet, preferring a silk scarf instead, citing her hair as the reason. The Queen has been an accomplished horsewoman since receiving her first Shetland pony, Peggy, at age four. Though she has reduced her riding in recent years due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and continues to breed fell ponies at Hampton Court and highland ponies at Balmoral. Some of her horses are now ridden by her grandchildren. Fell ponies, an ancient breed that has roamed Cumbria since the Neolithic period, were historically used as pack animals and in mining before becoming popular family riding ponies in the 1950s.

A noise dispute between two Brisbane neighbors escalated fatally when 28-year-old Phillip Pama allegedly punched 55-year-old Leon Yeaman in the head, killing him. Yeaman was making noise in his yard around 9 pm on Thursday night, while Pama, a shift worker, was sleeping before his 3 am warehouse shift. When Pama confronted Yeaman about the noise, the situation escalated and Pama struck him. According to Pama's defense lawyer, Pama was being pushed while throwing the punch blindly and did not intentionally aim at Yeaman's head. Paramedics were unable to revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead around 11 pm. Pama was charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail with restrictions including passport surrender, a curfew, and twice-weekly police reporting. The case returns to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old student, Damian Vanya, following their breakup. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) and specified brutal details including breaking his arms and legs, damaging his kidneys to cause bleeding, and then finishing him herself. Police conducted a sting operation with an undercover officer posing as a hitman, secretly filming the exchange. After handing over expense money, Simonova was arrested and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison. The student ended their year-long relationship to be with a classmate and expressed relief at her arrest.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, revealed that he prays daily but never discusses football with God or his wife. The 52-year-old stated he separates his professional and family life, attending church only when he feels the need, though regularly when in Portugal. Mourinho emphasized that despite his competitive sideline persona, he considers himself a good person and family man who supports others. He acknowledged making mistakes in his emotionally competitive professional area but stressed that professional life is only part of a person. The father-of-two and his family have worked as ambassadors with the World Food Programme against hunger.

Bob Barker, the legendary host of "The Price is Right," returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1. At 91 years old, Barker hosted the opening segment, including the "Lucky Seven" game, before handing over duties to current host Drew Carey for the remainder of the episode. Barker had originally hosted the game show for 35 years before retiring in 2007, and demonstrated he remained sharp and capable during his brief return.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested at 12:30 am on Friday in southeastern Washington D.C. after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who was posted with the foreign missions branch of the Secret Service, had his security clearance revoked and was placed on leave following his arrest. He was scheduled for arraignment Friday afternoon. This arrest follows another incident two days prior involving a high-ranking supervisor accused of misconduct, and comes amid an ongoing investigation into a March 4 incident where two agency officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life at a safari park by leaving his car and approaching a male lion to within 10 feet to capture photographs. Armed only with a camera, Saeed lay on the ground to photograph the lion, believing this was the only way to capture the animal's character and status. The lion's hunting instincts were triggered, and when the camera's shutter sound alerted the lion to Saeed's presence, the animal aggressively jumped toward him, forcing Saeed to scramble back to his car. Saeed acknowledged the extreme danger of the encounter and stated he would not attempt such a risky photograph again.

An unnamed woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn's Gravesend section and was pronounced dead that evening. With no identification on her body, the NYPD released images of a distinctive tattoo on her right leg—the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose—in hopes of identifying her. Police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death and are asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. Unable to afford property, they spent a year and a half constructing a wood and steel home that cost approximately $25,000. The truck home, now parked on a lot in Nelson, New Zealand, features aromatic cypress wood interiors, a wood-fired stove, and stained glass windows. The couple lives nearly self-sufficiently, powered primarily by solar panels (resulting in a $25 first power bill), with water sourced from a nearby spring and gas-powered heating and hot water. They are surrounded by nature with trees and a babbling brook on their property and plan to build another similar home in the future.

Children who share iPads in class perform significantly better on early literacy tests than those who don't use iPads or use them individually. Researcher Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University studied 352 kindergarten students and found that shared iPad users scored approximately 30 points higher than individual users and non-iPad users. Blackwell attributes this success to collaborative learning around the technology rather than collaboration alone, and suggests schools should reconsider how tablets are used in earlier grades to maximize effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its two front legs. The piglet, nicknamed "super pig," belongs to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, China, and was discovered to be missing its hind legs when Ms. Duan noticed something unusual during feeding time. Despite its disability, the piglet has mastered balancing and foraging for food while interacting normally with its littermates. The heartwarming video of the piglet's movements has captured widespread attention online. This follows a similar case in China where a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo became a popular attraction after learning to hop on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was struck by Francesco Dracone's car during a pit stop on lap 25. Dracone spun while exiting the pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, receiving stitches for a leg cut before being released. The race was affected by rain, causing traction issues for many cars. Dracone did not finish the race and finished 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, just four days after their marriage. CCTV footage shows him smashing her head into concrete aving 11 times, punching her face 10 times, and then shooting her in the face five times at point-blank range. He confessed to the crime, stating he was jealous of men looking at her. After the murder, he stole a neighbor's car but was apprehended by police following a crash. Officers found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bullet-proof vest in his vehicle. He now faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her personal struggle with mental illness, including severe anxiety that brought her close to taking her own life. She explained that a combination of mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and family isolation led her to feel her life was not worth living and that she couldn't see a way forward. Wilson has since found peace with her condition and now accepts she is an anxious person. She believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and advocates for better acknowledgment of this connection to address the rising rates of stress and anxiety affecting Australian women. According to Beyond Blue, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

Elena Curtin of Portland, Oregon, was seven months pregnant when she was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar. She found the ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom and beat her with a crowbar when the woman refused to leave. Prosecutors dropped the charge because Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage," citing Oregon law that allows physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. Curtin gave birth in January and was set to go to trial in Multnomah County Circuit Court, where conviction would have resulted in a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years. She is now living with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California, was filmed reacting negatively to broccoli mixed in with her treats. Upon eating the vegetable, she made a disgusted expression and spit it out on the floor. The passage notes she lives with two children and also enjoys sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official Hong Kong website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was intended for the bank's Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was shut down after the awards were scrapped in 2011. When the domain registration was allowed to expire, a porn site took over the URL address. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website after discovering the error and stated it had no association with the external site. The bank assured the public that its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old boy in Maryland called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home in Clinton on Sunday morning, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister in a second-floor bedroom. During the 11-minute call, Marcus remained calm, provided firefighters with directions to their location, and comforted his sister. Prince George's County firefighters entered through the home, broke a window, and rescued both children. Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out the window to another rescuer and gave his gas mask to the girl. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while the three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae has been photographed lighting up Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay on the NSW south coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured images of the neon glow illuminating the beach, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The phenomenon is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, typically due to natural causes. This carnivorous algae preys on diatoms and produces the luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and experts indicate there is no cause for concern about the algae.

New genetic tests can identify aggressive breast cancer tumors and help patients avoid unnecessary chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened in a lab to determine recurrence risk within days. For some women, tests like Endopredict can show recurrence risk as low as 5%, comparable to or better than chemotherapy outcomes. While most breast cancer patients routinely receive chemotherapy after tumor removal despite its severe side effects, experts recognize that some women face lower recurrence risks and may not need the treatment. These tests, currently available privately for about £2,500, may soon become available on the NHS. Medical professionals argue the cost is justified by savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy, and the tests enable patients to make informed treatment decisions rather than receiving chemotherapy by default.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over nine years, with HMS Ocean accounting for five emergency evacuations. At least 18 other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A strict "no touching" rule at sea suggests most pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 due to pregnancy, with 102 women evacuated from Iraq. Military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, comprising approximately 9 percent of personnel in 2014.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's prime minister's residence in Tokyo on Wednesday. The drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material. The discovery has raised terrorism concerns in Japan, particularly regarding potential drone threats at upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. The incident occurred the same day a Japanese court approved restarting two nuclear reactors at the Sendai plant, a decision that remains unpopular among many Japanese citizens. Currently, Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but not over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not present at the time, as he was attending a conference in Indonesia.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang Province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work every day on his motorbike because she suffers from Alzheimer's disease and he fears she will get lost if left alone. After his father passed away earlier this year and with his wife working in another city and son still in school, he became her sole caregiver. Each morning he helps her up at 5 am, secures them together with a sash, and rides slowly the four kilometers to work, a journey taking an hour. At work, his employers provide her with her own room and he checks on her regularly. Lu explains that his mother devoted her life to caring for her children, and he now feels duty-bound to care for her in return.

Heavy drinking among Americans increased 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, driven largely by rising rates among women, according to a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. The CDC defines heavy drinking as exceeding one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion. Researchers attribute the increases to changing social norms that make women's drinking more acceptable, younger populations more likely to binge drink, affluent individuals having more disposable income, decreased alcohol taxes in real dollars, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study tracked county-level drinking patterns among 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older and found that approximately 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, with excessive drinking costing over $220 billion annually.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting women and babies at risk. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary, as it can cause infections and death. In England, just over a quarter of women have caesareans, more than double the rate since the early 1990s, including women choosing planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The WHO recommends the rate should ideally be between 10-15 percent due to dangers and costs. A planned caesarean costs the NHS £2,369 compared to £1,665 for natural birth. Current NHS guidelines contradict WHO recommendations by allowing caesareans even without medical justification, including for women with tokophobia (anxiety about childbirth), previous complicated births, age over 40, or conditions like asthma, diabetes, or depression. Research shows one in ten caesareans cause infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, broke into a summer home on Martha's Vineyard owned by Mark Conklin and lived there for at least a week. She sold items from the home at a yard sale, including deck chairs, a grill, tables, lamps, and a painting. Conklin discovered her in his living room on April 17, and when he called police, she fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck. She was arrested later that day after attempting to re-enter the home. Filkins has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department. Her next court date is May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with its owner after police at Albury Police Station posted humorous photos and messages on her unlocked Facebook page. The phone was handed in on Sunday morning after being lost at a friend's birthday party. Officers posted selfies and puns, including photos of the phone in a holding cell, with messages encouraging Bella to collect it and suggesting she add a password. When Bella arrived at the station, officers recognized her from her Facebook page and even replied to text messages from her friends with the same humor. Bella was able to retrieve her phone without providing identification and subsequently added a password to her device.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface after one of the fighting adults grabbed it in its jaws. The mother hippo, who had been watching from a distance with her herd, attempted to rescue her calf by attacking the adult hippo's neck, but this caused the hippo to bite down harder and fling the baby into the air. The calf died from its injuries hours later. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the incident.

A three-bedroom maisonette in Knightsbridge, London is listed for £575,000, significantly below market value due to having only three years remaining on its lease. At this price, the annual cost equals £191,000 (£15,000 monthly), comparable to renting in the area. The unmodernised property on Egerton Place features 1,990 sq/ft, two bathrooms, a reception room, lift, parking, and communal garden. If a buyer extends the lease, the property could be worth over £6 million. A second larger maisonette on the same street is priced at £595,000. Lease extension with the current freeholder (Welcome Trust) would likely cost £3.35-4.5 million for a 90-year lease. The next cheapest three-bedroom Knightsbridge property costs £1.5 million with a 28-year lease. Estate agents note such short-lease properties rarely come to market and warn buyers about the substantial premium required for lease extension.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage on Friday affecting 8,000 stores (7,000 in the US and 1,000 in Canada), caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. The outage prevented registers from processing credit cards, prompting baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods to customers. Some stores closed early to avoid further giveaways, while others remained open accepting cash. The company resolved the issue by Saturday and apologized for the inconvenience. The outage occurred one day after Starbucks announced record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Terrorist training and radicalization activities have been identified in rural areas of west Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Those involved appear to engage in ordinary community activities while harboring ulterior motives. Historical incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales include: a 1998 training group sent by Abu Hamza to the Brecon Beacons; two 7/7 bombers photographed in North Wales in 2005; three would-be terrorists from Cardiff arrested in 2010 for plotting attacks; and Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, who studied at a former institute in Llanybydder. Detective Constable Gareth Jones emphasized that terrorism issues are not limited to large cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence in identifying such activities.

A rare Omura's whale, a species feared to be extinct, washed ashore on a remote beach in Western Australia following Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. The 5.68-meter juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling, marking the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. The species was only first described scientifically in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. Omura's whales have distinctive features including a sleek body shape, 53 vertebrae, and four digits on each pectoral fin. Scientists consider the discovery highly significant as very little is known about the species. The skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and potential museum display.

A female Texas businesswoman argues that Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president because female hormones could make her irrational and start unnecessary wars. However, scientific studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men, and male leaders throughout history have made poor decisions influenced by hormones. The passage argues that the real issue isn't hormones or biology, but rather deep-seated gender bias in the workplace and society. Women face both overt bias (such as corporate boards having more men named John, Robert, William, or James than total women) and covert bias (such as professors being described as "geniuses" versus "nice"). The passage contends that gender equality benefits everyone—companies with more female leaders are more profitable, involved fathers make children happier and more successful, and diverse teams produce better results. The article concludes that society must acknowledge and actively work to overcome gender bias rather than simply telling women they can achieve anything.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his collection of over 200 antiques in a £100,000 auction to downsize his home. Known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and playing Winston Churchill multiple times, Hardy is a keen military historian who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and is an expert on the medieval longbow. The auction includes 238 lots being sold by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire on Saturday, featuring a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000-£6,000), a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, paintings, furniture, swords, rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating back to the 17th century. Hardy expressed sadness about downsizing his treasured collection but hopes new owners will enjoy the items as much as he has.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a Florida man wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead at their shared Winter Garden home on Saturday. Shemansky has been on the run since failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the day of the murder. The body was discovered following a well-being check called in by an out-of-state family member, and initial investigation determined foul play occurred. Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was previously involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward. His wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors suggest his mother may have prevented him from attending the scheduled visit and that stress from divorce proceedings may have motivated the crime. He was allegedly seen asking for water at the trailer park office shortly after the murder. Shemansky fled on foot without provisions or medication and remains at large. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

Eugene, Oregon has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations Council bypassed the usual bidding process, viewing this as a unique strategic opportunity to host the championships for the first time in the USA. Eugene had previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which went to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated the decision was made because public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public were joining forces to support the event. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan was similarly awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after being found guilty of luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death. Granger targeted Hassan after spotting him with cash at a London casino, befriended him using her appearance, then left his flat door unlocked so her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler could enter. The two men tied up Hassan and kicked him to death while searching for his hidden winnings, leaving him with multiple broken bones. They fled with £3,000, his TV, and mobile phone.
