Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum 36-year term. All three defendants were convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan. Judge William Kennedy described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's Spanish midfielder, has experienced a significant decline in form during the second half of the season, continuing a pattern noted by his former club Barcelona. After accumulating 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, he has managed only one in five subsequent games. While he was on pace to break Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists, his current form makes this unlikely. Fabregas captained Spain in a 2-0 defeat to Holland and struggled to impact the match. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is concerned about the fatigue affecting his key midfielder as the team pursues the Premier League title. With nine games remaining, Fabregas faces opponents against whom he has previously created goals, offering an opportunity for a late-season resurgence that could help Chelsea secure the title.

West Ham is negotiating to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial with their academy. Beckford, considered one of the Caribbean's top prospects, has also received offers from Belgian clubs. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets at their new Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making them the cheapest in the Premier League as they prepare to move there for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped their investigation into a violent assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, who was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters with iron bars during a hunt near Amesbury on January 24. Despite video evidence and a dossier containing names and car registration numbers provided to Wiltshire Police, the case was shelved due to insufficient evidence. Lane suffered concussion, broken teeth, memory loss, and facial swelling, and has paid £500 for dental treatment. While the suspect's photograph was released, he was never identified or charged. Lane and other hunt supporters have criticized the police decision, with the Countryside Alliance campaigning to ban face coverings on saboteurs to aid prosecution. Police stated the case remains undetected but could be reopened if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, 36, known as "Azzam the American," was killed in January in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation. Born in 1978 in rural California, he converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, joining al Qaeda at age 20. He became al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist and rose through the ranks in Pakistan's tribal areas. Gadahn appeared in numerous al Qaeda videos from the mid-2000s onward, threatening attacks on Western cities, urging Muslims to conduct lone-wolf attacks in the U.S., and criticizing American presidents. He was indicted for treason and material support to al Qaeda in 2006 and was among the FBI's most wanted terrorists. His final video was posted in September 2014. He was married to an Afghan Muslim woman and had at least one child.

Chinese parents emphasize raising child prodigies across various fields. A viral video in China features five-year-old Mai Zizhuo demonstrating exceptional basketball skills, including scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously while maintaining focus and rhythm. Mai began playing basketball at age two and a half. His remarkable abilities have garnered widespread attention and admiration from fans across China, with netizens expressing amazement, skepticism, and admiration in response to the video. China's previous basketball prominence was established by Yao Ming, who played for the NBA's Houston Rockets from 2002 to 2011.

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) from the 1970s-80s, attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to support the media pressure group's campaign for statutory press regulation. Hacked Off, established following the phone-hacking scandal, is lobbying MPs to create a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry, opposing the independent press standards organisation. O'Carroll was previously jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals and was involved with the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee. His association with Hacked Off is considered an embarrassment to the group.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as an unconventional catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Ten Pieces, a lifestyle brand headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, presented their capsule collection of ten monochromatic, unisex clothing pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. Guests enjoyed refreshments from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria while watching the minimalist, androgynous designs on an unseasonably warm 28-degree Celsius day. Regular lap swimmers were displaced to the beach for the event.

Amir Khan, a 28-year-old boxer from Bolton, spent Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During the family outing, Khan posed with and fed a rare white tiger, as well as posed with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30 at welterweight, ending speculation about potential opponents including Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian teenager who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name removed from Israel's memorial wall at Mount Herzl after complaints from his family and others. His father, Hussein Abu Khdeir, objected to his inclusion without permission and refused to have his son's name listed among soldiers. Almagor, an organization representing terror victims in Israel, also opposed his inclusion, describing his death as a rogue attack rather than an act of terrorism. Following these complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel announced it would remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial wall, and his name has already been removed from the organization's website.

A California-based YouTube user filmed his young son repeatedly using the family cat as a pillow in the garden. The boy chases the cat around, lies on it to rest, and the cat moves away each time. After several repetitions, the cat goes indoors to escape. A later video shows the boy and cat have reconciled, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a 32-year-old witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity basketball coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his years selling marijuana. Kushner testified that undercover officers on trial stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Though his 2007 charges were expunged, he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to probation, and pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. The academy's head of school was unaware of his criminal history when he was hired in 2010 after passing a background check. Kushner is one of more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government about allegations of police wrongdoing. The six former drug squad officers are accused of racketeering and other charges.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China's Fujian province, injured six people and sparked a major fire on Monday night. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, with five injuries caused by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters brought the fire under control by Tuesday morning. The plant had experienced a previous explosion in July 2013 with no reported casualties. The facility was originally planned for the densely populated city of Xiamen but was relocated in 2007 due to pollution concerns and public backlash.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland under-21 international, wears his socks low and children's-sized shinpads due to superstition, despite referees asking him to pull his socks up. He made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR on Tuesday and expressed satisfaction with receiving the opportunity, though he acknowledged it was a challenging match in a relegation battle. Grealish stated he plans to maintain his superstitious sock-wearing habit and hopes to earn more starts for the club.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive despite being removed from a medically induced coma. She does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow people around the room. She has a tracheostomy in her throat. While her father Bobby Brown stated she was awake and improving, her grandmother Cissy Houston and family attorney Christopher Brown indicated her condition remains serious, with doctors saying she could live this way for a lifetime. The family states she has left the ICU and begun a long rehabilitation process, though the quality of her future life remains uncertain.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie after two victories on Saturday. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, saving a match point in the second set, while Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's three remaining matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents are bracing for another storm this week following severe weather last week. Meteorologists predict an east coast low could bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, with the heaviest impact expected in the far northern parts of the state and the hard-hit Hunter region. The State Emergency Service has over 4,000 jobs remaining from 24,196 requests and is concerned that additional storms will hamper cleanup efforts. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills warned that more rain will raise flood levels on saturated ground and wind will topple already uprooted trees. The Bureau of Meteorology indicates intense rainfall and strong winds will primarily affect coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coasts, with peak rainfall expected between Thursday and Saturday. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families while working to complete as many cleanup jobs as possible before the next system arrives.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" music video, denied claims that she attempted suicide. Italian media reported she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment, but Moric stated she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was hospitalized on Saturday night. She posted photos of bruising on Instagram to her 40,000 followers, explaining she fell and hit her head during a domestic accident. Her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso initially confirmed the suicide attempt, but Moric clarified the reports were inaccurate and that she was recovering well at home. Italian media had also claimed she attempted suicide in 2009 through overdose. Moric is a Croatian-born model formerly married to paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son born in 2002.

Kate and William are expecting their second child, and a YouGov poll reveals the British public's preferences for the baby's name. If the child is a girl, Diana (named after William's mother, Princess Diana) is the favorite choice at 12 percent, followed by Alice and Charlotte at 9 percent each. If the child is a boy, James is preferred at 13 percent, with Alexander as the second choice. Of the 2,200 people polled, 25 percent hope for a girl, while only 3 percent want another boy. Social media users have expressed enthusiasm for naming a daughter Diana. Additionally, 68 percent of Britons support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were en route to join a larger rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other organization has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles. His agent confirmed that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that was conditional on him playing in 60 percent of matches. The negotiations have ended, and Alves will depart the club this summer.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. Osvaldo has scored three goals in six games since arriving and believes both players would be excellent fits for Boca due to their South American style of play. He stated that the Bombonera fans would enthusiastically support such signings, noting that Pirlo is one of the world's best midfielders and Totti is a Roma legend who would be equally beloved in Argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square during a race at Wincanton. Despite the dramatic nature of the fall, which became an internet sensation after being watched hundreds of thousands of times online, Ferguson sustained only a minor cut on his nose. He returned to work at Paul Nicholls's yard the following morning, mucking out stables as usual, and remains undeterred about returning to riding. Ferguson described the fall as a blur and expressed that he was fortunate the outcome wasn't worse, noting there was nothing he could have done to avoid it.

James Haskell, London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man to celebrate the release of the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie, which premiered at Westfield London shopping centre. Haskell returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing for Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and Highlanders in New Zealand. Since rejoining Wasps, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 England caps.

Wide leg trousers are a major SS15 trend that offers an effortless alternative to skinny jeans. Available in various styles including denim, cropped, printed, and striped, this look has made a comeback since the seventies. To wear wide legs successfully, especially for shorter individuals, the key is pairing them with high-heeled shoes to elongate the leg and keeping the top half simple to maintain proportion. High-waisted, longer lengths also add leg length. Denim is the easiest way to achieve the trend, with designers like Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney featuring wide-leg styles on their SS15 runways. High street options include Topshop's Miller jean. The wide-leg trouser silhouette updates your wardrobe and doesn't require specific weather conditions.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with screening "American Sniper" after initially canceling it due to a petition signed by over 200 students who objected to the film's depiction of the Iraq War and its potential negative impact on the Middle East and Arab-American communities. The university's vice president for student life stated that canceling the film was inconsistent with the university's commitment to freedom of expression and student choice. As an alternative, the university will offer a screening of "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper."

Two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly used an aerosol spray and lighter to create a flame that burned a quokka on Rottnest Island, Western Australia on April 3. The animal survived but was singed. Detectives seized video evidence of the incident, and both men were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are small animals, similar in size to domestic cats, found on islands off the west Australian coast.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed in New York nightclubs like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s alongside notable performers such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, was shown a video compilation of early music videos called "soundies" featuring her performances. Despite having motion pictures made of her and performing in chorus lines, Barker had never seen herself dancing until filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled and presented the video to her at her nursing home, delighting her with the experience.

Car washing as a Sunday routine in Britain is declining significantly. A survey of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that 31 percent of men have never washed their own car, with only 12 percent of regular washers doing so frequently. Three-quarters of women never wash their own cars. Reasons for the decline include the rise of hand car washes, larger vehicles that are difficult to clean, shops opening on Sundays, and increased live football on television. Only 5 percent of respondents said they had asked their children to wash the car for pocket money. However, car washing increases during holidays, with an estimated 15 million cars cleaned during the Easter break. Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield see the most owner-washed cars, while Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh see the least. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most frequently washed by owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least often washed by their owners.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since arriving at Liverpool in 2008 and believes the club can overcome the challenge of replacing him. Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday, with the potential to sign off his Anfield career in the final on his birthday (May 30) before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and credits him with helping him settle at the club from day one. While acknowledging that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, Skrtel believes the team has players capable of replacing him if given proper support. Both players could return to the lineup against Villa after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, his first ace on that course. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Although Nicklaus achieved his ace, Camilo Villegas eclipsed the moment by making two holes-in-one (on the fourth and eighth holes). Five total holes-in-ones were made that day, tying a record from 2002. Kevin Streelman won the par-3 contest in a play-off against Villegas. Nicklaus won the Masters green jacket in 1963 as the youngest winner and again in 1986 for his sixth title. He is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Several severe storms brought tornado warnings to Kansas and neighboring states on Wednesday night. Tornado sirens sounded as spotters reported twisters, including one about 6 miles northwest of Goddard near Wichita, and three sightings near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. A CNN severe weather expert warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Missouri was also affected, with a possible tornado touching down in Potosi, about 70 miles from St. Louis, causing wind damage, flooding, and roof damage. Reports from the region included fallen trees, water-covered streets, unusual dark clouds, and baseball-sized hail. Additional storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates claims he accidentally shot Harris with his gun instead of subduing him with a taser. The judge granted Bates permission to vacation in the Bahamas, which prompted criticism from Harris's family. Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The family's lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz, and claims he lacked proper qualifications. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office has denied these allegations. Bates has apologized for the shooting, as has the sheriff.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. McGregor has unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, joining his existing gorilla tattoo on his chest. He claims to have greater motivation than Aldo, who is defending his title for the eighth time, and has stated that Aldo doesn't want the belt as much as he does. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 supporters. The two fighters have a fractious relationship leading up to their bout.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at a university sports function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert argued the act was problematic because it glorifies binge drinking and associates masculinity with alcohol consumption, potentially encouraging people to focus on drinking quickly rather than socializing responsibly. She warned it perpetuates the stereotype that heavy drinking defines a "true blue aussie bloke." Opposition leader Bill Shorten made a quip about the incident, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott by highlighting his fitness routine. Dr. Robert noted that while drinking is part of Australian tradition, the prime minister should set an example against irresponsible drinking practices, particularly given current concerns about binge drinking.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to an intravenous drug use outbreak primarily involving the painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, which has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used syringes. The program's future beyond April 25 remains uncertain as Pence reviews recommendations from health officials. Legislation to expand needle-exchange programs to 23 other Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates has passed the House but faces uncertain Senate support, partly due to concerns that such programs could promote drug use. Funding challenges also exist, as federal law has banned public funding of needle exchange programs since 1989.

An Arsenal fan created and administered a test to his girlfriend Saskia about the football club, grading her answers with a red pen. The test included multiple choice questions, tables to complete, and open-ended sections, covering topics such as Arsenal player positions, FA Cup finals, and comparisons between players. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), with the boyfriend jokingly stating he would not dump her based on her performance. She made some errors identifying player positions but provided creative answers to subjective questions. The boyfriend posted feedback indicating areas for improvement. The post went viral on Twitter, with many commenters praising Saskia as "proper gf material" and the boyfriend as a "legend," though some felt he had taken the joke too far.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years as an informant after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s as a former mid-level Medellin cartel member. He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work but was never granted it. Toro helped the DEA carry out undercover stings worldwide and provided information that aided in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. After retiring due to declining health, he is now facing deportation and living illegally in the U.S. He cannot collect social security benefits without a green card or passport and fears returning to Colombia would result in his death. His former DEA handler and a colleague have provided financial assistance after the DEA refused to help him.

A 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh, India was allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village. Two days after the assault, she set herself on fire using kerosene, sustaining 70 percent burns, and is now hospitalized in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. The accused men have been arrested. The passage also discusses heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, including the banning of a documentary about the 2012 gang rape and murder of 23-year-old student Jyoti Singh, and recent vigilante violence against accused rapists in Nagaland.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal will face Manchester City in a derby at Old Trafford on Sunday without Robin van Persie, whom he has ruled out despite the player claiming fitness. Van Gaal distinguishes between being fit and being fit enough to play. Despite City's recent defeat to Crystal Palace, Van Gaal views the match as an opportunity for United to finish second or third and secure Champions League qualification, stating he dreams of victory. He acknowledged City will be a stern challenge and emphasized the need to control aggression, noting that losing to City twice is possible. Luke Shaw is also ruled out as not yet match fit. Van Gaal expressed appreciation for Manchester United's supporters and looked forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford with home advantage for the first time since joining the club.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at Emirates Stadium. Tickets for the 12:45pm kick-off started at £64, among the highest in the Premier League. The protest, organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906, was triggered by the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, including one reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket," to raise awareness about the financial struggles of match-going supporters. Organizers called ticket prices "extortionate" and criticized the lack of concern for fans, citing additional grievances such as late fixture changes and unreasonable kick-off times. Further protests were expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her ducts, she required a liver transplant to survive. Neither of her parents were suitable donors, but her maternal aunt Shanell Reader, who is Star's mother's twin sister, proved to be an ideal candidate and donated part of her liver. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since made a good recovery, though she requires weekly blood tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge, competing in pairs. In round one, Hazard and Ake won 5-3 by firing balls into a car boot from close range. The second challenge involved playing over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus used as a tennis net, which Hazard and Ake won again, extending their lead to 6-0. The final challenge required long-range shooting at convertible Audis, which Remy and Willian won. During this final round, Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the cars with a long-range shot. Hazard and Ake won the overall competition.

A former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, Robert Dellinger, 54, drove his pickup truck across a highway median at over 100 mph in December 2013, crashing into an oncoming SUV and killing 24-year-old Amanda Murphy (who was eight months pregnant) and her 29-year-old fiancé Jason Timmons. During his sentencing hearing, Dellinger claimed he was not suicidal, contradicting prosecutors' claims that he told investigators he was attempting suicide. He pleaded guilty in February to negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus's death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. His defense attributed his actions to Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis symptoms. The crash caused injuries so severe the medical examiner compared them to a plane crash. Dellinger also faces a wrongful death lawsuit filed by Amanda Murphy's estate.

Lacey Spears of Kentucky was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt through his feeding tube while he was hospitalized. Prosecutors alleged she made her son ill for attention and continued blogging about his condition. A New York judge noted she suffers from mental illness and called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty." Her ex-partner and the boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, hoping she would not survive in prison. Spears' lawyer claimed her innocence, blamed hospital negligence, and announced plans to appeal the verdict.

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia a month later than expected, now including protection against two new strains—influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket—that caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most indigenous Australians, will receive free government-funded flu shots from April 20. The vaccine also provides protection against influenza A strain H1N1. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the influenza specialist group, recommends that everyone get vaccinated, noting that the modified vaccine should be a good match for circulating strains globally and help prevent more deaths. He encourages people to book their flu shots now and suggests that even those not in high-risk groups should be vaccinated to protect vulnerable people around them.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois are facing challenges from both an unflattering National Geographic critique and proposed state budget cuts. The magazine described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby," while historian Adam Goodheart called it "a disappointment" in "incongruous art deco style." Meanwhile, Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the site, and funding cuts of $1.1 million have already reduced the tomb's operating hours and staff. Despite these criticisms, the preservation agency notes the tomb has received over $2.5 million in recent repairs and renovations, including $730,000 in interior upgrades completed last year. The tomb, designed by sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, features black and tan marble interior with bronze trim and houses Lincoln's burial chamber. Supporters of the site dispute the National Geographic portrayal, with some visitors calling it "absolutely gorgeous," while officials express concern about the impact of further budget cuts on the historic site's management.

Nineties and noughties fashion trends are making a comeback, with styles like chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts becoming popular again. However, many trends from that era should remain in the past. The passage identifies nine problematic fashion trends: bucket hats, camouflage print, taking trends to extremes (like double denim), UGG boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets worn as outfits, and harem trousers. While some celebrities are reviving these looks, the article suggests most are impractical or unflattering, with modern versions offering only minor updates to the original styles.

The passage summarizes trending stories from a busy week, including: four rainbows appearing over the New York area after heavy rain, China cracking down on the practice of hiring exotic dancers at wakes, Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK interview about his private life, the Kardashians sparking a lip-plumping trend using jars to imitate Kylie Jenner, 102-year-old Alice Barker recreating a prom experience with filmmakers, a controversial prom proposal referencing bombs that raised racism accusations, Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer, a pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombing his son.

Serena Williams defeated Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 in the Miami Open quarterfinals to record her 700th career victory, earning a celebratory cake. Williams advanced to the semifinals where she will face third-seed Simona Halep, who beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5. Williams's hopes of playing her sister Venus were ended when Venus lost to Carla Suarez Navarro. The milestone victory comes after Andy Murray received a cake for his 500th career win.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and cafe owner, was shot and killed at point-blank range in Karachi after locking up her second-floor cafe, T2F, which served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. She had just hosted a discussion on disappearances in Baluchistan, a topic authorities had attempted to suppress by shutting down a planned university event. Though no one has claimed responsibility and police have not named a motive, Mahmud had previously received death threats for discussing this sensitive subject. Her death devastated those across Pakistan who valued her role as a figurehead for progressive values, free speech, and tolerance in a country where such expression is dangerous. Her mother was also shot but is expected to survive.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, is among approximately 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) who fled to Kashmir during India's 1947 partition and have been denied citizenship rights for nearly 70 years. Unable to own property, vote in state elections, or access state employment and education, these refugees live in poverty in the Jammu region of India's only Muslim-majority state. Successive governments have withheld these rights due to concerns about disrupting the demographic balance between Hindu and Muslim populations. However, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) recently gaining a share of power in Kashmir, refugees like Ram and activist Labha Ram Gandhi hope their status will finally be normalized and they can obtain full citizenship rights.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Chelsea this summer after the club made an offer believed to be around £4 million. Chelsea would loan the 22-year-old to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, but Muto is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut at FC Tokyo in July 2013, praised his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence as a player. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of the Japan international but stated the club prioritizes signing good players while also considering financial and commercial interests, including Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre manufacturer Yokohama Rubber.

Australia has abandoned its policy of excluding overseas-based players from selection, a decision the author praises as sensible. The author argues England should follow suit, allowing coach Stuart Lancaster to pick the best players regardless of where they play. Examples cited include Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell at Toulon, Steffon Armitage, and Nick Abendanon, whose performances have improved abroad. The author contends that restricting selection to domestic players is outdated and counterproductive, particularly for a home World Cup where England needs its strongest squad. Jonny Wilkinson's success in France is presented as precedent. The author argues that players deserve confidence they were selected on merit, not location, and that clubs benefit from a winning national team. The current policy is characterized as misguided and unnecessarily limiting England's chances of success.

Open Garden has developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that strengthens wireless mesh networks created by their Firechat app. Firechat, downloaded over five million times, allows users to send messages and photos without internet or mobile signal by using Apple's multipeer connectivity framework (MCF) on iOS and a similar Bluetooth feature on Android. The app creates a localized network where each phone becomes a node passing data between nodes, with a maximum range of around 200 feet. Greenstone acts as a beacon to extend this range and fill communication gaps. The device is still in development, currently works only with Firechat at 20 feet range, holds up to 1,000 recent messages, and has a one-year battery life. Open Garden is partnering with manufacturers to design and sell the product for use in situations requiring resilient communication without connectivity, such as hospitals, festivals, and protests.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle delivered a TED talk promoting body positivity by reclaiming the word "fat" as a neutral self-descriptor rather than an insult. She argues that "fat" is simply an honest description of her physique, just like calling herself "short" or "wife," and should not be synonymous with "ugly." Lillian notes that society programs women to reject this label, citing a 66 percent rise in workplace size discrimination over 30 years and studies showing girls aged 11-17 wish to be thinner. However, research indicates that exposure to body diversity increases acceptance and preference for different body types. Through burlesque performance since 2012, Lillian aims to present a fuller figure in a positive, glamorous context to challenge societal beauty standards. She recommends developing a "courage reference"—a moment of bravery to recall during insecure times. Her TED talk, posted on YouTube three weeks prior, garnered nearly 38,000 views with predominantly positive feedback, including messages from viewers who reconsidered their body image perceptions.

Theo Walcott and six Arsenal colleagues posed for an official photoshoot with Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013, alongside runway model Olga Sherer. Walcott has been benched for much of the season, appearing on the substitutes' bench in 17 of 33 Premier League games. He came on for the final six minutes of Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea and is hoping to start in the upcoming match against Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday, having not started since Arsenal's 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14. Arsenal's players will wear similar attire for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa at Wembley Stadium on May 30.

A collection of 417 props and puppets created by legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker over his 30-year career will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, features items from over 50 productions including Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Gremlins 2, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker and Thriller. Individual items are expected to fetch between $1,500 and over $40,000, with notable pieces including the Alien Edgar Bug ($40,000), the Grinch costume ($8,000), and the Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons ($6,000).

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell from Wales, died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his family during skiing. While on the final run of the day at Flaine resort, his sister lost her ski and his mother stopped to help her, but Carwyn continued ahead. Believing he could see the resort through the trees, he left the piste, removed his skis, and entered dense woodland. He fell over a 164ft drop, and police located his body by following footprints in the snow. His family described him as a daring, outgoing, and determined child who brought laughter and love to those around them, and expressed their devastation at his death.

Laura Scurr, 15, from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 after being bullied about her weight and feeling pressured to be "size zero." At her worst, she survived on approximately 100 calories daily, hiding food and lying to her mother. Her severe malnutrition caused her heart rate to dangerously slow, leading to collapse and hospitalization on a heart monitor. After discharge, she received support from eating disorder organizations (EDICT and CAMHS) and has since recovered. She now advocates against size zero pressures on teenagers and has reached the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting positive body image away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit designed by New Balance, who secured a record £300 million four-year deal to replace Warrior as the club's kit supplier. The gingham design was presented by players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet at Anfield. Liverpool supporters made clear their expectation that Sterling remain at the club, with fans applauding when one supporter told him to ensure they see him in the kit next season. This came a week after Sterling rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and expressed interest in Arsenal. The players also discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley. The new shirt features white branding and includes a memorial flame and number 96 in tribute to the Hillsborough disaster casualties.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter, showing clumps of dark matter across 0.4 percent of the sky. The map is the first in a series that will eventually provide a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky, covering 12.5 percent of the entire sky over five years. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device attached to the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, as part of the Dark Energy Survey led by Fermilab. Dark matter, which comprises at least 80 percent of matter in the universe, cannot be directly observed but its gravitational effects on galaxies can be mapped. The team analyzed 130 million telescope images of galaxies to construct the map, requiring supercomputers for the complex measurements. The research shows that galaxies form where dark matter concentrations are highest, with visible galaxies clustering near dark matter clumps and sparse regions containing few galaxies. The survey aims to better understand dark energy and test cosmological theories by comparing amounts of dark and visible matter.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch winger. Manager Louis van Gaal, who is familiar with Depay from Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign where the team finished third, is keen to make him one of his first signings. Depay has had a prolific season at PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games, and helped PSV win the Dutch championship on Saturday. PSV's technical director confirmed contact from Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, noting that Depay is now worth more than Tottenham's £15 million bid from the previous summer. Depay is described as a pacy left-winger with close control who loves running at defenders, though he can sometimes make poor decisions. He was nominated for the World Cup's best young player award and scored in Holland's group stage matches.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth side 3-1 in a youth cup final match at the Academy Stadium. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half to give Chelsea an early lead, with Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalizing for City. Dominic Solanke sealed Chelsea's victory with a late goal. The passage provides detailed player-by-player analysis of both teams' performances, highlighting Abraham and Solanke's effectiveness for Chelsea, and noting that Brandon Barker was Manchester City's standout performer despite the loss.

Marco Rubio claims people are born with sexual preference but believes same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that states should decide marriage definitions through their legislatures rather than courts. He stated he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of respect and love, comparing it to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but not stopping him from loving divorced individuals. Rubio announced his presidential candidacy and has received monetary commitments exceeding $51 million for the primary season.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are cycling around the world with no fixed plans or timeline. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they have covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries in 356 days, living on less than three euros per day. They keep costs minimal by camping (their primary accommodation), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and spending only 2.74 euros daily on food—primarily pasta, bread, rice, eggs, and seasonal produce, supplemented by meals from locals and occasional foraging. Starting from London, they have traveled through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. They plan to continue into Asia and eventually cycle across the Americas, expecting to remain on the road for several more years.

A Texas couple who were married in 2012 is suing photographer James Evans of Premiere Photos after racial slurs were allegedly printed on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their wedding. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, discovered the offensive captions months after their celebration when the bride's sister informed them of the incident. When the groom contacted Evans about the photos, Evans allegedly refused to apologize and told him to "sue" him. The couple is pursuing legal action under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies all allegations, stating there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption at a party of 103 people. The couple's primary goal is to obtain an apology rather than monetary compensation. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if no agreement is reached.

Mike Brown, England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion and remains unsure when he will return to play for Harlequins. After experiencing a headache following England's match against France, he pulled out of the Ireland game despite it being a major Six Nations fixture. Brown credits World Rugby's online concussion awareness modules with helping him recognize symptoms and make the responsible decision not to rush his recovery. He emphasizes the importance of honesty about concussion symptoms and notes that increased awareness means players are now less likely to risk playing through potential concussion signs. His cautious approach contrasts with cases like George North, who has been advised not to play again this season after four quick-fire concussions, and Johnny Sexton, who was stood down for 12 weeks.

Smartphone use and internet connectivity may be contributing to a decline in sexual frequency among British couples. Research shows that typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times per month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University attributes this decline to the blurring of boundaries between public and private life, constant email checking, and increased busyness that leaves less quality time for partners. The erosion of separation between work and home life means people remain mentally connected to work and the outside world even during personal time, causing sex to fall lower on their list of priorities.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, were once highly prized in China, with prices reaching £1.2 million per dog. However, their popularity has dramatically collapsed due to several factors: the government's anti-corruption crackdown eliminated their use as bribes to officials, and weight restrictions banning dogs over 50 kg were implemented in major cities like Beijing and Shanghai. As a result, hundreds of these dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather, often stolen from streets or offloaded by breeders as poor-quality specimens. The breed's decline was also accelerated by over-breeding that deteriorated their quality and by urbanization making them unsuitable for city living. The mastiff boom that began in 2005, when they became status symbols, has ended in a cruel fate for many of these animals.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every female respondent had experienced sexual harassment on public transport, with half first experiencing it before age 18. Harassment ranges from insults and whistling to sexual assault and rape. The widespread problem causes six out of ten women to fear attacks, leading many to alter their routes, schedules, and clothing to avoid confrontation, which effectively excludes women from public spaces. The report, submitted to France's women's rights ministry, prompted calls for campaigns against sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains. Officials emphasized that women need education about what constitutes sexual assault and that the message must reach both aggressors and witnesses.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix, asking design groups to create prototype products addressing common everyday emergencies. A survey of 2,000 people identified the top ten stressors, with not being able to sleep ranking first at 46 percent. Three prototypes were shortlisted: Snooze (an alarm clock that silences phone notifications), Forget Me Lock (a key device that shows whether a door is locked or unlocked), and Nipper (a portable phone charger powered by household batteries). The public voted via Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag, with the winning product to be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product. Other concepts that didn't make the final shortlist included a smart cycling helmet with bone conduction headphones, a parking pin alert system, and a relay app for receiving messages when a phone dies.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is facing a Ministry of Justice investigation after awarding £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity supporting crime victims of which she is a director. Chief Constable Sue Sim also sits on the charity's board. Critics, including Labour MP Keith Vaz, have called the allocation inappropriate and a conflict of interest, arguing that PCCs should not use public funds for organizations in which they have a personal interest. Baird defended her decision, stating that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. The Ministry of Justice confirmed it would investigate whether conflict of interest rules were breached and has the power to cease funding if a conflict is established. Sim is retiring from the force in June.

Three people have been imprisoned and two others await sentencing for assaulting a 53-year-old man in Philadelphia. The gang, dubbed the "tattoo terrorists," was led by 21-year-old Corry Campbell, who believed the victim, Greg Valecce, had injured his cat. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng (19), and friend Carl Halin (18) beat Valecce in a basement for approximately 42 hours in March 2014, then forcibly tattooed offensive symbols and words on his body while he was restrained to a chair. Valecce suffered three broken ribs, two broken wrists, and facial fractures before escaping and contacting police. Campbell and Halin each received 20-year sentences, Ng received 23 months, and two other defendants await sentencing or trial. All three convicted pleaded guilty to aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch winger. Manager Louis van Gaal, who is familiar with Depay from Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign where the team finished third, is keen to make him one of his first signings. Depay has had a prolific season at PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games, and helped PSV win the Dutch championship on Saturday. PSV's technical director confirmed contact from Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, noting that Depay is now worth more than Tottenham's £15 million bid from the previous summer. Depay is described as a pacy left-winger with close control who loves running at defenders, strong shooting ability, and good dribbling skills, though he can sometimes make poor decisions. He was nominated for the World Cup's best young player award and scored in Holland's group stage matches.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth side 3-1 in a youth cup final match at the Academy Stadium. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half to give Chelsea an early lead, with Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalizing for City. Dominic Solanke sealed Chelsea's victory with a late goal. The passage provides detailed player-by-player analysis of both teams' performances, highlighting Abraham and Solanke's effectiveness for Chelsea, and noting that Brandon Barker was Manchester City's standout performer despite the loss.

Marco Rubio claims people are born with sexual preference but believes same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that states should decide marriage definitions through their legislatures rather than courts. He stated he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of respect and love, comparing it to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but not stopping him from loving divorced individuals. Rubio announced his presidential candidacy and has received monetary commitments exceeding $47 million for the primary season.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are cycling around the world with no fixed plans or timeline. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they have covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries in 356 days, living on less than three euros per day. They keep costs minimal by camping (their primary accommodation), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and purchasing inexpensive staples like pasta, bread, rice, eggs, and seasonal produce. Their journey began in London and has taken them through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. They plan to continue into Asia and eventually cycle across the American continent, expecting to remain on the road for several more years.

Mike Brown, England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion and remains unsure when he will return to play for Harlequins. After experiencing a headache following England's match against France, he pulled out of the Ireland game despite it being a major Six Nations fixture. Brown credits World Rugby's online concussion awareness modules with helping him recognize symptoms and make the responsible decision not to rush his recovery. He emphasizes the importance of understanding concussion dangers and being honest about symptoms, noting that increased awareness means players should not risk playing through potential concussion signs. Other players facing similar challenges include George North, who has been advised not to play this season after four concussions, and Johnny Sexton, who was stood down for 12 weeks.

Smartphone use and internet connectivity may be contributing to a decline in sexual frequency among British couples. Research shows that typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times per month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University attributes this decline to the blurring of boundaries between public and private life, constant email checking, and increased busyness that leaves less quality time for partners. The constant connectivity means people remain mentally engaged with work and the outside world even at bedtime, causing sex to fall lower on their list of priorities.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, have experienced a dramatic fall from favor in China. Once commanding prices up to £1.2 million, they are now being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which eliminated the practice of gifting these dogs to officials, and to weight restrictions (over 50 kg) imposed in major cities like Beijing and Shanghai. Poor breeding practices created a glut of low-quality dogs that cannot be sold. Additionally, rapid urbanization has made people realize the breed is unsuited to city living. Animal welfare workers have documented cruel conditions, including 20 mastiffs found in cramped cages with a third already dead and none fed for three days. Gangs are also stealing the dogs from streets to sell to slaughterhouses.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix, asking design groups to create prototype products addressing common everyday emergencies. After surveying 2,000 people about their top ten stressors, three products were shortlisted: Snooze (an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep), Forget Me Lock (a key device that shows whether a door is locked or unlocked), and Nipper (a portable phone charger powered by household batteries). The public voted via Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag, with the winning product set to be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product. Other non-finalist concepts included a cycling helmet with bone conduction headphones for navigation and a parking pin that alerts users when a parking space becomes available.
